Organization.Name: acts2fellowship
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this organization is to promote learning about God and the Bible by providing an open forum for listening to speakers and asking questions, and to be a place to build lifelong friendships.
Organization.Description: What is acts2fellowship? Acts 2 is a passage in the Bible describing people devoted to studying the Bible, to prayer and to one another. “Fellowship” is simply another word for friendship—friendships that develop through discovering life together from God’s perspective with its many challenges. So, whether you’re a Christian, or someone who’s just curious about finding out what Christians believe, we welcome you!

Organization.Name: Alpha Epsilon Zeta Fraternity, Inc.
Organization.Summary: Alpha Epsilon Zeta (AEZ) is an undergraduate Professional Fraternity sponsored by the Walter A. Haas School of Business. AEZ members come from a variety of majors, ranging from Computer Science to Business to Biology.
Organization.Description:
Founded in 2003, AEZ has grown substantially, with more 80 active and alumni members. Our alumni have leveraged the skills gained in AEZ to excel in their careers in top firms and graduate schools, including Facebook, Google, McKinsey, Goldman Sachs, UCSF Medical School, and the Harvard Business School. Alpha Epsilon Zeta’s main values are Professionalism, Brotherhood, and Unity.

Alpha Epsilon Zeta (AEZ) is an undergraduate Professional Fraternity sponsored by the Walter A. Haas School of Business. AEZ has distinguished itself from other Professional groups on the UC Berkeley Campus with its multidisciplinary focus. AEZ members come from a variety of majors, ranging from Computer Science to Business to Biology. With weekly professional development training from University Faculty and Experts in Industry, AEZ members are well-rounded and knowledgeable in a variety of fields.

Organization.Name: Alpha Phi Omega
Organization.Summary: Alpha Phi Omega is an international co-ed service fraternity with over 75 years of college volunteerism, it is the largest fraternity in the world. Our chapter at UC Berkeley consists of over 100 active members who contribute 10,000 hours of
Organization.Description:
Alpha Phi Omega is an international co-ed service fraternity with over 75 years of college volunteerism, it is the largest fraternity in the world. Our chapter at UC Berkeley consists of over 100 active members who contribute 10,000 hours of service annually. In addition to service we have numerous events during the semester to promote friendship and brotherhood within the chapter and with chapters on other campuses.

 

Places we often volunteer at include but are not limited to: Project Open Hand, San Francisco Food Bank, Adventure Playground, Playland Not At the Beach, Brewer Tutoring, Calstar Yoga, Red Cross Blood Drive, and many more. We also volunteer for some rather large-scale service projects, such as Academy of Friends, Eggstravaganza, and Halloween Carnival.

Organization.Name: American Advertising Federation
Organization.Summary: imagiCal is UC Berkeley's competition team in the annual National Student Advertising Competition hosted by the American Advertising Federation. We focus on creating multi-million dollar marketing campaigns for corporate sponsors and competing
Organization.Description: imagiCal is UC Berkeley's competition team in the annual National Student Advertising Competition hosted by the American Advertising Federation. We focus on creating multi-million dollar marketing campaigns for corporate sponsors and competing against other American Advertising Federation chapters on the regional and national levels.

Organization.Name: American Medical Student Association--Berkeley Premedical Chapter
Organization.Summary: The mission of Premed AMSA is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, support, and leadership development. As activists, we seek to educate
Organization.Description:
The mission of Premed AMSA is to develop professionalism and activism in our members as physicians-in-training. We aim to prepare students for medical school by providing resources, support, and leadership development. As activists, we seek to educate premedical students about public health issues and advocacy, such as health policy, the culture of medicine, global health and preventative medicine. We believe that a comprehensive medical education is necessary for the development of every physician.

Our general meetings for Fall 2013 are held on Thursdays from 7-8 PM in 2063 VLSB. For more information, visit our website, amsa.berkeley.edu

Organization.Name: American Nuclear Society
Organization.Summary: The American Nuclear Society serves its members in their efforts to develop and safely apply nuclear science and technology for public benefit through knowledge exchange, professional development, and enhanced public understanding.
Organization.Description:
The American Nuclear Society is a not-for-profit, international, scientific and educational organization.  It was established by a group of individuals who recognized the need to unify the professional activities within the diverse fields of nuclear science and technology.  December 11, 1954, marks the Society’s historic beginning at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, D.C.  ANS has since developed a multifarious membership composed of approximately 10,500 engineers, scientists, administrators, and educators representing 1,600 plus corporations, educational institutions, and government agencies.  It is governed by three officers and a board of directors elected by the membership.

We, The Student Chapter

The American Nuclear Society (ANS) Student Branch at University of California Berkeley is a subsidiary of the National ANS. The main objectives of the ANS Student Branch is consistent with those of the National ANS, which is to promote the advancement of science and engineering relating to the atomic nucleus and of allied sciences and arts.We are formed and managed by a group of students interested to contribute toward the development of nuclear science and technology at the University of California through activities in which student members and faculty may participate.Most of us are students in the Nuclear Engineering Department but we welcome students from all backgrounds to join us. The only requirements we ask for is a desire to learn and an open-mind for new technology.

We organize events for the benefit of our own members as well as to promote understanding of nuclear technology on campus. The recent focus of this society has been to increase public awareness of the many benefits of nuclear technology and its place in our future. With the increasing threats of nuclear terrorism, our aim is to educate the public on the safety issues and responsibilities related to nuclear power generation as well as the peaceful use of nuclear materials in medical radiation as well as food processing industries.

Our student section has sent many students to the ANS national conferences over the years. In 2002, UC Berkeley-ANS sponsored the National Student Conference for ANS and the conference was a tremendous success in bringing together students from all over the country to present information on latest technology in the field and to foster interaction between like-minded current and future scientists.

Our Mission

The American Nuclear Society serves its members in their efforts to develop and safely apply nuclear science and technology for public benefit through knowledge exchange, professional development, and enhanced public understanding.

• Creates an association where Armenians and non-Armenians alike can come together, without any outside political affiliations and/or religious influence.

• Cultivates a spirit of appreciation toward Armenian history, heritage, and culture through active cultural functions, historical and political awareness, as well as, social and recreational events.

It enhances the quality of life at Berkeley through its focus on diversity appreciation.

Organization.Description: The Asian Pacific American Coalition (APAC) currently serves 16 different UC Berkeley APA organizations. Organization.Name: Associated Students of the University of California
Organization.Summary: The Associated Students of the University of California is the official recognized student government of the UC Berkeley student population, representing over 30,000 Undergraduate and Graduate students. The ASUC is supported administratively by a
Organization.Description:

The ASUC is supported administratively by a dedicated staff of 24 career employees of the ASUC Auxiliary. Find out more about any of the components of the ASUC at...

ASUC  Student Government, asuc.org

Graduate Assembly, ga.berkeley.edu

ASUC Auxiliary, asuc.berkeley.edu

Organization.Name: Association for Muslim Professional Development
Organization.Summary: The student organization is dedicated to preparing Muslim students for professional fields. AMPD helps facilitate awareness and provides access to professional internships and vocations through networking, informational workshops, and mentor-ship program
Organization.Description:
The Association for Muslim Professional Development organization helps Muslim Students create and plan a professional future through networking, information workshops, and personalized coaching; attempting to facilitate awareness and access to professional internships and vocations. These include, but are not limited to the professional arenas of finance, medicine, engineering, consulting, sales and marketing, research, law and academics. 

Since its founding in 2005, AMPD (formerly known as the Muslim Business Students' Association) has hosted several events catered specifically to preparing Muslim students in their respective fields of study.


Building Networks: 

Our alumni have had the opportunity to employ the skills they developed through the AMPD in their careers within the corporate and non-corporate world including Bain & Co., Genentech, PG&E, Google, Microsoft, Wells Fargo, Intel, Cisco, Oracle, KPMG, Amigos International, Merrill Lynch, Lazard, Goldman Sachs, and Deloitte Consulting, as well as many more reputable firms. 

Our alumni constantly give back to the organization, acting as mentors, staffing our advisory board, and leading many of our training sessions. Our members have an opportunity to develop a network of professionals in their field of choice.

Organization.Name: Association of Psychology Undergraduates
Organization.Summary: The Association of Psychology Undergraduates (APU) is a student group that formed to serve students who are interested in Psychology. Its primary goal is to facilitate interaction between students and staff and provide students with a sense of belonging.
Organization.Description:
The Association of Psychology Undergraduates (APU) is a student group that formed to serve students who are interested in Psychology. Its primary goal is to facilitate interaction between students and staff and provide students with a sense of belonging.

APU holds lots of different kinds of events -- social, academic, volunteer -- so there is something for everyone! If you're new to psych and need some guidance, or you're a seasoned major and want to share your wisdom, you can join our Mentorship Program!

Organization.Name: ASUC - Office of Academic Affairs
Organization.Summary: DEPARTMENTS & OVERVIEWAcademic Programs, Academic Services, Intern Relations, Grants, PolicyThe purpose of the Academic Affairs Vice President office is to increase the accessibility of higher education and academic engagement to all students
Organization.Description:
DEPARTMENTS & OVERVIEW
Academic Programs, Academic Services, Intern Relations, Grants, Policy
The purpose of the Academic Affairs Vice President office is to increase the accessibility of higher education and academic engagement to all students through student initiated academic programs and services, safeguard academic affordability, and implement academic policy. We build proactive and community-oriented leaders through a social, professional, and service network. The AAVP office continues to represent student voices and fight for new educational opportunities to enrich the scholastic experience here at Cal.

Organization.Name: ASUC - Office of External Affairs
Organization.Summary: The ASUC Office of the External Affairs VP works is to represent the student body of the University of California, Berkeley to all off campus entities and empower students to create change at the local, state, national, and international levels.
Organization.Description:
ASUC External Affairs Vice President 2013-2014: Safeena Leila Mecklai

ASUC External Affairs Chief of Saff 2013-2014: Ayesha Bhardwaj

The Office of the External Affairs Vice President seeks to represent the student body at the local, state, national, and international levels. Students in the Office of the External Affairs Vice President will be working on a variety of different projects and initiatives that seek to improve UC Berkeley's relationship with the city as well as state and federal elected officials. Responsibilities may include advocacy through arranging lobbying visits, speaker forums to engage students with legislators and internal policy setters, city initiatives, as well as administrative and programming tasks. The EAVP Office channels Berkeley's history of advocacy, community organizing, and student activism.

Organization.Name: ASUC - Office of the Executive Vice President
Organization.Summary: The Office of the ASUC Executive Vice President is committed to developing quality student life and a stronger culture of community on the UC Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description: The Office of the Executive Vice President supports student organizing in all spheres. The office is a supportive partner and ally to the ASUC Senate, facilitating the success of the Senate’s collective vision while assisting with its outreach and visibility. Offering financial and networking resources, leadership development, and empowerment opportunities, we strive to provide students with an environment that allows them to create positive change in their areas of their interest. We will revamp the ASUC’s infrastructure and modernize it by leveraging technology to provide for an efficient, effective, user-friendly, and transparent ASUC. We seek to increase resources for student leaders through collaboration with other campus departments to bring affordable, accessible space and all kinds of resource to support their endeavors. We work to build a more vibrant and inclusive campus community through collaborative events, coalition building, and engaging as many students as possible in major campus decisions. Our hope to is to develop a better UC Berkeley founded on values of inclusivity, Cal pride, and thriving student life.

Organization.Description: Departments: Projects/Programs, Outreach/Internal Affairs, Policy Initiatives, Partnerships (Resources, Alumni, Financial), Commercial Development

Organization.Name: ASUC - Senate
Organization.Summary: The 20-member ASUC Senate is the legislative branch of the student government. They control the ASUC's $1.7 million budget, update the governing documents, and represent the voice of UC Berkeley students.
Organization.Description:
The 20-member ASUC Senate is the legislative branch of the student government. They control the ASUC's $1.7 million budget, update the governing documents, and represent the voice of UC Berkeley students. Senators work on a wide variety of issues such as campus safety, healthcare, affordability of education, and improving academic services.

ASUC Funding to student programs is allocated by the ASUC Senate. See www.asuc.org Funding page for a complete description of the different ways students can apply for support from the ASUC.

The ASUC Finance Committee reviews spending decisions of the ASUC Senate and Student Groups according the ASUC By-Laws Title III. Groups seeking permission to use funds for a normally restricted use (see By-Laws) or is seeking a Pauley Ballroom Rental Fee should initiate the appropriate waiver request available through the Forms link to the right of this page

Organization.Name: ASUC Student Advocate Office
Organization.Summary: Departments: Academic, Financial Aid, Conduct, GrievancesThe Student Advocate's Office -- effectively the campus public defender -- offers representation, help, and advice to any student or student group involved in a dispute with the University. We
Organization.Description:
Departments: Academic, Financial Aid, Conduct, Grievances
The Student Advocate's Office -- effectively the campus public defender -- offers representation, help, and advice to any student or student group involved in a dispute with the University. We provide assistance for a broad variety of problems, including conduct violations, grade disputes, enrollment issues, financial aid problems, establishment of residency, discrimination, and harassment. All assistance is free and confidential.

Organization.Name: ASUC Student Government
Organization.Summary: The Associated Students of the University of California are the elected representatives of the UC Berkeley student body. As the collective voice of the students, we build student power through leadership development, and through grassroots
Organization.Description:
The Associated Students of the University of California are the elected representatives of the UC Berkeley student body. As the collective voice of the students, we build student power through leadership development, and through grassroots campaigns and coalitions, we fight to hold the University, City, State and Nation accountable to student needs.

 

The ASUC Auxiliary provides essential services to the ASUC, overseeing budgets, managing and maintaining ASUC facilities, and serving and supporting Cal's student government and student organizations

Organization.Name: Berkeley American Civil Liberties Union
Organization.Summary: Berkeley ACLU is the college chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. The ACLU advocates individual rights and liberties by by litigating, legislating, and informing.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley ACLU is the college chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

The ACLU's stated mission is to to defend and preserve the individual rights and liberties guaranteed to every person in this country by the Constitution and laws of the United States. It is the nation's largest non-profit law firm and one of the leading activist organizations. Some of the ACLU's most famous legal battles include the Scopes Evolution Trial of 1925, Japanese-American internment during WWII, the desegregation struggle of the Civil Rights era, contemporary women's reproductive rights, and numerous free speech issues.

Our organization was established in the Fall of 2000. We work to educate the campus community and promote civil liberties through film screenings, speaker panels, letter writing campaigns, and ASUC Senate resolutions.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Bahai Club
Organization.Summary: tbd
Organization.Description:
The Bahá’í Faith is a world religion based on the teachings of Bahá’u’lláh. He explained that there is only one God and one human family, and that all religions are spiritually united. Bahá’u’lláh’s writings offer spiritual guidance as well as directives for personal and social conduct.

The more than five million Bahá’ís around the world are engaged in the process of learning how to translate that guidance into realities of individual and community life. Though they come from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, they are united by their belief in Bahá’u’lláh and by their desire for a united, prosperous, and peaceful future for all of humanity."

The Berkeley Baha'i Club upholds the standards of the Faith and aims to set ablaze love and unity for all of mankind. 

We encourage all of you who are interested to get in contact with us if you'd like to come to a meeting or an event or would just like to investigate the Faith.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Ballroom Dancers
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Ballroom is a student run group that has been providing classes, practices, and ballroom events for dancers in the Berkeley and East Bay area for the past 50 years!
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Ballroom is a student run group that has been providing classes, practices, and ballroom events for dancers in the Berkeley area for the past 50 years!

We cater to the needs of all dancers, and cater our classes to beginner social dancers. The best part is, for all of our events, no partner or experience is required, but if you have one or the other or both, that’s great, too!

Check UCBD.org for more information!

And ucbd.smugmug.com for pictures!

Organization.Name: Berkeley Cambodian Students Association
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture. Over the years, the Berkeley Cambodian Student
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture.

Over the years, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association has evolved to place greater emphasis upon recognizing and sharing the Cambodian-American experience with the UC Berkeley community. The Cambodian-American story is neither a relic of the past nor an inert fact of today. Thus, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association aims to reclaim Cambodian cultural and political histories, create socially aware individuals, inspire leadership and service, and bridge generations. We aim to eliminate the invisibility of the Cambodian-American community and empower its members.

Organization.Summary: The Berkeley College Republicans is one of the largest and most active student run organizations at UC Berkeley and is the largest College Republican organization in the state of California. BCR offers right-minded Berkeley students the opportunity to
Organization.Description: The Berkeley College Republicans is one of the largest and most active student run organizations at UC Berkeley and is the largest College Republican organization in the state of California. BCR offers right-minded Berkeley students the opportunity to gather behind enemy lines for a truly open discussion of the issues.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Consulting
Organization.Summary: Each semester, we provide consulting services to several businesses in the Bay Area. We also organize professional development training for our members.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Energy and Resources Collaborative
Organization.Summary: BERC is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Energy & Resources Collaborative (BERC) is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.

More specifically, BERC’s mission is to connect, educate, and engage its members in order to foster innovation and action. To that end, BERC:

  • Connects nearly 3,000 members as a part of a broad, cross-disciplinary network of students, faculty and professionals in the fields of energy and resources;
  • Educates students about cutting edge work in energy and resources through organizing events, lectures, and treks; and
  • Engages members by providing opportunities to address global energy and resources issues and collaborate on real-world projects.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Group, The
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Group is a professional student group committed to providing pro-bono consulting services to nonprofit organizations in the Bay Area. We work with individual nonprofits to create solutions to the vital challenges they face in today's
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Group is a professional student group committed to providing pro-bono consulting services to nonprofits and social enterprises in the Bay Area. We work with individual organizations to create solutions to the vital challenges they face in today's society. We believe that helping social sector organizations with business challenges is a unique way to impact the community by providing long-lasting, sustainable effects.

Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Berkeley Legal Studies Association
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Legal Studies Association is a pre-law organization affiliated with the Legal Studies Department, but open to ALL STUDENTS interested in law.
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Legal Studies Association strives to create a community of individuals interested in law. Some of our events for the semester include LSAT workshops with popular test preparation companies, lunches with Legal Studies professors, speaker panels, The Living Catalogue, and many, many other important, enjoying, and interesting opportunities! We hope that you will join the club and enjoy the friendly and intellectual environment that we are committed to provide! Please feel free to email us at blsalaw@gmail.comwith any questions you may have or if you want more information on how to join.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy
Organization.Summary: BOAA is an ASUC-sponsored student organization on the UC Berkeley campus. We have weekly meetings to discuss animal rights issues, plan events to advocate for animals, and enjoy yummy vegan food!
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy is the campus' only social justice group dedicated to raising awareness about issues of animal oppression. We, at BOAA, firmly stand against the abusive, gendered, and exploitative nature of the treatment of animals in our society. We believe that the ills of factory farming are felt not only by non-human animals, but also by the environment, people of color, low income people, and the health and culture of our society. As a group, we are dedicated to raising awareness and promoting compassionate, socially just, and sustainable diets, and advocating for the liberation of animals from systems of human oppression. We participate in vegan and vegetarian outreach on campus and work in partnership with other local animal rights groups to better the lives of non-human animals.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Stop the War Coalition
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Berkeley Students for Life
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Students for Life (BSL) recognizes the inherent and inviolable dignity of human life. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to provide the resources necessary to make this happen.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Students for Life: Mission Statement

As UC Berkeley’s pro-life student group, Berkeley Students for Life (BSL) recognizes the inherent and inviolable dignity of human life, from that of the unborn to that of the aged and terminally ill. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to put an end to abortion, embryonic stem cell research and euthanasia.

Since BSL is based at a prestigious educational institution, we see the need to educate our community about the truths surrounding offenses against human life. To that end, we facilitate and engage in intellectual discussion on relevant issues, challenging widely held relativist assumptions on the dignity of human life, the role of individual autonomy and society's role in protecting human life. Through these means, we seek to convince hearts and minds of the horrors of the offenses against life. We desire to convert society so that it might be more receptive to a culture of life that fully recognizes the dignity of every human being.

Furthermore, we aim to form leaders that will encourage the development of a more just society grounded in the recognition of the inherent and transcendent value of human life. We seek to enter our respective professions armed with the knowledge and tools needed to uphold the dignity of life in every facet of society.

Also at the heart of BSL’s mission is its commitment to community service. We believe that socioeconomic circumstances do not justify the taking of human life, and we affirm that such difficulties can be overcome. To that end, BSL provides information to assist women facing crisis pregnancies and refers them to local crisis pregnancy centers that provide women with what they need to bring new life into the world. We also volunteer at local crisis pregnancy centers to help promote their mission to encourage the bringing of new life into our community.

Though the focus of our outreach is primarily local, we collaborate with other pro-life organizations from around our state and nation and are united to them by virtue of our common cause. As a member of California Students for Life (CASTL), BSL is an active participant in the development of pro-life student activism at the state level. We also collaborate with Students for Life of America in order to engage in the fight for life at the national level. As an organization that concerns itself with matters of great public relevance, BSL strives to do everything in its capacity to shape public opinion on relevant university, state and federal policies, as well as to influence said policies, so that these might more accurately reflect our vision for a world in which every human life is valued and protected.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Undergraduate Sociology Association
Organization.Summary: tbd
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Undergraduate Sociology Association (BUSA) is an organization of students who are interested in the field of sociology. BUSA organizes valuable academic, social, service, and sociological events for undergraduates by facilitating interaction between undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty. BUSA’s goal is to provide opportunities for sociology students to explore academic and service interests in a social setting while enriching their undergraduate experience.In the past few years, BUSA has organized the GSIology Series, BUSA Bowling, Honors Thesis 411 Session, Karaoke Night, ASA Conference participation, Alumni Night, and the groups’s premier annual event: The UC Berkeley Sociological Research Symposium.

If you are interested in joining this dynamic student group, please attend BUSA’s general meetings during the first week of each month in 475 Barrows Hall. Join us in creating a thriving, inclusive sociology community at Cal!

Or you can email us for more information at:  joinbusa@gmail.com

Organization.Name: Berkeley Women in Business
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Women in Business was founded by a group of dedicated and enthusiastic female Berkeley students hoping to pursue professional careers in business. The purpose of Berkeley Women in Business is to educate Cal women about contemporary issues in
Organization.Description: Berkeley Women in Business was founded by a group of dedicated and enthusiastic female Berkeley students hoping to pursue professional careers in business. The purpose of Berkeley Women in Business is to educate Cal women about contemporary issues in the business world, to create career-networking opportunities, and to learn about savings and investment as a means of developing financial independence. BWIB hosts several corporate events throughout the year in addition to helping our members with professional development.

Organization.Name: Bioengineering Honors Society
Organization.Summary: The purpose of The Bioengineering Honor Society shall be to confer recognition upon students of Bioengineering who have demonstrated exceptional academic talent and abilities in their field, to encourage advancement and quality of Bioengineering
Organization.Description:
The purpose of The Bioengineering Honor Society shall be to confer recognition upon students of Bioengineering who have demonstrated exceptional academic talent and abilities in their field, to encourage advancement and quality of Bioengineering education and to serve as a representative on behalf of members in presenting their needs and objectives to the faculty and professional community.
-BioEHS Constitution

Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Business and Technology Association
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Business Careers in Entertainment Club
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to provide internships, job opportunities, career information, and hands-on experience to undergraduate students interested in the business end of the entertainment industry.

Organization.Name: Cal Actuarial League
Organization.Summary: Cal Actuarial League provides resources to students aspiring to be actuaries, including company presentations, exam preparation DeCals, exam manuals for renting, an annual Actuarial Career Fair, Excel workshops, and an annual Actuarial Case Competition.
Organization.Description:
Founded in February 1998, The CALIFORNIA ACTUARIAL LEAGUE aims to…

  • Inform interested students of career paths available to actuaries, and provide members with an ongoing opportunity to interact with companies seeking fresh actuaries
  • Serve as a professional and social network of persons with experience and/or interest in pursuing a career as a pension actuary, casualty actuary, consulting actuary, or other related designation
  • Serve as a contact for private and public organizations interested in recruiting for full-time positions, providing summer or co-op internship opportunities, giving corporate information sessions, offering scholarships for actuarial students, facilitating exam preparation courses to help prepare CAL members for professional actuarial examinations given by the Society of Actuaries (SOA) and the Casualty Actuary Society (CAS)
  • Advise members and non-members of appropriate agencies and resources that can answer questions or provide direction in the pursuit of one’s actuarial career
  • Have agencies permanently associate CAL members with genuine interest and determination in actuarial careers

Organization.Name: Cal Berkeley Democrats
Organization.Summary: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley.
Organization.Description: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley. We have a strong tradition of being involved in Democratic politics at both the local and state levels – our members have worked on city council races, presidential campaigns, and everything in between. We have the largest active membership of chapters among the California College Democrats. We are also one of the most active chapters of the California Young Democrats. In addition to working to get Democratic officials elected, our annual events include the California Democratic Party Convention, various community service projects, partaking in debates on-campus, and a variety of other social and professional events. The Cal Berkeley Democrats are committed to making the goals of the Democratic Party realities; these include but are not limited to – affordable higher education, good jobs with good pay, responsible environmental use, and affordable health care for every American. For more information about our club, including how you can get involved, please visit our website at www.caldems.com.

Organization.Name: Cal Dragon Boat
Organization.Summary: Dragonboat is an ancient sport originating in China where multiple boats, each consisting of 20 paddlers, race against each other to victory. Today, dragonboat has become one of the fastest growing water sports in the world, with teams ranging from San
Organization.Description:
Dragonboat is an ancient sport originating in China where multiple boats, each consisting of 20 paddlers, race against each other to victory. Today, dragonboat has become one of the fastest growing water sports in the world, with teams ranging from San Francisco to Australia. Our team is composed of a group of loud and crazy college kids who aim to become one of the fastest teams out on the water. During the school year, we practice 2-3 times a week on the water at Alameda Bay and twice a week on campus near the RSF. Our team races in various competitions around the Bay Area and Long Beach about 6 times a year. Next year, our team plans on competing in Vancouver at the Rio Tinto Alcan Dragonboat festival, one of the largest competitions in the world with over 200 teams competing. 

If you are interested in joining our team, please feel free to contact one of our captains for more information about recruitment.

Organization.Name: Cal Hawaii Club
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Cal Hiking and Outdoor Society
Organization.Summary: The largest and oldest Outdoor Club on campus! Community members, undergrads, and grad students get together to enjoy any & all outdoor activities. IMPORTANT: We don't use CalLink & can't accept member requests here. To join CHAOS, please see our website
Organization.Description:
The largest and oldest Outdoor Club on campus!

Community members, undergrads, and grad students get together to enjoy any and all outdoor activities. Camping, backpacking, kayaking , climbing, fishing, skiing, you name, we do it!

IMPORTANT: We only use this CalLink page for administrative purposes with the ASUC, and only add club officers to our roster. If you want to join CHAOS, please check out our website, or come out to one of our weekly meetings (details below.)

We meet every Wednesday at 7:30 in the La Val's courtyard, on Euclid (North side of campus). Everyone is welcome to stop by, grab dinner or just chill!

Membership is $10 a year, and gains you access to an email list with over 600 enthusits, and access to the the Gear Shed, which contains all types of outdoor gear you will need for your adventures, at no extra cost to you!

Keep it Chaotic! :)

Organization.Name: Cal in the Capital
Organization.Summary: Cal in the Capital is a student-run program at UC Berkeley that helps 70 students each year to learn the application and professional skills necessary to find a summer internship in DC.

Organization.Name: Cal Japan Club
Organization.Summary: CJC is a UC Berkeley student club open to everyone! CJC brings the Japanese student community together by providing networking, socializing, and career opportunities to Japanese and Japanese-American students. We also welcome anyone interested in
Organization.Description:
CJC is a UC Berkeley student club open to everyone!  CJC brings the Japanese student community together by providing networking, socializing, and career opportunities to Japanese and Japanese-American students. We also welcome anyone interested in Japanese language or culture.
The official language of the club is Japanese, but the events are hosted in English.  Casual conversation is often in Japanese. We cater to those who are currently learning Japanese and looking for the opportunity to use it.

 

Our traditional social events include the first general meeting, welcome party, movie night, language exchange, game night, bowling trip, hot-pot (nabe) party, and end of semester party.  CJC also provides support for job hunting in Japan. We often host panel discussions, on-campus company info sessions, and career guidances.

Organization.Name: Cal Pre-Law Association
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Cal Pre-Vet Club
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Cal PVC is to connect UCB pre-veterinary students with one another in a supportive environment and to provide opportunities to learn about the field of veterinary medicine.
Organization.Description:
Mission
The mission of the Cal PVC is to connect pre-veterinary students at the University of California, Berkeley, in a supportive community and to provide opportunities to learn about the field of veterinary medicine.  These opportunities include:
  • lectures delivered by professionals in the veterinary and animal science fields.
  • educational field trips to veterinary and animal care facilities.
  • community service for or with local animal welfare organizations.
  • informational meetings that address students' questions about academics and obtaining animal experience.
Why Cal PVC?
Cal PVC prides itself in being UC Berkeley's premier resource for pre-veterinary students.  Cal PVC aims to serve its members in all academic and extracurricular endeavors, and these services are unique to Cal PVC alone.  Through the club, Cal PVC members forge long-lasting relationships with local veterinarians, enjoy priority for behind-the-scenes tours of major organizations, and receive significant aid in preparing their applications for veterinary school.  Cal PVC hosts a wealth of knowledge and experiences, and we are proud to serve the UC Berkeley veterinary community.

Organization.Name: Cal Running Club
Organization.Summary: We are a friendly group of runners who meet 6 days a week for running and fun. To join the Cal Running Club, all you have to do is show up! We meet at Kroeber Fountain, at the cross of Bancroft and College (across the street from Cafe Strada).
Organization.Description:
Cal Running Club is a student-run running group at UC Berkeley. We meet 6 days a week, rain or shine, pay no membership fees, and have a lot of fun running with other students who also enjoy running. If you like running, you should definitely come check us out! 

We meet for 3~5+ mile runs at 5pm, Monday through Friday, at Kroeber Fountain (at the cross of Bancroft and College, across from Cafe Strada). We also have Sunday morning long runs this semester at 9am, also at Kroeber Fountain.

Rules of Running Club:

1. -No iPods/CD players/MP3 players/etc. More generally, anything that lowers your ability to hear during runs is banned. We like to keep our runners safe and healthy, and staying alert while running on the dangerous streets of Berkeley is part of that effort. Plus, this means its easier to socialize during runs =)

2. - No iPods/CD players/MP3 players/etc.

3. - No iPods/CD players/MP3 players/etc.

4. -Have fun and run!

Organization.Name: Cal Slam
Organization.Summary: Established in 2001, CalSLAM hosts workshops, open mics, and slams open to the campus and greater Bay Area community, throughout the school year. Our mission is to create a safe space on campus for students and community members to explore and share them
Organization.Description:
Established in 2001, CalSLAM hosts workshops, open mics, and slams open to the campus and greater Bay Area community, throughout the school year. Our mission is to create a safe space on campus for students and community members to explore and share themselves, their experiences and their world through words.

For the uninitiated, poetry slam is an oral poetry competition in which poets bring to the mic their original work, and are given scores based on their writing and performance from judges (picked randomly from the audience) on a scale of 1-10. In general, poetry slams are loud, high-energy, and brashly honest. Poets bring their original work to compete for a chance to represent UC Berkeley at the ACUI-hosted College Union Poetry Slam. Anyone can sign up to read, but only students, staff, and employees can make the team.

Cal Slam hosts events throughout the semester and features the best performing artists from the Bay Area to the Atlantic Ocean

Organization.Name: Cal Taiko
Organization.Summary: Cal Raijin Taiko is a Japanese drumming team comprised of UC Berkeley students drive to perfect and share the art of taiko with the community. Cal Taiko members two to three times a week to practice songs and prepare for on and off campus performances.
Organization.Description: Founded in 2005 by Tom Hata and Andrew Rowland, Cal Raijin Taiko has been a part of the UC Berkeley community as the only taiko, or Japanese drumming, team. Our group is comprised of roughly twenty members who meet two to three times a week on campus to practice musical drills, songs, and prepare for performances. Cal Taiko's writes its own repertoire and builds its own equipment, outside of practice hours. Members are highly commited to perfecting the art of taiko and sharing the culture of taiko with the community. Around campus you may often see Cal Taiko practicing at night or appearing at performances such as Calapalooza and Cal Day. Raijin Taiko is excited to have become a regular part of campus activities and enjoys sharing the energy of taiko with the students of Cal.

Organization.Name: Cal Undergraduate Public Health Coalition
Organization.Summary: We are a professional organization that strives to give students the skills, experience, opportunities and support necessary to excel in the field of public health.
Organization.Description: Cal UPHC gives students opportunties to lead service, research, and educationional events in the areas of International Health, Public Health Policy and Advocacy, Community Health and Environmental Health. Our organization also publishes the Public Health Advocate, which is a student-run journal that explores pressing health issues. Other past projects/events include teaching De-Cal courses, hosting internship workshops, holding nutrition fairs, promoting health awareness days, and sending opportunity updates. Future events will include career dinners, mixers with public health professionals, panels, and networking events.

Organization.Name: California Mock Trial
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: CalSol
Organization.Summary: CalSol, the UC Berkeley Vehicle Vehicle Team, is an ASUC sponsored student-run organization whose mission is to design, build, test, and race solar powered vehicles.
Organization.Description: CalSol, the UC Berkeley Solar Vehicle Team, is an ASUC sponsored student-run organization whose mission is to design, build, test, and race solar powered vehicles.

Organization.Name: Cantonese Student Association
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Chi Epsilon - Civil Engineering Honor Society
Organization.Summary:
The civil engineering honor society--
Dedicated to the purpose of maintaining and promoting the status of civil engineering as an ideal profession, Chi Epsilon was organized to recognize the characteristics of the individual civil engineer
Organization.Description:
The civil engineering honor society--

 

Dedicated to the purpose of maintaining and promoting the status of civil engineering as an ideal profession, Chi Epsilon was organized to recognize the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career, and to aid in the development of those characteristics in the civil engineering student. Engineering, the application of scientific principles to the practical needs of society, is assuming a constantly increasing responsibility for the physical well-being of all people, and thus calling for competence of the highest order. This responsibility can be discharged only by a professional group whose members are possessed of a good basic technical ability, intelligence, moral integrity, and effective social poise in their relationship with the larger community of which they are part. To contribute to the improvement of the profession, Chi Epsilon fosters the development and exercise of sound traits of character and technical ability among civil engineers, and its members, by precept and example, toward an ever higher standard of professional service.

Organization.Name: Chinese People Union
Organization.Summary: Chinese People Union is a social club run by people who are dedicated to promote Chinese culture on campus. Throughout the semester, we organize various fun retreats, celebrations, and mixers.

Organization.Name: Chinese Student Association
Organization.Summary: We promote the interests and awareness of Chinese culture in the Berkeley community while functioning as a means of social engagement.Some of our well-known events include Karaoke Contests, Moon Festival Bonfires, and the annual Chinese Culture Night.
Organization.Description: Founded in 1951, the Chinese Student Association (CSA) is the first Chinese organization serving the growing Chinese-American community in Berkeley. Today, we are one of the largest and most active organizations at UC Berkeley. CSA promotes the interests and awareness of Chinese culture in the Berkeley community while functioning as a means of social engagement. We host several events which allow participants to have fun and meet new people. Some of our more well-known events include Karaoke Contests, Ski Trips, Broomball, Moon Festival Bonfire, and the annual Chinese Culture Night.

Organization.Name: Circle K International
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to develop college students into responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to serving our community. Our club adheres to the tenets of service, leadership, and fellowship. We organize over 200 service projects
Organization.Description: Our mission is to develop college students into responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to serving our community. Our club adheres to the tenets of service, leadership, and fellowship. We organize over 200 service projects (over 15,000 service hours this year), raise over $19,000 a year for charity, and put on over 100 social events for our members. We benefit the community through these projects, in which we take on tasks such as cleaning up the environment, serving food to low-income families, putting on free festivals and educational workshops for underprivileged children, and raise money for global charities such as Pediatric Trauma Program, Eliminate Project, and Autism Speaks.
Organization.AddressStreet1: Circle K International c/o LEAD Center

Organization.Name: Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action By Any Means Necessary
Organization.Summary: BAMN is building the new civil rights movement to realize Dr. Martin Luther King's vision of integration and equality in America. We stand against the New Jim Crow, which includes separate and unequal education and discrimination against immigrants
Organization.Description: BAMN is building the new civil rights movement to realize Dr. Martin Luther King's vision of integration and equality in America. We stand against the New Jim Crow, which includes separate and unequal education and discrimination against immigrants without papers. We will organize to win by any means necessary.

Organization.Name: Committee for Korea Studies
Organization.Summary: Weekly meeting: 88 Dwinelle Friday 7:00 pm Objective: to increase the awareness and knowledge of Korean culture, history, and issues to the students of the University of California, Berkeley and its surrounding communities.
Organization.Description:
Weekly meeting: 88 Dwinelle Friday 7:00 pm

Objective: to increase the awareness and knowledge of Korean
culture, history, and issues to the students of the University of California, Berkeley and its surrounding communities.

Organization.Name: Computer Science Undergraduate Association
Organization.Summary: We are the computer science undergraduate association. We serve the Berkeley community by providing infosessions, help sessions, tutoring, and tons of other events!
Organization.Description: We are the computer science undergraduate association. We serve the Berkeley community by providing infosessions, help sessions, tutoring, and tons of other events!

Organization.Name: CRSSO - Conservation & Resource Studies Student Organization
Organization.Summary: The purpose of CRSSO is to foster community among past, present and future Conservation and Resource Studies majors by providing academic support, networking, volunteer and social opportunities.
Organization.Description:
The Conservation and Resource Studies Student Organization is a cohort within the College of Natural Resources comprised of current, past, and prospective CRS students. We embody the colleges' "See the Bigger Picture. Make a Better World" tagline as we are a community striving to make a more socially just, ecologically friendly, and sustainable way of life. The CRSSO actively engages with ESPM 90, the introductory course to the major, to help guide the students in the formation of their Area of Interest. The CRSSO serves as a hub to discuss important issues in our society and shows students how they can tailor their AOI around these complex issues.

We also offer students a taste of what research at Berkeley is like by acting as a platform where seniors post their research thesis and link up with other students interested in that field of study. Our goal is to set up a senior mentor/ underclassmen mentee program to further utilize the interdisciplinary design of our major.

A large focus of the CRSSO is the Alternative Graduation ceremony each May for CRS graduating seniors. The CRSSO is the entire basis behind organizing and implementing the event as well as for the healthy growth of Living Diplomas which are handed to each graduating senior.

Apart from activities within our own major, the CRSSO organizes fun events and promotes volunteer opportunities both on and off campus.

Organization.Name: CyKorean
Organization.Summary: not in rso database

Organization.Name: Danceworx
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Danceworx is to provide an outlet for dancers to perform and also to provide an opportunity for dancers to learn and improve technique, while in a fun and supportive environment.
Organization.Description:
Danceworx was founded in 1988 and is the oldest student-run dance group on the UC Berkeley campus. For over 20 years, we have been providing students with a creative outlet to choreograph, dance, and perform in a fun and supportive environment.

Dancers are selected at the beginning of each semester and practice routines in various styles: Jazz/Lyrical, Hip Hop and Tap. Throughout the semester, we host social events such as Bowling, Movie Nights and our End of the Semester Banquet so our dancers can get to know each other better.

Each semester culminates in three performances: two outdoor showcases on the UC Berkeley campus and an evening showcase in a local theater venue. Our showcases attract over 400 attendees each semester and also feature guest performances from campus and local community groups to foster unity and promote diversity among UC Berkeley’s performing arts community.

Danceworx also performs at campus and local events. If you would like Danceworx to perform at one of your events, please contact our Outreach Chair (dwxoutreach@gmail.com).

Like us on Facebook! facebook.com/danceworx

For more information, please visit: dwx.berkeley.edu

Organization.Name: DeCadence
Organization.Description: DeCadence ("dee-KAY-dence") is a student-run, co-ed a cappella group at the University of California, Berkeley. We give several public concerts each semester and are available for private events. Don't forget to stop by Sather Gate every Wednesday at noon, where you'll find us singing our hearts out!

Organization.Name: Delta Phi Epsilon Co-ed Professional Foreign Service Fraternity
Organization.Summary: Cal's only Foreign Service and International Affairs Co-ed Fraternity.
Organization.Description: Cal's only Foreign Service and International Affairs Co-ed Fraternity.

Organization.Name: Dil Se
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's premier South Asian Acapella team
Organization.Description: UC Berkeley's Dil Se was founded by Arjun Ohri in 2004 after many semesters of being just a dream. Dil Se combines the melody-based raagas of Hindi Film Music with the depth and harmony that drive western music to create a fresh perspective on the tradition of a cappella. The group combines a wide range of experience, from years of training in Hindustani and Carnatic music, to Western Classical and Jazz Choirs, and even countless mornings of singing in the shower. Our goal is to entertain the audience with a well-rounded performance that emanates Dil Se -- "from the heart".

Organization.Name: Eggster Organization
Organization.Summary: Eggster is a non-profit student organization located in Berkeley with a focus on volunteering in the lower-income community. Every year we organize and run the Eggster Egghunt and Learning Festival, the largest free egghunt in Northern California.
Organization.Description:
Eggster is non-profit student group and is composed of three committees: Finance, Event, Public Community Relations. Each of these committees provides an opportunity for members to develop an array of skills in leadership, communication, community networking, event planning, advertising, and fundraising. Our activities include planning our annual, free, on-campus Eggster Hunt and Learning Festival, going on volunteer outreaches in the Berkeley area, and raising money for our agencies. 

The Event Committee accounts for just that, the event. Every year, their creative minds come up with atheme and about 30 corresponding booths for the children to enjoy. They not only research and create learning and activity booths, but also acquire the necessary materials and supplies through in-kind donations. They also train the 300 volunteers through orientations about a month before the big day. They design the egg hunts and have recently added obstacle courses to physically challenge the children. 

Each committee is made up of two leaders ("Eggheads") and about 3-5 members. The two "Overalls" are the leaders in charge of the "Eggheads" and the Social/Admin "Eggheads" have their own responsibilities but do not head a committee. 

The Finance Committee takes on all fiscal responsibilities. In addition to doing organizational bookkeeping such as tracking the budget andprocessing reimbursements, they also work to acquire prize donations for the winners of the raffle drawing held at every event. Finance is also in charge of writing grant and corporate applications, which constitute much of Eggster's budget. 
The Social Historian and Technology chair records minutes, organizes social events, and compiles a scrapbook at the end of the year. SHA also designs and periodically updates Eggster's website, which is essential for communication within the student group and with the greater university and Bay Area community. 

The Public Community Relations Committee(PCR) consists of the recent combinations of two committees: Public Relations (PR) and Community Relations (Comrel). PCR deals with both the public and the community aspects of the organization. PCR advertise for our event directly to low-income elementary schools, and are involved throughout the entire process of inviting, choosing, and working with our beneficiaries. PCR is also responsible for attaining food and candy donations for the egg hunt. In doing so we work with small businesses as well as large corporations. PCR networks with elementary schools, small businesses, corporations, and non-profits in the Bay Area. <

Organization.Name: EGO (Cal's Traditional Korean Percussion Group)
Organization.Summary: EGO's mission is to share the joy and beauty of Korean traditional drumming, also known as PungMul. In doing so, we hope to spread awareness of Korean culture in the Bay Area and beyond.

Organization.Name: elecTonic
Organization.Summary: elecTONIC is dedicated to all aspects of electronic music, including: listening and appreciation, DJing, concerts, production, dance, and electronic music culture.
Organization.Description:
elecTONIC is a student group at UC Berkeley dedicated to promoting all kinds of electronic music!

We bring together music fans, DJs, and music producers to host awesome events and support the Berkeley electronic music community.

If you're into music production, DJ'ing, awesome music...OR if you're just a fan of shake'n it on the dance floor, then join this group RIGHT NOW.
---
elecTONIC:
:: Brings together electronic music lovers
)) Throws ultra awesome dance parties
|| Helps you find music (Music swap or featured tracks on the website - msg me if you wanna blog!)
>> Teaches music production, DJing, and glowsticking
~~ Releases compilation album(s) or mixes
!! Promotes more varied dancing styles at Berkeley

Organization.Name: Engineering Student Council
Organization.Summary: The Engineering Student Council represents the engineering student body; supporting engineering societies in reaching their full potential; and promoting a diverse community through successful collaboration between students, faculty, societies
Organization.Description: The Engineering Student Council represents the engineering student body; supporting engineering societies in reaching their full potential; and promoting a diverse community through successful collaboration between students, faculty, societies

Organization.Name: English Undergraduate Association
Organization.Summary: The English Undergraduate Association (EUA) is an academic and social organization that serves all undergraduates interested in the study of English language and literature. The goal of the EUA is to provide a forum for students to participate
Organization.Description: The English Undergraduate Association (EUA) is an academic and social organization that serves all undergraduates interested in the study of English language and literature. The goal of the EUA is to provide a forum for students to participate actively in the English major on the Berkeley campus. We exist as a liaison between students and the English Department. The EUA works to facilitate working academic relationships between professors and the student body, as well as to encourage social interaction between faculty and students. We exist to strengthen the connection between UC Berkeley students and the local literary community.

Organization.Name: Ethiopian Student Union
Organization.Summary: The Ethiopian Students Union is a student-based organization that focuses on the further academic, social, and cultural advancement of the Ethiopian students on the University of California, Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description: The Ethiopian Students Union is a student-based organization that focuses on the further academic, social, and cultural advancement of the Ethiopian students on the University of California, Berkeley campus. This organization will initiate programs and activities within and outside of the university to promote interaction and strengthen relations between students and members of the Ethiopian community outside of the campus. The level of growth and success of this organization is entirely dependant on the interest and participation demonstrated by its members. Thus, the union serves as: a pillar of information inspired by the experienced seniors, the judicious juniors, the acknowledged sophomores, and the zealous freshman; a place to exchange current affairs and discuss new developments in Ethiopia; and a place to share and express our tradition.

Organization.Name: European Student Union
Organization.Summary: European Student Union (ESU) is an organization dedicated to revealing and fostering the incredible diversity of European culture and all that it has to offer here at Berkeley!
Organization.Description: European Student Union (ESU) is an organization dedicated to revealing and fostering the incredible diversity of European culture and all that it has to offer here at Berkeley!

Organization.Name: Evangel Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: We exist to increase the knowledge and application of God's Word in the lives of His people and lead others to the saving knowledge of Jesus Christ so that they can live to the glory of God.
Organization.Description:
We exist to increase the knowledge and application of God's Word in the lives of His people and lead others to the saving knowledge of Jesus Christ so that they can live to the glory of God. We are a campus outreach ministry of Evangel Bible Church of Berkeley.

We meet every Friday at 7:00 PM during the Fall and Spring semesters on the UC Berkeley Campus for a time of praise and Bible study. Each week's location will be posted on our online media outlets. We also meet together in mid-week small groups.

Join us as we delve deeply into the Bible and study how it speaks to us today. We will read and discuss, discover and apply, and encourage and support each other each week as we come to know and love God. Everybody is welcome!

Organization.Name: Fashion and Student Trends
Organization.Summary: The purpose of our group is to provide an opportunity for students interested in fashion or the fashion industry to learn from other students and experts in the field.  We hold one fashion show a semester, featuring student designers
Organization.Description:
The purpose of our group is to provide an opportunity for students interested in fashion or the fashion industry to learn from other students and experts in the field.  We hold one fashion show a semester, featuring student designers and student models, to help our students experience a real fashion show.  We also have experts in the fashion industry talk to us about career development and industry trends. 

Our club also aims to help students network with each other and we foster this through social events throughout the semester.  We try to make various field trip to see shows and fashion show cases.  We constantly try to diversify our trips to attract a larger variety of members.

Lastly, philanthropy is a fundamental part of FAST.  Half of all proceeds raised at our fashion shows go to a reputable charity.

Organization.Name: Fei Tian Dancers
Organization.Summary: Fei Tian is a group of dancers who promote cultural awareness through Chinese dance performances from many of China's ethnic groups and by providing Cal students with a beginning dance decal.
Organization.Description:
As UC Berkeley's only Chinese dance performing group, Fei Tian Dancers (FTD), strives to cultivate an on-campus atmosphere that welcomes and appreciates the abundant diversity of the Berkeley community. FTD performs at many functions in Berkeley and around the Bay Area, showcasing the multifarious ethnic dances of China.

The Chinese people consists of more than 50 ethnic minorities, and each group's cultures and lifestyles are illustrated and expressed through the performing arts. FTD provides an opportunity for all those interested to enhance their Chinese ethnic dance techniques and skills.

While the performing group forms the core of Fei Tian Dancers, the group also facilitates a Beginning Chinese Dance DeCal every semester and hosts free monthly workshops. Everyone is invited to join the DeCal and come to these workshops, regardless of gender, ethnicity, or dance experience.

Organization.ParentName: Associated Students of the University of California

Organization.ParentName: Associated Students of the University of California

Organization.Name: National Organization for Women
Organization.Summary: Berkeley NOW is a multi-issue feminist organization that seeks to raise awareness in our community about womens' issues such as pay equity, body image, reproductive rights, economic justice, sexual violence, media and conscious consumerism.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley NOW is a multi-issue feminist organization that seeks to raise awareness in our community about womens' issues such as pay equity, body image, reproductive rights, economic justice, sexual violence, media and conscious consumerism.

The goal of Berkeley NOW is to take action to empower anyone who has, does or will identify as a woman. We recognize that all forms of marginalization are interrelated, and we strive to eliminate oppression everywhere.

Organization.Name: Pre-Health Society
Organization.Summary: Now known as the Pre-Health Society, our club focuses on building a strong pre-health community by uniting pre-meds, pre-dents, and even those who are interested in health but not sure what they want to do.
Organization.Description: The Pre-Health Society (formerly known as Asian American Health Society) was created to help everyone understand more health issues in the United States. Our society is focused on helping new students, especially freshmen and transfer students, to find research opportunities and giving advice regarding school and classes. We will also provide career guidance by inviting professors, graduate students, and professionals to come speak about their jobs, volunteer experiences, and research experiences.

Organization.Summary: Central location for Information and Forms for Government (formerly SAG Parent Organization)

Organization.Name: Theta Tau
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Theta Tau is to develop and to maintain a high standard of professional interest among its members and to unite them in a strong bond of fraternal fellowship.
Organization.Description: The only Professional Co-Ed Engineering Fraternity on campus.

Organization.Name: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation
Organization.Summary: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation, formerly known as Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, is an organization dedicated to better social services, medical care, education, and humanism in the community. We hold weekly community service and
Organization.Description: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation, formerly known as Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, is an organization dedicated to better social services, medical care, education, and humanism in the community. We hold weekly community service and cultural events that promote the organization's values and principles.  These events include shoreline clean-up, hotmeal serve, visiting a convalscent home, recycling, tea ceremony, sign language, flower arrangement, and much more!

Organization.Name: Active Minds
Organization.Summary: Active Minds at Berkeley is a student-run mental health awareness, education, and advocacy group. By planning campus-wide events that promote awareness and education, the group aims to remove the stigma that surrounds mental illness. The
Organization.Description:
Active Minds at Berkeley is a student-run mental health awareness, education, and advocacy group. By planning campus-wide events that promote awareness and education, the group aims to remove the stigma that surrounds mental illness. The group's goal is to create a comfortable environment for open conversation about mental health, and empower students to tell their stories and know they are not alone.

Find us on Facebook! Active Minds at Berkeley

Organization.Name: Advocacy Agenda
Organization.Summary: tbd
Organization.ParentName: ASUC - Office of the Executive Vice President

Organization.Name: Alpha Kappa Alpha
Organization.Summary: Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated is an international service organization that was founded at Howard University in Washington, D.C. on January 15, 1908. It is the oldest Greek-lettered organization established by African American college women.
Organization.Description:
Since its founding over a century ago, Alpha Kappa Alpha’s mission has been to cultivate and encourage high scholastic and ethical standards, to promote unity and friendship among college women, to study and help alleviate problems concerning girls and women in order to improve their social stature, to maintain a progressive interest in college life, and to be of “Service to All Mankind.”

Rho Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated was chartered at the University of California, Berkeley on August 21, 1921 by 6 women under the leadership of Soror Ida Louise Jackson. With the chartering of Rho Chapter, the landmark expansion of the sorority to the West Coast began. Rho women have been striving to fulfill Ida’s dream of nothing short of excellence for the chapter. The women of Rho exemplify the Alpha Kappa Alpha woman through their commitment to academic excellence at Cal and beyond, professional and personal development, community service, and their sisterhood.
Organization.AddressStreet1: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA BERKELEY LEAD CENTER – 102 HEARST GYM, MC 4500
Organization.AddressStreet2: ATTN: ALPHA KAPPA ALPHA SORORITY, INC.

Organization.Name: Alpha Phi Alpha
Organization.Summary: TBD

Organization.Name: Alternative Breaks
Organization.Summary: Alternative Breaks offers service-learning trips during academic breaks for UC Berkeley students to explore a social justice issue through education, reflection, and immersion into an impacted community.
Organization.Description:
Since its founding in 2001, Alternative Breaks has been a service-learning program that offers students opportunities to connect to the greater community through meaningful service, education, and reflection during their academic breaks. Many participants return from their experiences with greater insight on a particular social justice issue and a deeper understanding on what it means to get involved in the community. This year, Alternative Breaks offers ten trips to different locations during the spring break, covering issues such as environmental justice, health care, immigration, and homelessness.

These student-led trips travel to different locations in California and throughout the Western United States to further understanding of the community and to bring knowledge gained on-site back to the Berkeley community. Students not only participate in a week-long service trip, but also a spring DeCal course to further explore various topics revolving around each social justice issue and engage in reflection both pre- and post-trip.

Organization.Name: American Red Cross at Cal
Organization.Summary: American Red Cross at Cal is composed of a passionate group of college students dedicated to the mission and spirit of the Red Cross. "The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of...
Organization.Description:
American Red Cross at Cal is composed of a passionate group of college students dedicated to the mission and spirit of the Red Cross.

"The American Red Cross prevents and alleviates human suffering in the face of emergencies by mobilizing the power of volunteers and the generosity of donors."

We provide students and the community free disaster preparedness trainings, CPR/First Aid/AED classes, operate one of the largest blood donation centers in Northern California, respond to local and national disasters, and raise awareness about disasters and international issues and how the Red Cross is involved.

Come join us and our various lines of service: Blood Services, Youth Services, Awareness and Fundraising, Health and Safety, and Disaster Services.

Website: redcross.berkeley.edu
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/ARCatCal/

Organization.Name: Amnesty International
Organization.Summary: Founded in London in 1961, Amnesty International is a Nobel Prize-winning grassroots activist organization with over 2.2 million members worldwide. Amnesty International undertakes research and action focused on preventing and ending grave abuses of the
Organization.Description:
Founded in London in 1961, Amnesty International is a Nobel Prize-winning grassroots activist organization with over 2.2 million members worldwide. Amnesty International undertakes research and action focused on preventing and ending grave abuses of the rights to physical and mental integrity, freedom of conscience and expression, and freedom from discrimination, within the context of its work to promote all human rights.

The UC Berkeley chapter of Amnesty International works to promote human rights within our collegiate student body through advocacy, education, action, and service. Our past events have included film festivals, speaker events, letter writing campaigns, dinner/discussion series, demonstrations, concerts, and more.

 

Check us out on our website  https://sites.google.com/site/berkeleyamnesty/, Facebook, Twitter, and Blogger!

 

*ASUC Sponsored

Organization.Name: Art of Living
Organization.Summary: Yoga, knowledge, meditation, breathwork, service and fun.
Organization.Description:
Operating in over 150 countries, The Art of Living Foundation (AOLF) is a non-profit, educational and humanitarian organization founded in 1981 by the world-renown philanthropist and spiritual leader Sri Sri Ravi Shankar. All of AOLF’s programs are guided by Sri Sri’s philosophy: “Unless we have a stress-free mind and a violence-free society, we cannot achieve world peace.” The AOLF community is diverse and attracts people from all walks of life backgrounds and religious orientations. 

AOLF offers numerous highly effective educational and self-development programs and tools that facilitate the elimination of stress and foster deep and profound inner peace, happiness and well-being for all individuals. These programs, which include breathing techniques, meditation, yoga, and practical wisdom for daily living, have helped millions around the world to completely transform their lives. 

In addition to these courses offered globally, AOLF, working in collaboration with The International Association for Human Values (IAHV), has successfully implemented numerous humanitarian projects and service initiatives including conflict resolution programs, disaster relief, sustainable rural development, empowerment of women, prisoner rehabilitation, education for all, and environmental sustainability.

It has been said of Sri Sri Ravi Shankar that not since Mahatma Gandhi has one person united so many people of different races, religions, traditions, economic and social status, and nationalities, creating a One World spiritual family across the globe.  Sri Sri’s message is simple: “Love and wisdom can prevail over hatred and violence.” Happily this message is not just a slogan but through AOLF has been and continues to be translated into action and results.

Organization.Summary: TBD
