Organization.Name: ASUC Judicial Council
Organization.Summary: The Judicial Council consists of 9 students vested with the judicial authority of the ASUC. The Council's authority extends to all judicial cases that arise under the Constitution and the ASUC By-Laws.
Organization.Description: The Judicial Council consists of 9 students vested with the judicial authority of the Association. The council's authority extends to all judicial cases arising under the Constitution, the ASUC By-Laws, official actions of ASUC executive officers, employees, the Senate, and any matters delegated to the council by the ASUC Senate or the Constitution. In exercising the primary judicial powers of the Association, the Council only grants such judicial relief as defined by the Constitution and the By-Laws of the Association. All decisions of the Judicial Council shall be final unless reversed by subsequent council action.

Organization.Name: ASUC Lobby Corps
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley Lobby Corps is designed to help student groups on campus become more politically active. We can provide a "How to Lobby" Training, research issues that may be pertinent to your student group, and even arrange and assist with lobby visits.If
Organization.Description:
UC Berkeley Lobby Corps is designed to help student groups on campus become more politically active. We can provide a "How to Lobby" Training, research issues that may be pertinent to your student group, and even arrange and assist with lobby visits.

If you are a leader in an organization interested in adding a political component to your group, please contact us at callobbycorps@gmail.com and let us know. We would be happy to help you in that process.

Organization.Name: ASUC Secretariat
Organization.Summary: The Secretariat is comprised of a Senate Office Manager and typically 4-6 Senate Secretaries. We are ASUC Auxiliary staff who advise the student government offices and handle general office tasks on the second floor of Eshleman. You will often see us
Organization.Description:
The Secretariat is comprised of a Senate Office Manager and typically 4-6 Senate Secretaries. We are ASUC Auxiliary staff who advise the student government offices and handle general office tasks on the second floor of Eshleman. You will often see us staffing the front desk when you visit the second floor.

 

We have many responsibilities, some of which include: student government advising, student government budgeting and reimbursements, room reservations and equipment rentals, updating and distributing important ASUC documentation, and handling general campus and public questions.

Organization.Name: ASUC Student Legal Clinic
Organization.Summary: The ASUC Student Legal Clinic (SLC) is a comprehensive, student-run legal resource center that helps students and community members make informed decisions about legal problems. Interns learn to compile in-depth case reports for our clientele.
Organization.Description:
The ASUC Student Legal Clinic (SLC) is a comprehensive, student-run legal resource center that helps students and community members make informed decisions about legal problems. The clinic offers information on topics such as drug and alcohol isses, renter issues, bankruptcy, consumer issues, contracts, court appearances, divorce, immigration, insurance, small claims, and traffic violations. Services include legal research, attorney/agency referrals, and income tax assistance. The SLC does not give legal advice, but rather provides research for legal options.

Office: 112 Hearst Gym, Rm 112C

Drop-In Hours:

Academic Year (September - May) Monday- Thursday 10AM-4PM and Friday 10AM-2PM

Summer (May - August) : email intake only

Email: asuclegalclinic@gmail.com

Organization.Name: ASUC Sustainability Team
Organization.Summary: The Sustainability Team is a special program in ASUC established in Fall 2005. As a team, we create and implement a variety of projects that help establish sustainable practices and promote environmental awareness on campus.
Organization.Description:
The Sustainability Team is a special program in ASUC established in Fall 2005. As a team, we create and implement a variety of projects that help establish sustainable practices and promote environmental awareness on campus. Project committees within STeam work as a tight unit to accomplish their goals, and leadership capacity is shared equally. STeam is headed by the ASUC Director of Environmental Sustainability (DES) and is institutionalized in the ASUC constitution (Article I, Title 9.26: Director of Environmental Sustainability). STeam members meet all together once a month and separately within project groups every week to update each other on the progress of our projects and brainstorm strategies for successful implementation, and project committees break out into small groups to work on their individual projects. STeam members are unpaid and commit a minimum of 5 hours a week to their projects. The team also spends time outside of meetings through our STeam Socials and Community Service days a few times per semester.

Sustainability Team has coordinated EarthWeek every year since 2006 to celebrate Earth Day and engage the campus community in solutions to environmental issues.

In Fall 2006 STeam partnered with SUPERB to host a Climate Change Fair which featured a screening of Al Gore's "An Inconvenient Truth," as well as many campus and community environmental organizations.

Since our founding, Sustainability Team has provided students with reduced free or cost reusable water bottles to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, other toxic pollutants and waste--especially popular are our reduced priced Klean Kanteen stainless steel water bottles!

In Spring 2007 STeam launched The Local, UC Berkeley's first-ever student-run, nonprofit, cooperative produce stand that sells only locally grown, pesticide free, fresh fruits and vegetables. They're especially affordable since the stand is run completely by volunteers!

In Fall 2007 and Spring 2008, STeam continued its work with Earthweek and is started two new projects including our Responsible Investments Campaign (RI)and our One-Side-Clean Paper Project (OSC). RI retired at the end of Spring 2009, but OSC is still extremely vibrant and productive.

The 2009-2010 academic school year also saw the advent of the Composting Group, Student Team on Zero Waste and Plastics, and Campus Collaboration.  Campus Collaboration got absorbed into another entity outside of STeam [B-GAIA/ECO] during Fall 2010.

The highlights of the 2010-2011 academic year include the successful screening of "Tapped", a movie about the negative externalities associated with bottled water, the creation of our very own bag monster, and the creation of an auditing team for the ASUC's Green Certification pilot program, in which student groups can be actively recognized for their "greening" efforts.

During the 2011-2012 academic year, STeam had eight project groups: The Local, One Side Clean, Earth Week, Focus the Nation (STeam Energy), End Coal Campaign, Fair Trade University, Student Team on Zero Waste and Plastic (STOP), and Compost Group. Each project group worked hard to create tangible improvements and spread awareness on campus. Highlights include the screening of two documentaries: The Last Mountain and Waste Land, attending both the Fall and Spring California Student Sustainability Coalition Convergences, bonding at a STeam Winter Retreat, organizing a fantastic Earth Week 2012, and creating the Guide to Sustainability at Cal video for the CalSO program. We hope that our momentum will continue into the 2012-2013 academic year!

We are always open to new ideas.  The next project we work on could be yours! So come check us out at our meetings and initiate your own ideas.

The official STeam website is currently under construction, but the temporary website is http://calsteam.wordpress.com/. Visit it to learn more about project groups and upcomming meetings/events!

Organization.Name: Bay Area Environmentally Aware Consulting Network
Organization.Summary: The Bay-Area Environmentally Aware Consulting Network (BEACN) is a non-profit student organization that specializes in sustainable business consulting for local businesses and non-profits in the Bay Area.
Organization.Description:
The Bay-Area Environmentally Aware Consulting Network (BEACN) is a non-profit student organization that specializes in sustainable business consulting for local businesses and non-profits in the Bay Area. Each of our project teams consist of 5 undergraduate students majoring in Environmental Economics, Business, and a range of other disciplines.


In the past, BEACN has helped organizations:

-Formulate CSR policies for greener business operations
-Obtain Alameda Green Business
Certification<http://www.greenbiz.ca.gov/>
-Expand marketing strategies through market analysis and consumer research
-Calculate cost and energy savings of green products

Organization.Name: Bears for UNICEF
Organization.Summary: UNICEF at Cal is an ASUC sponsored student group at UC Berkeley. Founded in 2001, we are proud to be one of the first college campus UNICEF clubs!
Organization.Description: As one of the leading UNICEF Campus Initiatives, we aspire to raise funds and increase awareness among the students of UC Berkeley, as well as the surrounding East Bay community. Each year, we organize several outreach events that involve our entire community; we hope that our passion for helping children in developing countries will inspire and encourage the UC Berkeley community to join us.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Business Society
Organization.Summary: Here at the Berkeley Business Society, our primary goal is to use BBS' extensive network to help members access a bank of internships, mentorships, and networking opportunities while gaining real-world experience and building their professional skills.
Organization.Description:
Here at the Berkeley Business Society, our primary goal is to use BBS' extensive network to help members access a bank of internships, mentorships, and networking opportunities while gaining real-world experience and building their professional skills. What sets BBS apart is that we take a personal approach and tailor the club experience to every individual. Our distinct committees--Consulting, Marketing, Finance, Professional Development, Pro-Bono Consulting, Information Technology, Entrepreneurship and Communications--encompass different sectors of business, and members can apply to be in the division that interests them. Furthermore, bi-weekly workshops present skills and opportunities that can be used in any field of business. It is our hope that in BBS you will be able to find an area of business that interests you, and from there we will do our best to help you reach success.

Mission

The Berkeley Business Society is a close-knit group that aims to develop three things in its members: Skills, Cohesion and Networking. Therefore, all of our activities are geared toward improving the business and analytical skills of our members, expanding the members' professional networks and building up strong cords of friendship within the group.

(Berkeley Business Society changed its name from IABC August 2013)

Organization.Name: Berkeley Project, The
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Project is among one of the largest volunteer organizations on the UC Berkeley campus. Every year, we host four large scale service events with over 3,000 volunteers at over 100 sites in the City of Berkeley and Greater East bay.
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Project began in 2006 as a one-day service event. We have since expanded Berkeley Project Day to an annual 2,000 person event where volunteers work on service project throughout the City of Berkeley. From working at elementary schools to planting trees, making meals for the homeless to helping out at senior centers, our volunteers devote 15,000+ hours every year. Sign up for the eighth annual Berkeley Project Day today!

Organization.Name: Berkeley Roots & Shoots
Organization.Summary: " Roots & Shoots is guided by the founding principles and extraordinary vision of Dr. Jane Goodall, renowned primatologist, environmentalist and humanitarian. Her firm belief that young people, when informed and empowered, when they realize that
Organization.Description:
"

Roots & Shoots is guided by the founding principles and extraordinary vision ofDr. Jane Goodall, renowned primatologist, environmentalist and humanitarian. Her firm belief that young people, when informed and empowered, when they realize that what they do truly makes a difference, can indeed change the world, is at the very heart of our program. This powerful message of hope inspires us all. Our program—dedicated to inspiring tomorrow's leaders today—not only motivates young people to learn about pertinent issues facing our local and global communities, but helps them actually design, lead and implement their own projects as a means of solving them."

- Roots and Shoots international website: http://www.rootsandshoots.org

Organization.Name: Best Buddies at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Black Recruitment and Retention Center
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to recruit and retain Black students at the University of California Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
By recognizing the struggle young people of color and our privilege as black students in higher education, the Black Recruitment and Retention Center seeks to serve our community both on and off the University of California, Berkeley in order to reestablish the foundation that attributed to our success as black students today. We hold ourselves accountable for:

1.The active recruitment of high school and community college students of color;

2.Being aware and involved in the political realms education for all students and;

3. Maintaining a strong connection with our communities outside of Cal, while retaining ourselves academically and socially

Organization.Name: Black Students in Health Association
Organization.Summary: Promote the needs and services for the pre-medical students of African decent at UC Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Californians, The
Organization.Summary: The Californians is a dynamic group dedicated to campus and community service, provide leadership development and class unity for the purpose of making today’s active students into tomorrow’s active alumni.

Organization.Name: City Affairs Lobby and Housing Commission / Cal Housing
Organization.Summary: This commission advocates for student housing needs through a website, surveys, and other means and plans Tenant's Rights Week.

Organization.Name: Dance Marathon
Organization.Summary: Dance Marathon is an annual campus-wide event that brings students together for a fun-filled night in the fight against Pediatric AIDS. Since its founding in 2005 Dance Marathon has raised upwards of $160,000 for the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS
Organization.Description:
Dance Marathon is an annual campus-wide event that brings students together for a fun-filled night in the fight against Pediatric AIDS.  Since its founding in 2005 Dance Marathon has raised upwards of $160,000 for the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation.  Consisting of 12 consecutive hours of dancing, live entertainment, themed activities, free food and exciting contests and prizes, Dance Marathon is unlike any other event on campus.  Coupling a lively social event with a highly relevant and worthy cause, Dance Marathon continues to to grow in popularity.

 

The Dance Marathon Committee works year-round to plan the annual all-night event, which generally takes place in Pauley Ballroom.  Dance Marathon is co-sponsored by the Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC) and the Office of Student Development (OSD), and as a non-profit student-run organization relies on the support of the university and its resources to continue its rising success on campus.

Organization.Name: Engineers and Mentors of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Come teach hands-on science and engineering lessons to local schools! You don't have to be a science/engineering major to join!
Organization.Description: BEAM is a student run organization that develops and teaches hands-on science and engineering activities to K-12 grade levels at local schools to make science and engineering more approachable and encourage students to pursue classes and careers in STEM-related fields. We train college students to be effective mentors, role models, and leaders in their community. As students ourselves, we understand that the best way to learn is to teach. Berkeley students earn course credit while improving their mentoring skills.

Organization.Name: Fellowship in Christ in Berkeley
Organization.Summary: FICB is a group of Cal Students committed to WIFE - Worship, Instruction, Fellowship, and Evangelism

Organization.Name: For Christ's Sake
Organization.Summary: For Christ's Sake is a Christian a Capella group that seeks to glorify God and share the gospel of Jesus Christ through song.
Organization.Description:
As Cal's Christian a cappella group, we have come together across campus fellowships and churches to proclaim the good news of the Gospel through song to our campus and community. Our hope is that through music we can better understand and share with others the knowledge that every good thing in us is for the sake of Christ, as expressed in Philemon 1:6.

We were founded by a group of Cal students in 2000. This spring, we celebrate 13 years of God's faithfulness to this group, and our prayer is that you might also be blessed by the joy we experience through Him. 

FCS has had the privilege of producing 3 studio albums: Nothing Compares (2004), Voicemail (2009), and Send Some Rain (2013). To listen to and purchase our most recent album, visit http://fcsberkeley.bandcamp.com/

Interested in gigs, purchasing a CD, or have general questions? Email us at FCSBerkeley@gmail.com.

Organization.Name: Foresight Pre-Optometry Club
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's Pre-Optometry Club aims to unite students and community members who are interested in the field of optometry. We encourage everyone to not only learn more about optometry but to build friendships with their future colleagues. Welcome!
Organization.Description: Foresight Pre-Optometry Club is a student-run organization that seeks to unite UC Berkeley students and individuals around the area who are interested in pursuing a career in the field of optometry. We teach members the necessary skills and we provide members with the necessary tools to shape them into more knowledgeable applicants. We hold various events such as optometry school presentations, detailed workshops on the application process and strategies for tackling the OAT, and socials to allow members the opportunity to meet peers and potential optometry school classmates. We educate our members on the current issues facing the growing field of optometry, and we encourage individuals to volunteer to better prepare them for a career in providing eye care for their community. Foresight aims to create a network between the members of the club and current optometrists by keeping strong connections with professors and alumni.

Organization.Name: Formula SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers)
Organization.Summary: We design, fabricate, and compete with small formula-style racecars against other colleges from around the world. The FSAE set of rules is in place to test our engineering skills and creativity.

Organization.Name: Freshman and Sophomore Business Club
Organization.Summary: Our purpose is to help students who want to major in business or economics take the right classes and make the right choices for the Haas School of Business, promote business and economics-related interests of freshmen and sophomores, educate freshmen
Organization.Description: Our purpose is to help students who want to major in business or economics take the right classes and make the right choices for the Haas School of Business, promote business and economics-related interests of freshmen and sophomores, educate freshmen and sophomores about current business issues, and provide help for freshmen and sophomores enrolled in lower-division business classes.

Organization.Name: Friends of the Co-ops
Organization.Summary: We are an organization open to all students, faculty, and staff interested in the Berkeley Student Housing Co-ops. We are a link between the UC Campus and the BSC (Berkeley Student Cooperative).
Organization.Description: The mission of Friends of the Co-ops is to provide an extension of the Berkeley Student Cooperative (BSC) community to the campus area. Our group will provide support and information about the BSC to current members. It will also work to promote community and campus interest in the activities of the BSC and cooperative living. The BSC is committed to providing a quality, low-cost, cooperative housing community to university students.

Organization.Name: Future Business Leaders of America-Phi Beta Lambda, Inc.
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley chapter of Phi Beta Lambda revolves around two central tenets: the promotion of the skills necessary for success in business leadership and the opportunity to experience the benefits of small club that some feel lacks at a large university.
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley chapter of Phi Beta Lambda revolves around two central tenets: the promotion of the skills necessary for success in business leadership and the opportunity to experience the benefits of small club that some feel lacks at a large university such as UC Berkeley. In order to achieve these goals, Berkeley Phi Beta Lambda employs a committee system that is headed by an executive board. Each semester, nine different committees focus on completing various tasks for the education and enrichment of the members of the organization. All committees utilize different talents that have real-life applicability. From fundraising campaigns conducted by the Finance Committee to large-scale presentations hosted by the Historian committee, all members of Berkeley Phi Beta Lambda are exposed to and instilled with critical skills and knowledge that possess value during and after college life.

 

Berkeley Phi Beta Lambda is affiliated with the national organization Future Business Leaders of America Phi Beta Lambda, Inc., a nonprofit organization. Because of this connection, Berkeley Phi Beta Lambda participates in various national-level and state-level functions hosted by FBLA-PBL, such as the State Business Leadership Conference held every spring. The State Representative on the executive board acts as the liaison between the local and state and national chapters of Phi Beta Lambda. Thus, Berkeley Phi Beta Lambda affords members the opportunity to interact with those not just on the Berkeley campus but also with affiliates at the state and national levels.

 

Visit our website at www.berkeleypbl.com for more information.

Organization.Name: Global Diversity Achievement Club
Organization.Summary: To promote diversity while also serving as a platform to accomplish the ideas of others.
Organization.Description: The strength of Berkeley is in its diversity, and from this diversity comes an abundance of unique and beneficial ideas. Not only will the club be a social setting for people with different backgrounds to come together, but it will allow them to watch their ideas become a reality with the help of other members in the club. Global Diversity Achievement Club is a hub for innovation and creativity; friendship and loyalty; understanding and knowledge.

Organization.Name: Grupo Folklorico Reflejos de Mexico
Organization.Summary: A student run organization whose goal is to educate the campus and local community about the richness and beauty of traditional Mexican dance.
Organization.Description: As a dance group we aim to teach both the students directly participating and the community about the fundamentals of Mexican culture.

Organization.Name: Haas Business School Association
Organization.Summary: The Haas Business School Association (HBSA) is the undergraduate student government of the Haas School of Business.

Organization.Name: Hindu Students Council
Organization.Summary: The UC Berkeley chapter of Hindu Students Council was founded in 1997 as a small organization of like-minded individuals with a keen interest in Hinduism.
Organization.Description: The UC Berkeley chapter of Hindu Students Council was founded in 1997 as a small organization of like-minded individuals with a keen interest in Hinduism. After a semester-long hiatus in 2000, the organization was revitalized with new leadership. Since then HSC has become a well-established club on campus, celebrating major festivals such as Dev-Diwali, Mahashivaratri, Makar Shankrati, Ramanavmi, providing the only open forum for Hindu students and faculty to organize on campus, and playing an active role in interfaith dialogue alongside a wide range of cultural and religious organizations.

Organization.Name: Hong Kong Student Association
Organization.Summary: The purpose of establishing HKSA is to provide a means for its members, in particular for Cantonese-speaking students, to socialize and interact and to promote the unique culture of Hong Kong in the at UCB. In pursuit of fulfilling its purpose, theH KSA
Organization.Description:
Hong Kong Student Association

Email: hksaofficer(at)gmail(dot)com

Website: www(dot)berkeleyhksa(dot)com

Tabling Hours: Sproul Plaza Tu-F 11-2

 

Facebook Group: Hong Kong Student Association

 

  • What is HKSA?We are a social organization that illustrates the Hong Kong culture with various outdoor and indoor activities. At HKSA, we avidly champion the culturally rich blend of traditional legacy and fast-paced modernity.

 

  • What do we do?The organization’s main purpose is to support current and prospective students from Hong Kong in adjusting to the UC Berkeley environment as well as to offer them a comfortable social environment under which they find familiar pieces of cultural elements from home. We are here to bring people together and promote the formation of new friendships. Throughout the year, we organize a variety of cultural, athletic, and other entertaining activities. In addition to promoting unity among Hong Kong students, we are also enthusiastic in facilitating cultural exchange between students from Hong Kong and other countries to reflect hong Kong’s internationally cosmopolitan spirit.

 

  • How can I join?The membership fee is only $10 per year. It is your ticket to stress relief for your career at Cal as well as many discount offers for events. Not to mention, you’ll also get a free HKSA T-shirt when you sign up!

Organization.Name: Indian Students Association
Organization.Summary: The Indian Student Association (ISA) is an organization conceived with the objective of representing India and the Indian community to the UC Berkeley campus in particular and the Bay Area in general.
Organization.Description: To educate, inform and present issues pertaining to the Indian sub-continent. These include but not limited to the social, cultural, spiritual, and political components relating to India and the established Indian communities through out the South Asian Disaspora. It would further attempt to foster and encourage an intellectual milieu that would discuss history, the foundation of the nation,various works of literature and other quintessential facets that has given India its unique position.

Organization.Name: Indus
Organization.Summary: The primary purpose of the association shall be to organize and engage in activities designed to preserve South Asian culture among its membership.
Organization.Description: To achieve this aim, Indus shall: 1. organize educational and cultural activities meant to educate the campus population at-large about classical and modern South Asian culture; 2. provide a forum of cultural, social and recreational activities designed to enhance the relationships between South Asian students on campus

Organization.Name: Institute of Transportation Engineers at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this ITE student chapter shall be to promote the advancement of transportation engineering by fostering the close association of students with transportation professionals
Organization.Description: The purpose of this ITE student chapter shall be to promote the advancement of transportation engineering by fostering the close association of students with the transportation engineering profession and the Institute; to acquaint students with topics of interest in transportation through speakers and chapter-sponsored trips; and to promote common interests among students.

Organization.Description: Purpose: 1) To promote IAESTE United States' mission of 'developing global skills in tomorrow's technical leaders'; to promote international understanding and goodwill amongst the students of all nations; 2) to provide students at institutions of higher educa tion with technical experience abroad relative to their studies in the broadest sense; 3) to promote cultural understanding through the exchange of students in work based opportunities; 4) to provide the opportunity for Berkeley students to live and

Organization.Name: International Students Association at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ISAB aims to create a positive intellectual and social atmosphere for international students, stimulate cultural awareness among all students in Berkeley, and strengthen Berkeley's multicultural community
Organization.Description: ISAB aims to create a positive intellectual and social atmosphere for international students, stimulate cultural awareness among all students in Berkeley, and strengthen Berkeley’s multicultural community

Organization.Name: Intertribal Student Council
Organization.Summary: academic representations of Native American Intertribal Students

Organization.Name: InterVarsity Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: IVCF
Organization.Description: The purpose of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship/USA is to establish and advance witnessing communities of students and faculty who follow Jesus as Savior and Lord at colleges and universities; growing in love for God, God's word, God's people of every ethnicity and culture and God's purpose in the world.

Organization.Name: Iranian Student Alliance in America
Organization.Summary: Iranian Student Alliance in America was established in the fall of 2002 at UC Berkeley with the aim of raising social, cultural and political awareness. We wish to promote Iran's rich culture through different event.
Organization.Description: We, the members of Iranian Student Alliance in America, wish to increase the general public's awareness regarding Iran and Iranian issues, provide a forum for discussion on Iranian topics, and promote the Iranian/Iranian-American community, identity, and culture. We also wish to increase the voice of Iranian/Iranian-Americans within the United States.
Organization.AddressStreet2: University of California, 112 Hearst Gym MC 4520

Organization.Name: Iranian Students Cultural Organization
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the group is to educate and promote cultural awareness among both natives and non-natives of Iran through various group activities. The group is in no way politically or religiously affiliated.

Organization.Name: Israel Action Committee
Organization.Summary: IAC
Organization.Description: The Israel Action Committee is the oldest organization in Berkeley dedicated to educating and promoting discussion about Israel to students, faculty, and the community. IAC aims to provide Berkeley with a link to Israeli politics, current issues, the diversity of cultures that exist in the state today, and the various perspectives surrounding the country and its presence in the Middle East. IAC is a group and social network for students who believe in and are passionate about the state of Israel. IAC provides a forum for its members to discuss and learn more about Israel, as well as an opportunity to interact and engage directly with various leaders, organizations, and sectors of Israeli society.

Organization.Name: Italian International Students Association
Organization.Summary: The Italian IISA was founded in 1999 by a group of UC Berkeley graduate students, with the goal of spreading the understanding of Italian culture, by promoting many of its aspects (tradition in the arts, history, and lifestyle). To promote its
Organization.Description:
The Italian IISA was founded in 1999 by a group of UC Berkeley graduate students, with the goal of spreading the understanding of Italian culture, by promoting many of its aspects (tradition in the arts, history, and lifestyle).

To promote its goals, the IISA promotes events such as exhibitions, symposia, music, theater, film and food festivals revolving around Italian Culture. All IISA activities are open to people interested in discover these different aspects of Italian culture and tradition.

The IISA has a certain number of so-called Active Members, who are directly involved in organizing the IISA activities. Past members have also an important role in giving suggestion to the current active members.

Any student, staff or faculty member of UC Berkeley may become an Active Member (see our constitution), you don't have to be Italian! You just need good will, commitment and passion. If you're interested, please read the rules on the constitution and then contact us

Organization.Name: Jericho!
Organization.Summary: Improvisational and sketch comedy troupe at UC Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
jericho! is U.C. Berkeley's premier longform improv team. We specialize in bringing various longform improv formats to the stage, as well as written sketches and videos.

We hold auditions at the start of every semester. Come to our general meeting to sign up for an audition time!

Organization.Name: Jewish Business Association
Organization.Summary: JBA

Organization.Name: Jewish Student Union
Organization.Summary:
Mission Statement:
The Jewish Student Union works towards evaluating and improving Jewish life on campus while creating a unified structure to represent the Jewish community. We are here to express a voice, to allocate resources to
Organization.Description:
Mission Statement:

The Jewish Student Union works towards evaluating and improving Jewish life on campus while creating a unified structure to represent the Jewish community. We are here to express a voice, to allocate resources to members, and to foster communication between the leadership of student groups within Berkeley Hillel.


Community Participation

The JSU functions best when community members involve themselves in the everyday workings of the group, rather than relying solely on the leadership. The executive board exists to implement the desires of the community and we need external input to represent the Jewish Community effectively. If you have an idea for an event or program that you would like to see, email the JSU President Daphna Torbati, JSUPres@gmail.com.

Organization.Name: Kairos Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: We are a Christian campus fellowship at UC Berkeley. We believe that the Bible is still very relevant in this day and age, and we live life and have fun together. We belong to the bigger family that is Gracepoint - Berkeley, led by Pastor Ed
Organization.Description:
We are a Christian campus fellowship at UC Berkeley. We believe that the Bible is still very relevant in this day and age, and we live life and have fun together.

We belong to the bigger family that is Gracepoint - Berkeley, led by Pastor Ed and Kelly Kang.

Organization.Name: Kappa Gamma Delta
Organization.Summary: Kappa Gamma Delta is dedicated to providing academic, social, and emotional support to the premedical community at Cal. We are also committed to various service events and projects in the community.

Organization.Name: Kesher Enoshi: Progressives for Activism in Israel
Organization.Summary: Kesher Enoshi is a growing community of students dedicated to engaging directly with social change organizations and activists in Israel.
Organization.Description: This engagement is driven by inclusive discussion and democratic decision-making, and is aimed at creating substantive exchanges, providing mutual assistance, and making meaningful contributions. Through engaging with these organizations and activists, we educate ourselves and others about their projects and objectives, discuss their work critically, openly and self-reflexively, and link them with relevant organizations on campus and in the wider community.

Organization.Name: Koinonia Campus Fellowship
Organization.Summary: Christian Fellowship for all students - for training and learning Bible theology, philosophy, community service, & much more. We're a UC Berkeley Christian Fellowship (Club). Many of us also attend Gracepoint Berkeley, with Pastor Ed and Kelly Kang.
Organization.Description: We're a UC Berkeley Christian Fellowship (Club). Many of us also attend Gracepoint Berkeley, where Pastor Ed and Kelly Kang lead the ministry.

Organization.Name: Korean American Student Association
Organization.Summary: The Korean American Student Association (KASA) is an organization of Korean and Korean American students here at UC Berkeley. Through our common heritage, we promote a balanced fellowship through which our peers may project one voice in celebration of
Organization.Description: The Korean American Student Association (KASA) is an organization of Korean and Korean American students here at UC Berkeley. Through our common heritage, we promote a balanced fellowship through which our peers may project one voice in celebration of our unique culture. We strive to foster an environment for cultural enrichment as we seek to remind students of their heritage, and to share with others what makes us a community. We hope that through our efforts, the organization may inspire and instill pride and devotion towards our Korean heritage with the student population and the community as a whole.

Organization.Name: Korean Chamber Ensemble
Organization.Summary: Korean Chamber Ensemble is a student-led instrumental chamber ensemble that will seek to provide more variety in Berkeley campus community by means of music, holding weekly practices and concerts each semester.
Organization.Description: Korean Chamber Ensemble is a student-led instrumental chamber ensemble that will seek to provide more variety in Berkeley campus community by means of music, holding weekly practices and concerts each semester.

Organization.Name: Laotian American Student Representatives
Organization.Summary: The primary goal of LASR is to create a community for UC Berkeley students who originated from Laos and to establish awareness for those who are interested in the cultures
Organization.Description: The primary goal of LASR is to create a community for UC Berkeley students who originated from Laos and to establish awareness for those who are interested in the cultures and experiences of Laotians. This community on the UC Berkeley campus provides social and academic support for all the members within the club.

Organization.Name: Latino Pre-Law Society
Organization.Summary: The Latino Pre-Law Society (LPLS) prides itself in providing information and exposure to UC Berkeley undergraduates who are interested in the field of law.
Organization.Description: Established in the Fall semester of 2002, the purpose of the Latino Pre-Law Society is to provide a solid professional, educational, progressive, supportive, and networking foundation within the Latino community in the legal profession, the Latino population at UC Berkeley, and the community at large. LPLS is a non-partisan organization that focuses on a progressive agenda that prepares and empowers Latinos to pursue a legal education and/or career. The importance of a career isn't only limited to a law degree, members also consider an online homeland security degree as another option for a great career in the field of criminal justice.

Organization.Name: LiNK Berkeley Chapter
Organization.Summary: LiNK is a student chapter of LiNK, a human rights NGO based in Torrence, California. Our mission is to raise awareness of the North Korean human rights crisis and fundraise to provide emergency relief and resettlement funds to North Korean refugees
Organization.Description:
LiNK is a student chapter of Liberty in North Korea, a human rights NGO based in Torrence, California. Our mission is to raise awareness of the North Korean human rights crisis and fundraise to provide emergency relief and resettlement funds to North Korean refugees. All the money we raise goes to support  the underground shelters that run along the Chinese and North Korean border as well as other Southeast Asian countries that house North Korean refugees.

For more infomation see: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Liberty-in-North-Korea-UC-Berkeley-Rescue-Team/642353665799593

Organization.Name: Main Stacks Dance Team
Organization.Summary: Founded in 2008 by then Cal students May Matsuo and Vivian Peng, Main Stacks was meant to provide the growing Berkeley dance community with an opportunity to dance competitively. Now, the team consists of about 40 UC Berkeley students, alumni, & friends!
Organization.Description: Founded in 2008 by May Matsuo and Vivian Peng, Main Stacks is UC Berkeley's premier competitive hip hop dance team. As hosts of the Prelude Norcal Urban Dance Competition, Main Stacks is comprised of dancers from various disciplines who are not only committed to their individual development-- but also dedicated to the growth of Main Stacks as an organization and the bay area dance community at large. It is through dance that we find the power to pursue our passions and it is through dance that members of Main Stacks have found a positive outlet to build lifelong friendships that have become family, and truly, a legacy to live on and share with the world.

Organization.Name: Mixed Student Union
Organization.Summary: Mixed Student Union (MSU) is the only student organization on the UC Berkeley campus devoted to the mixed race, multiethnic/multicultural, and transracial adoptee community.
Organization.Description: Mixed Student Union (MSU) is the only student organization on the UC Berkeley campus devoted to the mixed race, multiethnic/multicultural, and transracial adoptee community. MSU provides a fun, safe, and comfortable environment for people of mixed heritage or those who are interested.

Organization.Name: Movement, The
Organization.Summary: The Movement is UC Berkeley's premiere dance groups featuring different styles of hip-hop, jazz, and swing. With over 100 members, The Movement maintains a large but close family environment that is supportive to each member and our passions for dance.
Organization.Description:
Caroline Kim and Trisha Mitra founded the Movement in fall of 1999. They began with a vision of bringing together a diverse group of people sharing a passion to dance. Beginning with only 20 members, the group has expanded to over 100 members introducing different styles of hip-hop, jazz, and swing to the UC Berkeley campus.

Making their debut on Upper Sproul, the Movement continued to perform on Lower Sproul, cultural diversity fairs, various student productions on campus, the YWCA, and showscases at the Julia Morgan Theater. The Movement's continued success may account for why both Movement's Fall and Spring Showcases have sold out for the past three years!

Yet even as the group continues to grow, The Movement still works toward maintaining a close, family environment that is supportive to each member.

Organization.Name: Music Connection, The
Organization.Summary: The Music Connection (TMC), in collaboration with the Berkeley Unified School District, aims to provide free, supplemental music tutoring for young musicians through after-school and in-class tutoring in both individual and group settings.
Organization.Description: The Music Connection (TMC), in collaboration with the Berkeley Unified School District, aims to provide free, supplemental music tutoring for young musicians through after-school and in-class tutoring in both individual and group settings. By doing so, TMC will provide young students with a strong foundation in music, which will help them to develop cooperation and self-confidence.

Organization.Name: Muslim Student Association
Organization.Summary: Provide for the needs of the Muslim community and promote awareness to the UCB community about Muslim issues

Organization.Name: Nikkei Student Union
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union is the only Japanese-American (JA) interest org. on campus. We incorporate our JA heritage in social/community events like our Culture Show in the Fall. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join! Everyone is welcome~
Organization.Description:
UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union, founded in the spring of 2002, is the up and coming Japanese-American interest organization on campus. We are a one of a kind organization melding our interests in our Japanese American heritage with social and community events. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join!

We put on events such as our annual Culture Show , the Day of Remembrance, and volunteer opportunities at the SF Cherry Blossom Festival in Jtown. We also have joint socials with different student groups and play IM sports. Whether you are interested in getting involved in the JA community, looking to make friends, or want to play sports, we offer a variety of options for you. So feel free to check out our club.

Organization.Name: Objectivist Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: A group discussing the philosophy of Ayn Rand, also known as Objectivism
Organization.Description: A group discussing the philosophy of Ayn Rand, also known as Objectivism

Organization.Name: Omicron Delta Epsilon Economics Honors Society
Organization.Summary: The objectives of Omicron Delta Epsilon are recognition of scholastic attainment and the honoring of outstanding achievements in economics as well as the establishment of closer ties between students and faculty within Berkeley's economics department.
Organization.Description:
Currently, Omicron Delta Epsilon has 669 chapters located in the United States, Canada, Australia, the United Kingdom, Mexico, Puerto Rico, South Africa, Egypt, France, and United Arab Emirates. With such a broad, international base, chapter activities vary widely, ranging from invited speakers, group discussions, dinners, meetings, etc., to special projects such as review sessions and tutoring for students in economics. Omicron Delta Epsilon plays a prominent role in the annual Honors Day celebrations at many colleges and universitie

Omicron Delta Epsilon is one of the world's largest academic honor societies. The objectives of Omicron Delta Epsilon are recognition of scholastic attainment and the honoring of outstanding achievements in economics; the establishment of closer ties between students and faculty in economics within colleges and universities, and among colleges and universities; the publication of its official journal, The American Economist , and sponsoring of panels at professional meetings as well as the Irving Fisher and Frank W. Taussig competitions.

 

SOURCE: http://www.omicrondeltaepsilon.org/aboutus.html

Organization.Name: Outstanding Student Recognition Program
Organization.Summary: TBD
Organization.ParentName: ASUC - Office of the Executive Vice President

Organization.Name: Pakistani Student Association
Organization.Summary: To promote cultural awareness, education, ethnic diversity, and deconstruct myths and stereotypes pertaining to Pakistani peoplehood.

Organization.Name: Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinos
Organization.Summary: A collaborative community that focuses on pre-professional development and prepares students to take advantage of networks,resources,and opportunities.
Organization.Description:
The Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinos, also known as P4, is an organization dedicated to the advancement of Pilipino students in law and business. This is a mission that becomes ever so clear with the increasing economic and legal challenges that face our growing Pilipino Community. Our organization strives to create strong leaders that are capable of encountering these obstacles and organizing our communities for more political, legal, and economic freedom.

P4 holds various events that train students, giving them the experience and education necessary to pursue their career-oriented goals (i.e. community service, workshops, panels, internships, and mentorships). We also strive to develop a community and build a network that our members can benefit from for years to come. Here are some examples of our programming: 

· Professional workshops that assist and guide students in their preparation for interviews, resumes, internships, and applications, including Haas application and law school application workshops
· Community service projects that include, but are not limited to, legal clinics, tax aid assistance, and an annual charity golf tournament
· Career panels that give members an opportunity to dialogue with professionals who can share their knowledge and experience
· Regular socials that give our members the chance to network and bond with the entire group!

 P4 mission statement


.:To serve as a support group for those interested in the fields of business and law

.:To build a community and a network of pre-professionals and use each as resources

.:To aid in the advancement of students to graduate and professional programs, including the MBA and law school to diversify these fields

.:To encourage career paths in all sectors – private, public, and non-profit – while working towards social justice

All Majors, Ethnicities welcome

Because of the extent of the network depends decisively on our diversity, we, a partnership of unique individuals who share a common interest, welcome all majors and all ethnicities interested in the fields of business and law.

Organization.Name: Phi Alpha Theta
Organization.Summary: Phi Alpha Theta, Chi Chapter, is an undergraduate honor society which facilitates a wide range of activities every year designed to give history students the opportunity to better get to know one another, their graduate students, and their faculty.
Organization.Description: Phi Alpha Theta, Chi Chapter, is an undergraduate honor society which facilitates a wide range of activities every year designed to give history students the opportunity to better get to know one another, their graduate students, and their faculty on campus. Throughout the year, we sponsor events ranging from the intellectual to the purely social, including a stimulating lecture series, faculty-student dinners, and the History 101 undergraduate thesis colloquium at the end of every spring.

Organization.Name: Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity
Organization.Summary: The goal of Phi Sigma Pi is to promote a tripod of three ideals: Scholarship, Leadership, and Fellowship. Phi Sigma Pi is co-educational, open to all majors, and requires a minimum cumulative college GPA of 3.0.
Organization.Description:
Phi Sigma Pi is a Co-Ed National Honor Fraternity founded on February 14, 1916. Currently, there are chapters chartered throughout the Mid-West and East Coast, as well several new chapters on the West Coast. The Delta Omega Chapter of Phi Sigma Pi, is the only honor fraternity at the University of California, Berkeley. Delta Omega received its charter on April 13, 2002.

We are one-third honor society, one-third service organization and one-third social fraternity; we seek to incorporate the best and most beneficial aspects of all of these types of organizations into its own program. By balancing this tripod of organizations, our members achieve success as scholars and professionals.

Organization.Name: Pi Tau Sigma
Organization.Summary: Pi Tau Sigma is the national Mechanical Engineering Honors Society. We pride ourselves in connecting our members with faculty, industrial contacts, and other ME students as well as helping out in the community, all the while having fun.
Organization.Description: Pi Tau Sigma is the national Mechanical Engineering Honors Society. We pride ourselves in connecting our members with faculty, industrial contacts, and other ME students as well as helping out in the community, all the while having fun.

Organization.Name: Pilipino American Alliance
Organization.Summary: Purpose: In the ongoing attempt to serve & interact with the Pilipino community, PAA stands to promote a network of social support through the encouragement of political struggle, academic excellence, and cultural awareness while celebrating
Organization.Description: Purpose: In the ongoing attempt to serve & interact with the Pilipino community, PAA stands to promote a network of social support through the encouragement of political struggle, academic excellence, and cultural awareness while celebrating cultural diversit

Organization.Name: Pilipino Association for Health Careers
Organization.Summary: The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started through a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues in and around the Pilipino
Organization.Description:
The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started through a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues in and around the Pilipino community, as well as extended communities. We develop a structure of dedicated students to integrate their knowledge, experience, and skills to seek information on various health issues and careers. PAHC provides information and services to aid the Pilipino community especially and, in addition, to all who are health conscious both academically and individually.

 

Mission: To serve as a support group for those who are interested in health careers and to educate the community of health-related issues relative to Pilipinos and their extended communities.

Organization.Name: Pilipino Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers
Organization.Summary: Established in 1988, the Pilipino Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for social interaction, cultural understanding,
Organization.Description: Established in 1988, the Pilipino Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for social interaction, cultural understanding, professional guidance, and acamedic support.

Organization.Name: PreDental Society
Organization.Summary: The Pre-Dental Society is a registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives
Organization.Description: The Pre-Dental Society is a registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives in education, advocacy, and ethical professional standards.
Organization.AddressStreet1: Pre-dental Society (PDS), c/o ASUC Office of Student Affairs, University of California

Organization.Name: Pre-Pharmacy Informational, Learning and Leadership Society
Organization.Summary: The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. As the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus, PILLS was founded in response to the lack of support and
Organization.Description:
The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. As the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus, PILLS was founded in response to the lack of support and resources available to students interested in pursuing a degree in pharmacy. PILLS was established in order to provide Cal Students with the information and support needed in order to pursue pharmacy as a career path and to apply to pharmacy school. PILLS has created a variety of programs aimed at educating our fellow Cal students about the field of pharmacy. Our goal is to provide information about pharmacy and related fields, as well as opportunities to explore the field, and to guide students through the transition from UC Berkeley to pharmacy school.

 

PILLS is not exclusively for pre-pharmacy students. All students regardless of if they are planning to attend pharmacy school or if they are still undecided about the field, are welcome at all events.

Organization.Name: Psi Chi
Organization.Summary: Psi Chi is the International Honors Society in Psychology, founded in 1929 for the purposes of encouraging, stimulating, and maintaining excellence in scholarship, and advancing the science of psychology.
Organization.Description:
Psi Chi is the International Honors Society in Psychology, founded in 1929 for the purposes of encouraging, stimulating, and maintaining excellence in scholarship, and advancing the science of psychology.

Membership is open to graduates and undergraduates who are involved in the psychology program, or a related discipline, and who meet the minimum qualifications. Psi Chi is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies and is an affiliate with the American Psychological Association (APA) and the Association for Psychological Science. Our mission is to nourish and stimulate professional growth through events to augment and enhance the regular curriculum, and to provide practical experience and fellowship through the affiliation with the chapter.

Organization.Name: Public Relations at Cal
Organization.Summary: oin PR@Cal to formulate and carry out PR plans for real clients and develop key marketing skills. PR@Cal provides members with the right experience and contacts to get your foot in the door.

Organization.Summary: Umbrella for management of the Callink Publication Organization tree

Organization.Name: Quiz Bowl Club
Organization.Summary: We promote and encourage participation in academic quiz competitions at Berkeley and other universities. Everyone is welcome to join!

Organization.Name: Regents' and Chancellor's Scholars Association
Organization.Summary: Regents' & Chancellor's Scholars Association
Organization.Description: The Regents' & Chancellor's Scholars Association (RCSA) is an organization geared toward empowering scholars on the Berkeley campus and facilitating both professional development and social opportunities to students on campus.

Organization.Name: Russian Club
Organization.Summary: The Russian Club is organized to inspire exploration and understanding of the Russian and former Soviet culture by the Russian speaking, Russian learning and Russian exploring communities at the UC Berkeley campus. We strive to eliminate cultural
Organization.Description: The Russian Club is organized to inspire exploration and understanding of the Russian and former Soviet culture by the Russian speaking, Russian learning and Russian exploring communities at the UC Berkeley campus. We strive to eliminate cultural misunderstanding and preach peace and friendship among our members as well as the global community.

Organization.Name: Saving Mothers Research Team (SMRT)
Organization.Summary: Saving Mothers Research Team @ Berkeley is an ASUC-sponsored student organization dedicated to raising awareness on global maternal health issues. According to the UNFPA, every minute a mother dies during childbirth, and for every life lost, 20 or more
Organization.Description: Saving Mothers Research Team @ Berkeley is an ASUC-sponsored student organization dedicated to raising awareness on global maternal health issues. According to the UNFPA, every minute a mother dies during childbirth, and for every life lost, 20 or more women experience serious complications which range from chronic infections to disabling injuries such as obstetric fistula. SMRT is currently recruiting members who are interested in such issues and would like to take part in organizing various activities in raising awareness on these issues.

Organization.Name: Sigma Alpha Nu
Organization.Summary: Sigma Alpha Nu is a co-ed pre-law fraternity created to help its members become competitive law school applicants and successful members of the profession.

Organization.Summary: asuc sponsored service groups

Organization.Name: AAVP Grants
Organization.Summary: Fall 2013 Academic Affairs Grants will be available on Sunday 9/8/2013! Click to read more about the 5 grants offered.
Organization.Description:
Fall 2013 AAVP Grant applications are available from 9/8/2013 to 11/24/2013. Below is a summary of each of the 5 offered grants. To apply click on the link below the summary of your respective fund.

Tom Lee, the Coordinator of Grants Department, has his office hour on Tuesdays 12:00 - 1:00 pm at 114C Hearst Gym. Feel free to drop by if you have any question or concern regarding AAVP Grants. 

AAVP Grants Fall 2013

Academic Opportunity Fund (AOF):

The Academic Opportunity Fund awards grants for academic travel that enhances student access to valuable educational experiences beyond the classroom. The program provides opportunities for individuals and student groups to represent and further UC Berkeley's academic prestige and dedication to education. While most ASUC funding is restricted to on-campus activities, the Academic Opportunity Fund subsidizes off-campus academic pursuits, such as professional meetings, research conferences, academic competitions, and independent research.

Click here for more information or to apply for AOF 

 

Educational Enhancement Fund (EEF):

The EEF provides monetary support to DeCal courses and independent student-initiated courses at UC Berkeley. The ASUC Office of Academic Affairs administers the EEF in conjunction with the Program for Democratic Education (DeCal). The objective of this fund is to foster the growth of student-run courses and address the un-met academic needs of the student body. Funding is allocated to applicants based on their proposed classroom curriculum and ability to achieve the EEF goals.

Click here for more information or to apply for EEF

 

Intellectual Community Fund (ICF):

The Intellectual Community Fund provides monetary support to collaborative events planned by and for Cal students. The objective of ICF is to fund programs that aim to foster a unified campus community that is conducive to free intellectual exchange. Through the distribution of small grants, the Intellectual Community Fund promotes joint campus programs that serve the diverse student population of UC Berkeley. Funding is allocated to student groups that cooperatively plan and advertise academic events serving multiple communities of interest.

Click here for more information or to apply for ICF

 

Multicultural Fund (MCF):

The Multicultural Fund provides monetary support to events introducing the campus to a culture. The program provides opportunities for student groups to hold unique and innovative events to increase campus awareness of multicultural issues. The objective of this fund is to build tolerance and appreciation for diversity by broadening students' perspectives. Funding is allocated to student groups that organize and widely advertise cultural events.

Click here for more information or to apply for MCF

 

Public Service Fund (PSF)

The Public Service Fund provides monetary support to increase and facilitate public service efforts targeted towards communities outside of the UC Berkeley campus. The objective of this fund  is to encourage students to partake in philanthropic or humanitarian based projects. The Public Service Fund strives to develop a sense of community awareness and enrich students’ community service experiences. Funding is allocated based on the impact the activities/events have on the targeted communities.

Click here for more information or to apply to PSF

 

If you are still unsure about which grant is best suited for your event, please click here to take a short 20-second survey. 

For general AAVP Grants questions, please email a.acquistapace@berkeley.edu. For specific fund questions, please email the appropriate grant director listed on each fund's profile page. 

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.

Organization.Name: AAVPG - Academic Opportunity Fund
Organization.Summary: The Academic Opportunity Fund awards grants for academic travel that enhances student access to valuable educational experiences beyond the classroom.
Organization.Description:
Welcome to the ACADEMIC OPPORTUNITY FUND (AOF) homepage! 
 
Since all the interview spots have all been filled until the end of Fall Semester, AAVP AOF application submission is now closed for Fall 2013. Thank you for your interest in applying, and we look forward to your application in Spring 2014.

Fall Application Submissions will be open from 9/8/2013 to 11/19/2013.

Please Note: You may only apply for ONE AAVP grant per event and NO funding can be used for purchasing food, beverages, making copies, etc...for a complete list of spending restrictions, please click here and then on Title III Finance By-Laws.

TO APPLY: 

  1. You must first login (top right of screen) with your Calnet ID and Passphrase. Please answer every question as thoroughly and thoughtfully as you can. LINK TO AOF GRANT APPLICATION
  2. After filling out an application, please click here to sign up for a mandatory interview. You must sign-up at least 5 business days in advance. If you want to alter your interview time anytime after signing up, you must create an account. AOF interview slots will be in 20-minute intervals at 114c Hearst Gym on the following days: 

      Wednesdays 1:00-3:00pm

We look forward to reviewing your application! If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to email us at asuc.aof@gmail.com. 

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------

For more information about the Academic Opportunity Fund:

The Academic Opportunity Fund awards grants for academic travel that enhances student access to valuable educational experiences beyond the classroom. The program provides opportunities for individuals and student groups to represent and further UC Berkeley's academic prestige and dedication to education. While most ASUC funding is restricted to on-campus activities, the Academic Opportunity Fund subsidizes off-campus academic pursuits - professional meetings, research conferences, academic competitions, and independent research.

Applications are accepted on a rolling basis by the ASUC Academic Affairs Office. Allocations are generally limited to $500 per event, though this amount may be waived under exceptional circumstances. Since all graduate and professional student fees are directed to the Graduate Assembly, undergraduates will have the highest priority for this fund, though we do encourage all students to apply. Individuals who have not received funding in the past will be given greater consideration. Applicants that have the support and guidance of a UC Berkeley faculty mentor will receive special attention. Awards are contingent upon the availability of current funds and the number of received applications.  Each applicant may not apply for more than one grant for the same event.

The Committee will give the highest priority to proposals that demonstrate:

  • Potential for the advancement of research or the promotion of academic success
  • Full support and guidance of a UC Berkeley faculty mentor (includes optional statement of support)
  • Past history of academic achievement
  • Significant contribution to the student body and its academic development
  • Orientation toward co-curricular, academic, or professional development
  • Thoughtful planning with careful attention to logistical and financial details
  • Efforts to seek alternative funding

Organization.Name: AAVPG - Intellectual Community Fund
Organization.Summary: The Intellectual Community Fund provides monetary support to educational, activist, and awareness events planned by and for Cal students. The objective of the program is to foster a campus community that is conducive to free intellectual exchange.
Organization.Description:
Welcome to the Intellectual Community Fund (ICF) homepage! 

Fall Application Submissions will be open from 9/8/2013 to  11/24/2013. 

Please Note: You may only apply for ONE AAVP grant per event and NO funding can be used for purchasing food, beverages, making copies, etc...for a complete list of spending restrictions, please click here and then on Title III Finance By-Laws.

TO APPLY: 

  1. You must first login (top right of screen) with your Calnet ID and Passphrase. Please answer every question as thoroughly and thoughtfully as you can.  LINK TO ICF GRANT APPLICATION
  2. After filling out an application, please click here to sign up for a mandatory interview. You must sign-up at least 5 business days in advance. If you want to alter your interview time anytime after signing up, you must create an account. ICF interview slots will be in 20-minute intervals at 114c Hearst Gym on the following days: 

      Tuesdays 12:40 - 1:40 pm and Thursdays 12:00 - 1:00 pm

We look forward to reviewing your application! If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to email us at asuc.icf@gmail.com. 

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------

For more information about the Intellectual Community Fund:

The Intellectual Community Fund provides monetary support to educational, activist, and awareness events serving multiple communities of interest planned by and for Cal students. The Intellectual Community fund promotes campus programs that serve the diverse student population of UC Berkeley and are conducive to free intellectual exchange.

Allocations are limited to $500 per application for undergraduates and $250 per application for graduate students.  Undergraduates and new applicants have priority for this fund, but we encourage all students to apply. Awards are contingent upon the availability of current funds and the number of received applications.

The Committee will grant awards to proposals that demonstrate:

  • Extensive advertisement and high expected turn-out.
  • Attempt to present a balanced educational perspective.
  • Orientation toward co-curricular, academic, or professional development.
  • Innovative efforts to address and serve the unmet academic needs of the student population.
  • Collaboration with multiple campus and community groups.
  • Involvement of a considerable number of UC Berkeley students.
  • Thoughtful planning with careful attention to logistical and financial details.
  • Efforts to seek alternative funding.
  • Includes statement of support from a faculty mentor or student group adviser (optional)

 

Please keep in mind that, due to various reasons, there is no guarantee that an application will be awarded funding or the full amount requested. Please send an email to asuc.icf@gmail.com if you have any questions.

Organization.Name: AAVPG - Multicultural Fund
Organization.Summary: The Multicultural Fund provides monetary support to events introducing the campus to a culture. The program provides opportunities for student groups to hold unique and innovative events to increase campus awareness of multicultural issues.
Organization.Description:
Welcome to the Multicultural Fund (MCF) homepage! 

Fall Application Submissions will be open from 09/08/2013 to 11/24/2013.              

Please Note: You may only apply for ONE AAVP grant per event and NO funding can be used for purchasing food, beverages, publicity, making copies, etc...for a complete list of spending restrictions, please click here and then on Title III Finance By-Laws.

TO APPLY: 

  1. You must first login (top right of screen) with your Calnet ID and Passphrase. Please answer every question as thoroughly and thoughtfully as you can. LINK TO MCF GRANT APPLICATION
  2. After filling out an application, please click here to sign up for a mandatory interview. You must sign-up at least 5 business days in advance. If you want to alter your interview time anytime after signing up, you must create an account. MCF interview slots will in 20-minute intervals at 114c Hearst Gym on the following days: 

      Monday: 9:30am ~ 10:30am, Friday: 10:30am ~ 11:30am

We look forward to reviewing your application! If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to email us at asuc.mcf@gmail.com. 

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------

For more information about the Multicultural Fund:

The Multicultural Fund provides monetary support to events introducing the campus to a culture.  The program provides opportunities for student groups to hold unique and innovative events to increase campus awareness of multicultural issues. The objective of the program is to build tolerance and appreciation for diversity by broadening students’ perspectives.  Funding is allocated to student groups that organize and widely advertise cultural events.

Applications are accepted on a rolling basis by the ASUC Academic Affairs Office. All registered individuals and student groups are encouraged to apply for a grant up to $500 per event. The Committee may waive this limit under compelling circumstances. Since all graduate and professional student fees are directed to the Graduate Assembly, undergraduates will have the highest priority for this fund, though we do encourage all students to apply. Applicants who have not received funding in the past will be given greater consideration. Awards are contingent upon the availability of current funds and the number of received applications.

 The Committee will give the highest priority to proposals that demonstrate:

- Creative and innovative approach to educate Cal students
- Extensive, campus-wide marketing plans
- Measures to prevent exclusion and alienation of any community
- Sharing of personal cultural experiences and knowledge
- Attempt to present a broad view of the culture
- Thoughtful planning with careful attention to logistical and details
- Efforts to seek alternative funding
- Includes statement of support from a faculty mentor or student group advisor (optional)
- Use of the Multicultural Center

Organization.Summary: The Public Service Fund provides monetary support to increase and facilitate public service efforts targeted towards communities outside of the UC Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description:
Welcome to the Public Service Fund (PSF) homepage! 

Fall Application Submissions will be open from 9/8/2013 to 11/24/2013.

Please Note: You may only apply for ONE AAVP grant per event and NO funding can be used for purchasing food, beverages, making copies (for a complete list of spending restrictions, please click here and then read Title III Finance By-Laws).

TO APPLY: 

  1. You must first login (top right of screen) with your Calnet ID and Passphrase. Please answer every question as thoroughly and thoughtfully as you can. LINK TO PSF GRANT APPLICATION
  2. After filling out an application, please click here to sign up for a mandatory interview. You must sign-up at least 5 business days in advance. If you want to alter your interview time anytime after signing up, you must create an account. PSF interview slots will be in 20-minute intervals at 114c Hearst Gym on the following days: 

      Mondays 10:30am-11:30am and Thursdays 9:30am-10:30am

We look forward to reviewing your application! If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to email us at asuc.psf@gmail.com. 

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------

For more information about the Public Service Fund:

The Public Service Fund provides monetary support to increase and facilitate public service efforts targeted towards communities outside of the UC Berkeley campus. The objective of the program is to encourage students to partake in philanthropic or humanitarian based projects. The Public Service Fund strives to develop a sense of community awareness and enrich students’ community service experiences. Funding is allocated based on the impact the activities/events have on the targeted communities.

   Allocations are limited to $500 per application for undergraduates and $250 per application for graduate students. Also the soft cap for travel fee is $175 per application.   

    Graduate and professional students should also contact the Graduate Assembly for grants specifically tailored to them. Individuals who have not received funding in the past will be given greater consideration.  Applicants that have the support and guidance of a UC Berkeley faculty mentor will receive special attention.  It is suggested that a letter of recommendation be attached, but it is not required. Awards are contingent upon the availability of current funds and the number of received applications.

 IMPORTANT NOTES: Limit is just a limit. This does not mean that you are likely to get $500 for just applying. Any ambiguity in the correlation between the proposed budget and amount requested will DIRECTLY impact the decision made by the allocation committee. Please try to be as SPECIFIC AND REASONABLE as possible with the budget and the amount requested.

***Please keep in mind that even though you may qualify for our specific grant, this does not guarantee an award. Should you have further questions, please feel free to contact us.

Please be aware: Awards depend on the volume of applicants and budget restrictions for the EEF Fund.  Even though you may qualify, you are not guaranteed to be awarded funds! Please contact us with any questions!

**Please do not request to join organization. The invitation is for those whose applications are approved. The Grants Directors will be inviting you if that happens.
