For more information about the Educational Enhancement Fund:

The Educational Enhancement Fund provides monetary support to DeCal courses and independent student-initiated courses at UC Berkeley. The objective of the program is to increase diversity and address the unmet academic needs of the student body. Funding is allocated to applicants based on their proposed classroom curriculum and ability to achieve the EEF goals.

The committee will give the highest priority to proposals that demonstrate ability to achieve the EEF goals:

  • Fulfill an academic need of the student body
  • Improve the quality of instruction and learning
  • Create sustainable learning environment that is applicable to a wide audience
  • Exhibit and foster continued devotion and passion by the applicant/instructor
  • Demonstrate efforts to reduce costs

Student instructors and course-coordinators are allowed to apply for a grant for up to $300. Since all graduate and professional student fees are directed to the Graduate Assembly, undergraduates will have the highest priority for this fund. You can only apply for one ASUC grant per event/class.

Organization.Name: Al-Bayan
Organization.Summary: Al-Bayan is a publication at the University of California, Berkeley whose mission is to offer insight and clarity on issues pertinent to the Muslim community.
Organization.Description: Al-Bayan is a publication at the University of California, Berkeley whose mission is to offer insight and clarity on issues pertinent to the Muslim community. Al-Bayan in Modern Arabic means "The Clarification" and in Classical Arabic means "Eloquent Speech". This is the essence of the mission of the magazine, to clarify issues pertaining to the Muslim community today in the most eloquent of manners.

Organization.Name: Alternative Breaks Publication Group
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Alternative Breaks Publication Group is to compile, design, print, and distribute Alternative Breaks Portfolios in order to document the meaningful service and reflection that occurs on Alternative Winter and Spring Breaks.
Organization.Description:
Since its founding in 2001, Alternative Breaks has been a service-learning program that offers students opportunities to connect to the greater community through meaningful service, education, and reflection during their academic breaks. Many participants return from their experiences with greater insight on a particular social justice issue and a deeper understanding on what it means to get involved in the community. This year, Alternative Breaks offers ten trips to different locations during the spring break, covering issues such as environmental justice, health care, immigration, and homelessness.

These student-led trips travel to different locations in California and throughout the Western United States to further understanding of the community and to bring knowledge gained on-site back to the Berkeley community. Students not only participate in a week-long service trip, but also a spring DeCal course to further explore various topics revolving around each social justice issue and engage in reflection both pre- and post-trip.

Organization.Name: American Medical Student Association Berkeley's Survival Guide
Organization.Summary: To provide an environment that supports the creative ideas of physicians-in-training. To promote, encourage, and maintain a cohesive relationship with students and campus organizations. To affect change in the medical education process and to facilitate

Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: ASUC Student Initiative Fund/Bears Breaking Boundaries
Organization.Summary: Think. Create. Develop.Have an idea? Need $$$? We have $100,000 to give away!!!The Big Ideas @ Berkeley initiative and the ASUC are teaming up with a variety of research centers and institutions on campus to organize a series of competitions that will
Organization.Description:
Think. Create. Develop.

Have an idea? Need $$$? We have $100,000 to give away!!!

The Big Ideas @ Berkeley initiative and the ASUC are teaming up with a variety of research centers and institutions on campus to organize a series of competitions that will encourage student teams to propose the next generation of research, education, and service activities on the UC Berkeley campus. We currently have roughly ~ $100,000 in cash commitments to support these competitions.

Goals of Bears Breaking Boundaries:

* Provide concrete support (money, advice, other resources) for creative, high-quality student proposals.
* Encourage UC Berkeley students to set ambitious goals for their current and future endeavors.
* Increase the role that UC Berkeley students play in shaping the next generation of research, education, and service activities on the campus.
* Encourage the innovation and fresh thinking that often arises from multidisciplinary student teams.
* Have fun.

Competitions Include:

1. Neglected Diseases
2. Social Entrepreneurship
3. Green Cities
4. The Next X-Prize
5. Information Technology for Society
6. Curricular Innovation
7. Beautify Berkeley
8. Serious Games
9. Science, Technology, and Engineering Policy (STEP)
10. Solar Fuels

*Check out the website to learn more about each of these amazing projects and how you can become involved!

Organization.Name: Berkeley Poetry Review
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Poetry Review (BPR) is the University of California, Berkeley's longest running poetry journal, having been published annually since 1974. It has earned the distinction of being one of the premier student-managed journals in the country.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Poetry Review (BPR) is the University of California, Berkeley's longest running poetry journal, having been published annually since 1974. It has earned the distinction of being one of the premier student-managed journals in the country. Throughout the academic year, our staff works to produce a volume of poetry, with submissions coming from all accross the nation, as well as from students, faculty, and friends of the University. In addition, we wish to promote serious consideration of student creative writing and to foster a welcoming community where poets can hone their craft and receive helpful feedback about their work.

Past BPR issues have debuted the work of poets and writers such as Pablo Neruda, Vladimir Nabokov, John Ashbery, Lyn Hejinian, Brenda Hillman, Robert Hass, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Charles Bukowski, Leslie Scalapino, Alfred Goldbarth, Luis Omar Salinas, Robert Pinsky, C.K. Williams, Billy Collins, Galway Kinnell, Mark Levine, Thom Gunn, Gary Soto, Ishmael Reed, Frederico Garcia Lorca, Victor Hernandez Cruz, Josephine Miles, Leonard Nathan, and many others.

Berkeley Poetry Review is distributed in bookstores and libraries nationwide, as well as online through Amazon and the American Book Exchange.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Political Review, The
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's only non-partisan political magazine.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Political Review is UC Berkeley’s only nonpartisan political quarterly magazine. We publish and distribute the magazine for free four times a year (fall, winter, spring, and summer). Our staff is composed entirely of undergraduate students.

Berkeley Political Review meets every Tuesday at 7 pm, in North Gate Library. To learn more or to join our mailing list, please contact us at politicalreviewberkeley@gmail.com

Organization.Name: Berkeley Review of Education - name not approved
Organization.Summary: Not in rso database, need 4 signatories, approved name, & constitution
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Review of Education (BRE) is a peer-reviewed interdisciplinary journal that engages issues of educational diversity and equity within cognitive, developmental, sociohistorical, linguistic, and cultural contexts. Published online and edited by students from the Graduate School of Education at the University of California, Berkeley, the BRE encourages submissions on research and theory from senior and emerging scholars, practitioners, and policymakers. BRE is an open access journal hosted by the eScholarship initiative of the California Digital Library, and will be published twice yearly.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Science Review
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Science Review is a graduate student volunteer-run magazine that aims to educate the campus community about groundbreaking research at UC Berkeley and to foster discussion of current science policy issues facing the Berkeley
Organization.Description: The Berkeley Science Review is a graduate student volunteer-run magazine that aims to educate the campus community about groundbreaking research at UC Berkeley and to foster discussion of current science policy issues facing the Berkeley community.  We also aim to train scientists and nonscientists to communicate scientific research to the public in a manner that is engaging and accessible to nonspecialist readers.

Organization.Name: bridges Multicultural Resource Center
Organization.Summary: Welcome to bridges Multicultural Resource Center! bridges is a coalition of five student-initiated and student-run Recruitment and Retention Centers (RRCs) and affiliate organizations at the University of California, Berkeley.
Organization.Description: Welcome to bridges Multicultural Resource Center! bridges is a coalition of five student-initiated and student-run Recruitment and Retention Centers (RRCs) and affiliate organizations at the University of California, Berkeley. The bridges coalition is comprised of the Black Recruitment and Retention Center (BRRC), the Native American Recruitment and Retention Center (NARRC), Pilipino Academic Student Services (PASS), the Raza Recruitment and Retention Center (RRRC), and the Asian/Pacific Islander Recruitment and Retention Center (REACH!), and its affiliates the Mixed Student Union (MSU) and the Arab Recruitment and Retention Center (ARRC).

Organization.Name: Cal Berkeley Habitat for Humanity
Organization.Summary: Dedicated to providing affordable housing for low-income families; we also provide other services to under-served populations in the Bay Area. We accomplish this through workdays, fundraisers and events planned by our committees.
Organization.Description: Dedicated to providing affordable housing for low-income families; we also provide other services to under-served populations in the Bay Area. We accomplish this through workdays, fundraisers and events planned by our four committees:Special Events, Outreach & Advocacy, Publicity, and Media. We also run a decal every semester about issues in affordable housing. In addition, every semester we travel either nationally or internationally to build housing and create cross-cultural exchange.
Organization.AddressStreet2: Attn: Cal Berkeley Habitat for Humanity

Organization.Name: Cal Camp
Organization.Summary: Cal Camp has a history that dates back to the 1940s when students of UC Berkeley decided to create an organization that would enable underprivileged kids to be mentored and taught in a fun atmosphere. Thus, Cal Camp members set out to create an
Organization.Description: Cal Camp has a history that dates back to the 1940s when students of UC Berkeley decided to create an organization that would enable underprivileged kids to be mentored and taught in a fun atmosphere. Thus, Cal Camp members set out to create an overnight camp experience where kids from less fortunate backgrounds could learn from college students in a peaceful and natural setting. Since then, Cal Camp has continued to employ men and women of the UC Berkeley campus dedicated to the bettering of children’s lives. Each year Cal Camp selected about 70 to 100 abused and fostered youths, age 7-14, from Alameda and Contra Costa counties for a weeklong overnight camping adventure. The youths play games, participate in team sports and attend seminars on topics pertinent to their daily lives.  Furthermore, Cal Camp is more than fun and games. As Directors, we cannot stress enough about what Cal Camp means to the youth we serve.  Cal Camp is a vehicle to make change in the lives of the youth who attend and will be implemented as such.

Organization.Name: Cal Community Music
Organization.Summary: We are a music service group that helps spread music throughout the community and connect musicians with other musicians to listen, enjoy, and play music of all kinds.
Organization.Description: We are a music service group that helps spread music throughout the community and connect musicians with other musicians to listen, enjoy, and play music of all kinds.

Organization.Name: Cal in Local Government
Organization.Summary: Cal in Local Government (CLG) connects students and community organizations through project based internships in local government agencies in Berkeley, Oakland, and other East Bay locations.
Organization.Description:
Cal in Local Government is a student-managed internship program hosted by the Cal Corps Public Service Center. CLG's mission is to engage and empower students in local communities by enhancing their knowledge about local issues, improving their ability to think creatively and critically about how policy affects local problems, and developing their professional skills.

 

CLG started in 1980 as Cal in Berkeley, a joint venture between the Associated Students of the University of California, the UC Government & Community Relations Office and the City of Berkeley that aimed to connect students with officials in city government. Since its inception, the program has provided hundreds of Cal students with hands-on experience and professional development invaluable to their education at Cal. CLG provides community organizations with energetic, intelligent student interns, while giving students the opportunity to learn about local issues, understand the political process of the local community, learn the necessary skills for working in government, and meet with community stakeholders.

Organization.Name: Cal Queer & Asian
Organization.Summary: Cal Q&A was established to provide a space for safety, support, and empowerment for and to meet the needs of lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, transgender, queer and questioning individuals interested in queer and Asian topics. The intersectionality of being
Organization.Description:
Cal Q&A was established to provide a space for safety, support, and empowerment for and to meet the needs of lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, transgender, queer and questioning individuals interested in queer and Asian topics. The intersectionality of being queer and Asian is the main focus of this organization, but this applies to many aspects of society and American culture.

Also, we reach out to CBOs (community based organizations) and Bay Area campus communities andbuild and strengthen communities with other individuals interested in queer and Asian topics in the greater Bay Area.

We meet every Wednesday from 7:30 to 9pm. Check our tumblr for location details.

Organization.Name: Cal Veterans Group
Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: California Public Interest Research Group
Organization.Summary: Ever since CALPIRG was founded in 1976 as one of the first Public Interest Research Groups in the country, we as students have stood up for the public interest whenever special interests get in the way of positive change.
Organization.Description:
CALPIRG IS non-partican, and WE work on issues that are majoritarian, winning the support of at least 80% of students. 

Some of CALPIRG’s biggest recent accomplishments include banning plastic bags in Alameda County, registering over 8,000 students to vote, advocating for cheaper textbooks, creating a website that allows students to rate their landlords, and educating thousands of kids in the bay area about energy efficiency. 

This year, we are tackling Global Warming with our Million Clean Cars campaign, Reclaiming Democracy by getting money out of politics, banning Fracking and Plastic Bags across California, educating the public about what they can do to cut down their energy bill, and reducing hunger and homelessness in Berkeley.

Organization.Summary:
Camp Kesem Berkeley is a student-run nonprofit organization on the UC Berkeley campus which provides a free week of summer camp for children whose parents have or have had cancer.

Organization.Summary: Week Of Wilderness (WOW) is committed to exposing the youth of the Bay Area to the wonders of the great outdoors. WOW hopes to provide fulfilling experiences for each kid that attends our week.
Organization.Description: Week Of Wilderness (WOW) is committed to exposing the youth of the Bay Area to the wonders of the great outdoors. WOW hopes to provide fulfilling experiences for each kid that attends our week.

Organization.Name: Chican@/ Latin@ Architecture Student Association
Organization.Summary: Our goal is to provide information, guidance, and support to students in the design profession; to increase the number of incoming minorities in the College of Environmental Design; and to better introduce the profession of Latin@ design work.
Organization.Description:
C.A.S.A. is dedicated to providing outreach, support, and a professional network pre- and post graduation for Chican@/Latin@ students at CAL interested in any major in the College of Environmental Design. In addition, C.A.S.A. is committed to working with professional student organizations in the campus community to help raise more community awareness amongst ourselves and the professional realm.

Presently, C.A.S.A. is a well-recognized support group in the College of Environmental Design as well as in the Latino community. Keeping this in mind, C.A.S.A.'s board members are committed to maintain a group ran by the students of the College of Environmental Design for the students, encouraging all students to join, in hopes that C.A.S.A. will become for you what it is to us; great friends, great networking, and great support- a family.

Organization.Name: Chicano(a)s/Latino(a)s in Health Education
Organization.Summary: CHE strives to instill in CAL students the desire and dedication to help the underserved. As part of CHE, members can help develop health fairs & conferences, receive mentorship, attend socials & weekly meetings, and fundraisers. Everyone is welcome!
Organization.Description: CHE is a community of Berkeley Students who are interested in pursuing a career in the health field (Doctors, Nurses, Dentists, Optometrists, Public Health Professionals etc) and who are interested in learning about health issues that affect the latino community. Our goals are to motivate students to pursue a health career, to instill the desire to help the underserved, to provide resources to help them in their journey, to create a friendly and welcoming environment so that members can help and support each other,and to provide health resources to educate the communities of Berkeley and Oakland. We do this by having General meetings where we bring in health professionals, hold informational workshops (health care reform, mental health, diabetes etc), and provide interactive labs. We also have our own Health Screen Team, we organize Medical and Health conferences, plan health fairs, particpate in community service events, hold socials and fundraising events and offer study hours, mentoring from medical students, a 1 Unit de-cal, and the opportunity to Intern with a Board Director to gain leadership skills.

Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Summary: tbd

Organization.Name: Delta Sigma Theta
Organization.Summary: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated is a public service organization based on the principles of sisterhood, scholarship, and service.
Organization.Description: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Incorporated is a public service organization based on the principles of sisterhood, scholarship, and service. It was founded on the campus of  Howard University on January 13, 1913  and chartered on the campus of University of California, Berkeley on February 21, 1921. It is the first historically Black Greek Letter Organization at the University of California, Berkeley, and the first historically Black sorority chartered west of the Rocky mountains. For more than ninety years this public service organization has served this campus, the Bay Area, and the state of California.

Organization.Name: Democratic Education at Cal
Organization.Summary: The DeCal Program (or just DeCal) is a student-run democratic education program at the University of California, Berkeley - here, students create and facilitate their own classes on a variety of (often unorthodox) subjects.
Organization.Description:
The DeCal Program (or just DeCal) is a student-run democratic education program at the University of California, Berkeley - here, students create and facilitate their own classes on a variety of (often unorthodox) subjects.

Each semester we support over 150 courses facilitated by students, for students, on topics ranging from Taiwanese Language to Simpsons and Philosophy. These are accredited Pass / No Pass courses on our campus. To facilitate a course, a student must find a faculty sponsor. For example, a student wishing to facilitate a course on a favorite book can find an English professor to sponsor the course (as English 98/198 on student transcripts.)

Around 3000-4000 UC Berkeley students take DeCals each semester.

What the DeCal Board does:

  • Manage the online course listing / this website.
  • Help facilitators get funding from the ASUC, get publicity, make copies for their course, or simply help them fill out the paperwork.
  • Put on pedagogical workshops, connect people to UC FTR resources, foster an academic dialogue on education.

  • Every member of the DeCal Board holds office hours, at least 2 per week.

 

You can contact anyone on the Board via email or phone:

decalprogram@gmail.com

(510) 642-9127

Organization.Name: Disabled Students' Union
Organization.Summary: The Disabled Students' Union works to promote disability awareness on campus and aims to increase inclusion within greater society. The DSU hosts the annual week of events, Disability Awareness Week on the Cal campus.

Organization.Name: DULCE (Diabetes: Unidos Logaremos Controlar Esta Enfermedad)
Organization.Summary: DULCE: Diabetes Unidos Lograremos Controlar esta Enfermedad aims to increase awareness surrounding diabetes prevention on the Berkeley campus and in the surrounding communities. Our goal is to teach individuals how to manage/prevent diabetes.
Organization.Description: DULCE: Diabetes Unidos Lograremos Controlar esta Enfermedad aims to increase awareness surrounding diabetes prevention on the Berkeley campus and in the surrounding communities. Our goal teach individuals how to manage/prevent the disease through workshops, health fairs, conferences, and the DULCE Decal. Students are exposed to the implications of the disease related to health policy and management. The purpose of this class is also to have students explore personal health and establish goals for improvement in the areas of nutrition and exercise. Professionals (physicians, nutritionist, and professors) present seminars during class to further our knowledge in the areas described. By the end of the semester, students will have the vital knowledge and skills necessary to convey the information to their communities.

Organization.Summary: Community Legal Outreach (CLO) recruits and trains first year law students at Boalt Hall to conduct legal workshops and provide legal services, counseling, and referrals for the benefit of low income individuals in the surrounding community. The
Organization.Description: Community Legal Outreach (CLO) recruits and trains first year law students at Boalt Hall to conduct legal workshops and provide legal services, counseling, and referrals for the benefit of low income individuals in the surrounding community.  The workshops are conducted under the supervision of lawyers from the East Bay Community Law Center.  All of our legal services are completely free.

Organization.Name: FeelGood
Organization.Summary: FeelGood is a non-profit student-run deli working to eradicate hunger with grilled cheese sandwiches. We believe that in OUR lifetime, we can achieve a world free of extreme and chronic hunger. 100% of donations from food sales go to CHOICE Humanitarian.
Organization.Description:
Gourmet Grilled Cheese: Artisan bread, gourmet cheeses, local produce and a pannini press make for a mouth-watering comfort food that is sure to make you smile. The nostalgic simplicity of a grilled cheese is an irrestible invitation to everyone to make a systemic difference. Dedicated to a world that works for all life, students strive to get nutritious ingredients that benefit the earth and community. Chapters get creative with vegan and gluten free options to ensure they are meeting everyone’s dietary needs. Check out some featured menus here!

A Donation: A FeelGood Grilled Cheese comes without a price tag. We believe that the human spirit is fundamentally generous. By asking for a donation, we give everyone the space to manifest generosity by turning lunch into an opportunity to give back. People donate whatever makes them "feel good," expressing their love for humanity and our earth with every penny.

Organization.Name: First Aid Safety Team
Organization.Summary: First Aid Safety Team shall provide first aid relief to individuals participating in campus and community events.

Organization.Name: Gamma Zeta Alpha, Inc.
Organization.Summary: Established in 1992 at the University of California-Berkeley, Gamma Zeta Alpha Fraternity, Inc. is a Latino interest fraternity dedicated to three principles: academic excellence, community service, and brotherhood. We were established nationally in 1987
Organization.Description: Established in 1992 at the University of California, Berkeley (founded nationally in 1987 at Chico State University), Gamma Zeta Alpha Fraternity, Inc. is a Latino interest fraternity dedicated to three principles: Academic Excellence, Community Service, and the maintenance of the Latino culture through Brotherhood. All brothers of this fraternity strongly abide by these values in their everyday lives and demonstrate this strength through performing a number of community building activities. Community service is perhaps one of our largest emphases, as we strive to return a small portion of what our families and upbringings have provided to us in our quest for success. The strong bond that we possess among our 21 chapters statewide makes the brotherhood experience unlike any other Greek organization on campus.

Organization.Name: GIANT - The UC Berkeley Student Filmmaker Organization
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's Official Filmmaking Organization
Organization.Description: A. The organization known as GIANT is a service organization whose primary purpose is providing dedicated production support to the many student filmmakers of UCB. B. As an essential component to providing a valuable service to the students, GIANT helps foster the healthy and necessary growth of production components within the Film Studies curriculum. In doing so, Giant helps to combine the theoretical aspects of film with the technical to promote a creative environment for film production.

Organization.Name: Global Health Brigades at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We are the UC Berkeley Chapter of the largest student-led global health volunteer organization in the world.
Organization.Description: Brigaders learn about current social, economic, and political issues in Latin America and how they are related to the health outcomes there. There is a DeCal course throughout the semester before participants go on a one or two week brigade to Honduras with the aim of providing access to healthcare, clean water, and basic sanitation infrastructure.

Organization.Name: Health and Medical Apprenticeship Program
Organization.Summary: HMAP, an entirely student-run organization, is the umbrella program for three programs that influence over a thousand students every semester: the class Public Health 116 (PH116), the Field Study Internship (FSI), and the Health Service Internship (HSI).
Organization.Description: HMAP was created in 1984 by four UC Berkeley undergraduates with the goal to introduce Berkeley students to ethical issues and philosophical dilemmas related to the fields of health and medicine. The results of their efforts are three subprograms: the class Public Health 116 (PH116), the Field Study Internship (FSI), and the Health Service Internship (HSI).  An entirely student-run organization, HMAP continues to expose students to a broad spectrum of experiences and opportunities, covering many facets of health and medicine while emphasizing participatory learning.

Organization.Summary: Hermanas Unidas reaches out to the Chicana/Latina community and provides resources as well as a network through Academic Workshops/Events, Community Service Events, and Collegial Networking.
Organization.Description: HaU also raises awareness and educates the campus and community at large about Chicana/Latina issues.

Organization.Name: Hispanic Engineers and Scientists
Organization.Summary: Mission: The Hispanic Engineers and Scientists (HES) of the University of California, Berkeley, are determined to increase the number of culturally responsible engineers & scientists who succeed academically, lead professionally, & contribute to society
Organization.Description:
Mission

The Hispanic Engineers and Scientists (HES) of the University of California, Berkeley, are determined to increase the number of culturally responsible engineers and scientists who succeed academically, lead professionally, and passionately contribute to society.

 

History
HES is a student organization established in 1974 bringing together all Latino student engineers and scientists to promote the advancement of education among underrepresented minority students and to create a support system within Berkeley academia. HES is open to all students of the Berkeley campus who share our devotion to the recruitment and retention of Latino students into higher education. Throughout the year HES engages in activities that help both members in our organization and people in our community. The unwavering dedication of our members has made our numerous outreach, recruitment, and retention programs continued successes.

Organization.Description: • The Hmong Student Association at Berkeley (HSAB) is a student-initiated service group with the mission to promote higher education and cultural understanding of the Hmong community. HSAB provides academic and social support to current and prospective students at Berkeley through the implementation of educational discussions, social activities, and outreach services. Established in 2008, HSAB continues to represent a voice for the Hmong student community at University of California, Berkeley.

Organization.Name: La Voz de Berkeley
Organization.Summary:
La Voz de Berkeley strives to voice the opinions, findings, and theories of those underrepresented by mainstream media. We want to address issues that affect our community, other people of color, and traditionally disenfranchised groups.
As
Organization.Description:
La Voz de Berkeley strives to voice the opinions, findings, and theories of those underrepresented by mainstream media. We want to address issues that affect our community, other people of color, and traditionally disenfranchised groups.

 

As Xican@/Latin@ students, we take the responsibility of questioning and challenging unfounded images that permeate mainstream media within and beyond campus. La Voz de Berkeley aims to provide an open space for expression and discussion about the social, cultural, economic, and political forces that affect our lives. ¡La Voz es tu voz!

 

Articles and images featured in our publication cover politics, art, and culture that reflect the diverse opinions of our own writers and artists. To help reach the extended community, we translate several articles that we believe are most relevant to our Spanish-speaking community.

Organization.Name: Liberator
Organization.Summary: To be a journal of the new civil rights and student movement at UC-Berkeley. Articles will focus on assessing the development of the movement and pointing a way forward.

Organization.Name: maganda magazine
Organization.Summary: {m}aganda aims to foster critical dialogue within and across our communities through arts, literature, and education. We come from a heritage of Pilipino/American artists, writers, and cultural historians.

Organization.Name: Net Impact at Berkeley
Organization.ShortName: formerly Students for Responsible Business) (NI SRB
Organization.Summary: Net Impact is an international nonprofit organization with a mission to inspire, educate, and equip individuals to use the power of business to create a more socially and environmentally sustainable world. NIB is the Undergraduate chapter of
Organization.Description:
Net Impact is an international nonprofit organization with a mission to inspire, educate, and equip individuals to use the power of business to create a more socially and environmentally sustainable world.

NIB is the Undergraduate chapter of Net Impact. We are your link to a network of over 30,000 students and professionals, each of whom are interested in making a positive impact on the world. Our goal is to provide members with the real world experience and connections needed to excel and change the world.

We are sponsored by the ASUC, Haas School of Business, and the Center for Responsible Business. In addition, we work closely with other local Net Impact chapters (e.g., MBA at Haas, Professional at San Francisco, and other nearby universities) to provide our members with solid experience.

In short, NIB has four committees: Consulting, Marketing, Finance, and Internal Affairs. Each committee actively trains its associates so that our alumni are well-versed in each field. Our Consulting and Marketing Committees have their own process through which associates learn to strategize and develop successful campaigns. Our Finance Committee manages key relationships with corporations, and conducts on-site visits to learn more about the fast-paced world of finance. In Internal Affairs, associates learn how to plan events of various scales, as well as how to manage organizations. Please open the Committees tab to learn more about each committee.

As a general member, you will be able to attend all of our events, including many that are members-only. These events will prepare you to excel through networking and professional development. In addition, our general members are welcome to attend trainings hosted by any of our four committees.

Organization.Name: Onyx Express
Organization.Summary: The Onyx Express Magazine is staffed by individuals dedicated to building a support system for African American students on the UC Berkeley campus and beyond. Our purpose is to inform the Black community on issues that affect them as African Americans
Organization.Description: The Onyx Express Magazine is staffed by individuals dedicated to building a support system for African American students on the UC Berkeley campus and beyond. Our purpose is to inform the Black community on issues that affect them as African Americans and as members of a larger, global community, by spreading the voices of those who are marginalized and misrepresented in mainstream media. Furthermore, we serve as the vehicle for students of color to educate others about our socioeconomic challenges

Organization.Summary: Perspective Magazine is an outlet for students to celebrate, to discuss, to teach the richness, the depth, the beauty of Iranian culture as it should be done, and for both ourselves, and the community to gain perspectives of our heritage that seem to be
Organization.Description: Perspective Magazine is an outlet for students to celebrate, to discuss, to teach the richness, the depth, the beauty of Iranian culture as it should be done, and for both ourselves, and the community to gain perspectives of our heritage that seem to be getting even more lost lately within the state of our world, our media, and even our own minds. If we don't open a positive dialogue, and encourage others to as well, it has the potential to never exist.

Organization.Summary: The purpose of Student Commuters at Cal is to help commuter students (those not living in UC-sponsored housing) by providing them the support, resources, and a network of commuter students to make the transition to Cal as easy as possible.
Organization.Description: The purpose of Student Commuters at Cal is to help commuter students (those not living in UC-sponsored housing) by providing them the support, resources, and a network of commuter students to make the transition to Cal as easy as possible. We strive to represent the commuter student voice on campus and work to make UC Berkeley a more commuter friendly campus.

Organization.Name: Student Human Resources Association
Organization.Summary: Student Human Resources Association is the only group related to HR. Meet Professor Banks, Haas professor and expert in the field. Learn more about human resources, grow your skills, share your resume, and interact with professionals on a personal level.
Organization.Description:
Student Human Resources Association is an organization on campus that focuses on the professional field of Human Resources. Since there are only two courses on campus that address human resources or industrial psychology, our organization allows students to learn more about the field. 


* We offer opportunities for practical application of networking skills leading up to our networking event in the form of resume workshops, mock interviews, etc.

* Membership with our organization will also get you membership into the Northern California Human Resources Association (NCHRA), which has job boards and HR training for certification among its resources. We also get discounted or free access to some of their conferences, which normally would cost $100+. 

* We hold a semesterly Networking Luncheon where students and professionals are able to network in a more intimate setting than the typical career fair. Each professional receives a resume book with all of the attendees' resumes and many connections resulting in internships or full time employment were made here. 

SHRA is proud to announce our partnership with NCHRA (Northern California Human Resources Association), the second largest HR association in the nation. With an NCHRA-student membership, you will have access to job boards, networking events, seminars, workshops, and an HR West subscription, as well as the opportunity to network with thousands of HR professionals across northern California

Organization.Name: Student Organic Gardening Assoc.
Organization.Summary: SOGA! Student Organic Gardening Association Is a kale-chewing-garden-loving student association that manages the UCB Student Organic Garden on the corner of Walnut and Virginia.
Organization.Description:
SOGA! Student Organic Gardening Association

 Is a kale-chewing-garden-loving student association that manages the UCB Student Organic Garden on the corner of Walnut and Virginia. The association provides information and resources for students interested in organic gardening, horticulture, experimental education and food justice. We sponsor a DeCal class in the Spring which teaches college students basic organic garden skills and inspires students to become intimately engaged with their food from soil to table. Students experience this 8 week class with the expectation to learn how to plan, plant and care for their own garden using organic practices.

Organization.Name: Students for Ailing Mothers and Fathers at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We are a peer-led grief support group for students who have experienced the illness or death of a loved one.
Organization.Description: We are a peer-led grief support group for students who have experienced the illness or death of a loved one.

Organization.Name: Students for Hip Hop
Organization.Summary: We celebrate and promote the 4 elements of hip-hop culture on campus and in the surrounding community as an art form and means of activism. We put on the annual Hip-hop in the Park, as well as smaller concerts, music swaps, djing workshops, etc.
Organization.Description: Students for Hip hop is a group of students and community members who celebrate hip-hop culture and share it with others through concerts, music swaps, djing workshops, documentary showings, and more. We contact local and sometimes regional artists and bring them out to perform at Cal.  Our annual event Hip-hop in the Park celebrates the four elements with a main stage with MCs and djs, a side stage with bboys and bgirls, and graffiti art on the other side of the main stage. We welcome community members at our events and meetings as well as students.

Organization.Name: Students for Justice in Palestine
Organization.Summary: We are a diverse group of students, faculty, staff, and community members at UC Berkeley, organized to promote justice, human rights, liberation and self-determination for the Palestinian people.
Organization.Description:
We are a group of students, faculty, and community members working together at the University of California, Berkeley, in solidarity with the struggle of the indigenous Palestinian people against apartheid and occupation. In addition to organizing protests, memorials, and other events that attempt to visualize the Palestinian struggle, we organize frequent educational events that give a voice to the Palestinian narrative as well as highlight the plight of the Palestinian people under Israeli aggression.﻿

We are often asked what our vision for the future of Palestine and Israel is, as if we are entitled to decide on the precise shape and form of this future on behalf of those thousands of miles away. This question is a misunderstanding of our organization. We work in solidarity with, not on behalf of, Palestinians and Israelis who together continue to struggle against the apartheid regime that has consolidated itself in the West Bank, Gaza, Jerusalem, and 1967 Israel. It is not within our rights, then, to decide ourselves what that solution is, only to amplify those voices working against injustice. We like to say, though, that the future we would like to see in Palestine and Israel, we very much see already in ourselves: a diverse group of all backgrounds, Arab, Jewish, Palestinian, Israeli, and many others, coming together not based on our religious or ethnic identities, but rather in our agreement that we are working for a just cause.﻿

Organization.Name: Students for Sensible Drug Policy
Organization.Summary: SSDP mobilizes and empowers young people to participate in the political process, pushing for sensible policies to achieve a safer and more just future, while fighting back against counterproductive Drug War policies

Organization.Name: Taiwanese American Student Association
Organization.Summary: To promote Taiwanese culture and identity to Berkeley and build a strong community of Taiwanese Americans through social, cultural, community service, and professional networking events.

Organization.Name: Taiwanese Student Association
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this non-profit organization is to promote general understanding of Taiwanese culture within the student body. Through our events we strive to provide an environment where students from different ethnic backgrounds can come together to
Organization.Description: The purpose of this non-profit organization is to promote general understanding of Taiwanese culture within the student body. Through our events we strive to provide an environment where students from different ethnic backgrounds can come together to appreciate and learn from each other. There are many Taiwanese students in U.C. Berkeley who have just come to the U.S., and it is also one of our main objectives to provide guidance and resources for these students to adapt well to college life here.

Organization.Name: Tennis at Cal
Organization.Summary: Our purpose is to provide opportunities for UC Berkeley members to compete and socialize with students and faculty who have an interest in tennis at the Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description:
Our purpose is to provide opportunities for UC Berkeley members to compete and socialize with students and faculty who have an interest in tennis at the Berkeley campus. TAC is a social and casual club that encourages members to not only better their tennis game but to meet others that share the same passion for tennis. TAC provides its members with experiences, lessons, and memories that will last a lifetime!

We are an intra-mural club comprised of players of all skill levels. During practices, members are asked to join their respective Division and play with those of similar skill levels. Placement into a division is generally decided by the player's own discretion, but the officers can assist members find the right group to be in. Divisions are comprised from D1 (experienced) to D4 (beginner). We welcome all players, whether they have not played tennis before, or they have played for several years and competed in tournaments. 

Practices and drill sessions are always optional. Join us whenever you can!

We also hold tournaments and socials outside of our regular practice times. Tournaments are typically held three times a semester (1 Singles, 1 Doubles, and 1 World Team Tennis tournament). All members of TAC are welcome to participate! Socials include: rock climbing, boba socials, Six Flags, bowling, and more! These will be announced on our webpage and at practices a few weeks before the the event. 

 

Fall 2013 Practice Schedule (starting on 9/16):

Mondays, 7-9 p.m.
Thursdays, 5-7 p.m.
Saturdays, 2-4 p.m. / 4-5 p.m. Drills Session (D3/D4 Only) 
 
Come early to warm-up! 

All practices will be held at Hearst Tennis Courts unless otherwise announced.

Organization.Name: Teo Chew Association
Organization.Summary: Established in 2006, UC Berkeley TCA works to advocate for the preservation of Teo Chew and Chinese culture and to promote the general welfare of the Teo Chew community at Berkeley and abroad.
Organization.Description:
About UCB TCA
UC Berkeley Teo Chew Association started as a Facebook group, but it eventually grew to something much more. When some people realized that were actually quite a number of Teo Chew people in Berkeley, they decided that there should be a actual Teo Chew club on campus. Thus, in the fall semester of 2006, TCA was born. Our goal is to advocate for the preservation of Teo-Chew and Chinese culture and for the general welfare of the Teo-Chew community.

We are a club dedicated to preserving our Teo-Chew culture and building a strong community here at Cal. Throughout each semester, we hold exciting social and informative cultural events where students can meet other fellow Teo Chew students on campus (and of course, non-Teo Chew as well; we are not limited to only Teo-Chew people!). Our past events include: game nights, Teo-Chew cooking nights, Family History projects, and much more!

About Teo Chew People 

We trace our ancestral roots back to the city of Chaozhou in the Shantou (Swatow) region of Chaoshan - in the province of Guangdong. Our language is a derivative of the Min-Nan dialect of Chinese, of which Hokkien and Taiwanese (Fujian-hua) are closely related. We are famous for our powerful kung-fu tea, goochi (chive) gue dumplings, and magnificent vegetable carving.﻿﻿

Organization.Name: Thai Student Association
Organization.Summary: Welcome to the UC Berkeley Thai Student Association (ThaiSA)! We are a social, professional and cultural student organization with the main aim of informing the UC Berkeley community and beyond about Thailand and its exotic culture!
Organization.Description:
Welcome to the UC Berkeley Thai Student Association (ThaiSA)! Founded in 90’s, ThaiSA is a cultural, professional, and social student organization at UC Berkeley. ThaiSA members are united by a common interest in Thailand, whether through a cultural, academic, professional and/or social perspective. As such, ThaiSA’s activities range from regular educational, social and cultural events aimed at the campus community to professional networking events with UC Berkeley alumni in Thailand. ThaiSA also seeks to maintain cooperative ties with other cultural organizations on campus as well as other Thai student organizations and Thai communities across the United States of America. ThaiSA is open to everyone and we would love to hear from you and see you at our events!

Mission

As a cultural and professional club, our purposes and goals are:

To unite and act as an active resource for people who are interested in Thailand as well as Thai culture and affairs.
To encourage closer ties and greater exchanges between the campus community and Thailand.
To provide forums of free discussion and promote greater understanding about the cultural, political, and social affairs of Thailand among the campus and local communities.
To maintain an active professional network between current members and UC Berkeley alumni in Thailand.
To establish positive connections between ThaiSA and other cultural/professional organizations in the Berkeley campus.
To establish cooperative relationships with other Thai organizations across the United States, notably by maintaining intercollegiate ties with other Thai student organizations.
To participate in community service and/or fundraising that will help communities around the Bay Area and in Thailand.
To act as a support network for students from Thailand in their transition from Thailand to Berkeley and the United States.

Organization.Summary: This is a well-rounded student publication which prifdes itself in giving students of all majors and backgrounds a chance to get their voice heard. Our essential question is "What does the modern media lack in coverage." In other words, whatever
Organization.Description: This is a well-rounded student publication which prifdes itself in giving students of all majors and backgrounds a chance to get their voice heard.  Our essential question is "What does the modern media lack in coverage." In other words, whatever students feel like sharing with their fellow readers, we willl accept and publish.

Organization.Name: Theatre Rice - Modern Asian-American Theater
Organization.Summary: Theatre Rice, the first modern Asian American theater group at the University of California, Berkeley, was started in the fall of 1998. Since its conception, Theatre Rice has grown considerably, both artistically and physically. In the past several
Organization.Description:
Theatre Rice, the first modern Asian American theater group at the University of California, Berkeley, was started in the fall of 1998. Since its conception, Theatre Rice has grown considerably, both artistically and physically. In the past several years, the group has begun to attract an increasingly larger audience and a greater membership. Theatre Rice has emerged from a relatively unknown group to a group whose performances have become an anticipated community event.

 

Theatre Rice was conceived to provide people (particularly, but not exclusively, Asian American) who might not otherwise have a chance to participate in theatrical arts the opportunity to act, write, sing, direct, dance, and learn behind-the-stage techniques. What sets Theatre Rice apart from other dramatic groups is its open and unintimidating environment, and the basic ethic that effort and commitment are more important than experience or innate talent. Because the group is comprised of both seasoned and fledgling actors, there exists a healthy dynamic within which members can share their experiences and learn from each other.

 

The Asian American aspect of Theatre Rice is important because it is a step towards combating the misrepresentation, as well as the lack of representation, of the Asian American community in popular culture. By its mere existence, Theatre Rice is fulfilling its purpose of putting forth ideas that stem from the minds of Asian Americans, and therefore addressing the Asian American population as well as the greater community within Berkeley and beyond.

Organization.Name: Tunisian Student Club
Organization.Summary: The purpose of TSC is to promote fellowship among Tunisian students at the University of California at Berkeley and conduct activities on campus to raise awareness about the Tunisian culture.

Organization.Name: UC Berkeley Model United Nations
Organization.Summary: U.C. Berkeley Model United Nations is a club in which college students debate contemporary and historical topics relevant to international relations. Members travel to various international and domestic conferences and we also host a conference in SF.
Organization.Description: U.C. Berkeley Model United Nations is a club that allows college students to participate in debate and discourse on contemporary and historical topics relevant to international relations. In addition to traveling to various international and domestic conferences hosted by other universities, we put on our own conference in San Francisco. In addition, we hold numerous other events, including smaller regional conferences, as well as social events and club meetings that help build a unique network of individuals.

Organization.Summary: The University of California Rally Committee is charged with the protection and guardianship of the Spirit and Traditions of UC Berkeley. Founded in 1901, the Rally Committee maintains over 100 years of tradition and promotes service to the University.
Organization.Description:
The University of California Rally Committee is charged with the protection and guardianship of the Spirit and Traditions of University of California. Founded in 1901, the Rally Committee maintains over 100 years of tradition with events like Charter Day and the Big Game Bonfire Rally, while supporting Cal's student athletes and promoting service to the University.

If you are full of the Spirit of California, this is the organization for you!

Go Bears!

Organization.Description: Undergraduate Economics Association is a club for undergraduates at Cal who are Economics majors, considering enlisting in the major, or just interested in economics. Organization.Name: Undergraduate Financial Assn/Undergraduate Management Consulting Group
Undergraduate Marketing Association
Organization.Summary: The Undergraduate Marketing Association at UC Berkeley is dedicated to providing a bridge between the students and the marketing world. We provide our members with hands on experience in consulting, design, and event planning.
Organization.Description:
The Undergraduate Marketing Association at the University of California, Berkeley is a Haas sponsored organization dedicated to providing a bridge between students and the marketing and consulting world. We provide various opportunities in the marketing field and help our members reach both academic and professional goals. Our members are immersed in hands-on experience in consulting, design, creative strategy, and event planning. In addition, our members are able to interact and network with professionals through our external speaker series, developing their knowledge in marketing and consulting.

UMA is unique because our members consult and work with Bay Area companies and organizations through a variety of semester-long projects. UMA is divided into three committees – Strategy Consulting, Design Consulting, and Events Consulting. Each committee consists of six-eight members, led by two experienced Project Managers or Directors.

Organization.Name: Undergraduate Political Science Association
Organization.Summary: The Undergraduate Political Science Association (UPSA) is a non-partisan and outreach organization of the political science department that serves all students interested in the study of politics. Our mission is to enhance the educational experience of
Organization.Description: The Undergraduate Political Science Association (UPSA) is a non-partisan and outreach organization of the political science department that serves all students interested in the study of politics. Our mission is to enhance the educational experience of Berkeley students while making the campus community more aware of our local, national, and international political landscape.

Organization.Description: The purposes of this organization are: to increase awareness of the real estate industry; to provide a network for students interested in the real estate industry; to function as a representative organization of the undergraduate student body interested in real estate at the University of California at Berkeley campus.

Organization.Summary: USEU seeks to empower the Salvadoran student community by: developing an awareness of cultural, political, and economic issues that directly affect the Salvadoran community in El Salvador and the U.S. email:useuberkeley@gmail.com
Organization.Description:
We are USEU- La Union Salvadoreña de Estudiantes Universitarios (Salvadoran University Student Organization) here at UC Berkeley.

We are part of a larger USEU statewide coalition was first founded in CSULA in 2007 and now has chapters in UCLA, CSULA, LBCC, UCLA, UCSB, USF, SF State, Cal Poly Pomona, CSUN, UCSC, East Los Angeles College.

For more information about USEU, visit www.useuyouth.org

Organization.Name: Vietnamese Student Association
Organization.Summary: The Cal Vietnamese Student Association strives to empower its members to become leaders of their communities and preserve the history and heritage of the Vietnamese culture for future generations. We welcome any and all to come join our family!
Organization.Description:
Our Founding

Longing for their homeland, a group of immigrant Vietnamese students at UC Berkeley joined forces and created the Vietnamese Student Association in 1979.

Their goal was to create a space in which they could connect through their similar backgrounds and share their culture with each other. To further their purpose, they looked to educate others about Vietnamese culture, history, and heritage.

Through their efforts they built a family away from home for Vietnamese and Vietnamese American students, a community that continues to grow.

Cal VSA Today

Today, Cal VSA is still a student organization that embraces our Vietnamese and Vietnamese American roots and culture. Though our members are a part of a new generation, we recognize and commemorate the experiences that our parents and relatives have had while also striving to identify and to understand the emerging narratives and current issues in our community.

Cal VSA, alongside our goals, has evolved as an organization but we are still driven by the same principles that our founders embraced. These principles can be summed up by our three pillars:

  • Academics | We recognize and embrace the opportunities that we have been given and we endeavor to extend the same opportunities to others in our community.
  • Community | We recognize the diverse contemporary issues facing our community and we attempt to understand them, to promote awareness about them, and to address them.
  • Culture | We recognize that we have a unique Vietnamese heritage and tradition and we aim to preserve and to learn more about our culture.

Though we are an organization that focuses on the Vietnamese American experience, we are honored to be able to count many members of non-Vietnamese heritage as part of our family. We welcome any and all students to come see what Cal VSA has to offer!

Organization.Name: Clio's Scroll
Organization.Summary: Clio's Scroll is an ASUC-sponsored journal produced by UC Berkeley students. It aims to provide undergraduates with the opportunity to publish historical works and to train staff members in the editorial process.
Organization.Description: Clio's Scroll, the Berkeley Undergraduate History Journal, is an ASUC-sponsored journal produced by UC Berkeley students. It aims to provide undergraduates with the opportunity to publish historical works and to train staff members in the editorial process of an academic journal. It is published each semester with the generous support of the Townsend Center for the Humanities, the Associated Students of the University of California, the UC Berkeley Department of History, and the Office of Student Life. Clio’s Scroll is not an official publication of the Associated Students of the University of California or of the University of California, Berkeley. The views expressed in Clio's Scroll are the views of the writers and not necessarily the views of the ASUC or the views of UC Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children
Organization.Summary: As the FIMRC chapter in Berkeley, we strive to accomplish our global health mission by fundraising for medical projects, coordinating volunteer travel to our clinic sites, raising public health awareness, and providing service in our direct community.
Organization.Description:
The Foundation for the International Medical Relief of Children (FIMRC) is dedicated to improving the lives of children worldwide by providing medical support and health education.

As its primary mission, FIMRC establishes and maintains pediatric medical clinics in underserved regions. This includes staffing the clinic with local physicians and nurses; hosting international volunteers at its clinic sites; and raising funds for medical equipment and supplies. FIMRC also supports existing medical facilities with funding and volunteer staffing.

FIMRC at Berkeley strives to accomplish those goals in a way that pertains to us, that is, by:

  1. Fundraising for the construction of pediatric clinics in areas currently lacking a reliable source for healthcare.
  2. Directly influence the health of children by encouraging and supporting individuals and groups who desire to travel to medically underserved areas of the world.
  3. Encourage future health leaders to become involved in our purpose by recognizing their achievements.

Organization.Name: GA Rules Officer
Organization.Summary: The Rules Committee shall monitor the internal actions of the Graduate Assembly to ensure that they comply with the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda of Understanding between the Graduate Assembly and other entities. It generally shall include
Organization.Description: The Rules Committee shall monitor the internal actions of the Graduate Assembly to ensure that they comply with the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda of Understanding between the Graduate Assembly and other entities. It generally shall include proposing changes to the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda as well as deciding disputes regarding the Charter and these Bylaws. The Rules Committee shall conduct an annual review process of these Bylaws and all Memoranda. The Rules Committee may make recommendations to the Delegate Assembly regarding what corrective and, if necessary, disciplinary action should be taken against members of the Graduate Assembly who, without good cause, knowingly violate the Charter and these Bylaws.

Organization.Name: Global Medical Training at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Global Medical Training is an international, non-profit, and humanitarian organization focused towards addressing the healthcare needs of developing countries in Latin America through providing free medical and dental care services.
Organization.Description: Global Medical Training (GMT) is an organization that is focused entirely around our motto "LEARN BY DOING." It gives students the unique chance to participate in a more "hands-on" diagnoses and treatments of patients in Latin America under the supervision and training given by medical professionals. In the process, students will not only have time to learn more about health related professions for their near future, but also be socially aware and culturally competent in order to aid other medical deprived nations. UC Berkeley students will be given a chance to expand their understanding of medicine as well as health related hardships of living in third world countries whilst increasing awareness of the lack of healthcare in such  countries and providing care, information for the betterment of the nation. GMT services are also not limited to our national partners but are provided to our community as well. We will offer our students the opportunity to volunteer in multiple service events focused towards serving the underprivileged community of Berkeley and beyond.

Organization.Name: Global Water Brigades at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GWB is an international nonprofit organization with global health and sustainable development initiatives in developing countries.
Organization.Description: Our group offers Berkeley students the opportunity to volunteer in developing countries -- our most recent projects have been in Honduras where students worked in rural villages to improve access to clean water by developing a sustainable water infrastructure with community leaders. Many of our students are also Global Poverty and Practice minors and use their volunteer experience with GWB as part of the practice experience required for the minor.

..:: Mien solidarity ::..

Organization.Name: Labor Coach Program
Organization.Summary: The Labor Coach Program works with the Asian Health Services to provide support and translation services for mothers during their labor and deliveries.
Organization.Description: Labor Coaches have the unique opportunity to develop personal relationships with their patients, for whom they are on-call during the last month of the patient's pregnancy. The Labor Coach Program is great for those with a soft spot for babies, multi-lingual skills, and a desire to work closely with the OB-GYN hospital staff. Through this program, Labor Coaches have the potential to make a great impact in reducing the stress and pain of women, as well as share the excitement and immense joy at welcoming a new life to the world.

Organization.Name: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc.
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on Unity, Love, & Respect. To develop strong Leaders who will then provide and practice political, social and cultural activities. To promote Latino Unity through charitable
Organization.Description: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on Unity, Love, & Respect. To develop strong Leaders who will then provide and practice political, social and cultural activities. To promote Latino Unity through charitable and educational programs. To maintain a high standard of learning and serve as a voice for the Universal Woman, all Latino students and disenfranchised communities. Lambda Theta Alpha is the FIRST Latina Sorority created in the Nation as well as the Largest Latina Sorority in existence.

Organization.Name: Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to promote and foster Latina leaders through educational and professional development, relationship building, and community involvement. Our intent is to provide our members exposure to resources for continued growth.
Organization.Description: The purpose of Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. shall be to open the doors of opportunity to the Latinas of our community. Our primary focus is academic excellence and meeting the needs of Latina women in higher education. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. also promotes the advancement of Latinas through various campus activities and community services, and provides an environment for personal growth within a unit of sisterhood. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.'s priorities, however, will be placed upon academic excellence and community service.

Organization.Name: Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc.
Organization.Summary: The FIRST and The LARGEST at The FIRST and #1 Public Institution in the NATION. WE ARE THE INSTITUTION OF EVOLUTION! Beta Chi Chapter University of California, Berkeley
Organization.Description:
On December 1, 1975, history was made – history on a college campus, which would transcend other colleges/universities throughout the United States; history which would have a positive impact on the Latino community and our nation; history which would forever change the Greek system, more specifically, the entity known as a fraternity. On December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi was founded on the campus of Kean College in Union, New Jersey.

The ideals of this brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago. 

Since our founding, Lambda Theta Phi has established chapters in every region of the country at both the undergraduate and professional levels. Our brotherhood continues to provide the necessary skills and resources for the advancement and empowerment of our people and for the betterment of this nation. 

The University of California, Berkeley was home to the newest chapter of Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc. in the Spring semester of 2004. Ten undergraduate students came together with the idea of introducing a positive image of a Latino fraternity to the UC Berkeley campus. They wanted to embrace and take part in the unity, brotherhood, pride and respect for all cultures that Lambda Theta Phi offered.

On May 9, 2004, Luis Sanchez, Renato Manay, Renzo Manay, Arquimides Pacheco, and Rafael Hernandez created a historical landmark and established the first Latino Greek Letter Fraternity officially recognized by the National Interfraternal Council (NIC) on the UC Berkeley campus.

Now, since its establishment and through its further development and growth, Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley has continued to carry through its ideals of a service/social fraternity by giving back to the community while engaging in social activities that would allow further bondages among our members and with other organizations. Such include our participation in the Annual AIDS Walk, our service in low-income Oakland Elementary schools, and advocacy of immigrant rights to day laborers within the county of Alameda. Apart from these community service events, this chapter has sought to create strong ties and mutual respect with other Latin and non-Latin organizations through social activities and collaborative efforts.

Lastly, the main goal of Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley is to pursue the educational success of our fraternity brothers. At the national level, from New Jersey to California, many go on to become doctors, lawyers, engineers, among other professionals.

Organization.Summary: Multi-Cultural Fraternities and Sororities
Organization.Description:
OPEN FOR EXPANSION 2013-2014

Refer to DOCUMENTS for more information.

*Turn in completed applications to mcgc.president@calgreeks.com

 

We, the undersigned Greek organizations have joined together to form this council known as the Multi-Cultural Greek Council at the University of California, Berkeley in order to better meet our individual needs, voice our concerns and promote the greater good of our community. Our official charter date is February 2007. We recognize that there are certain areas of action and programming that can be best carried out by the joint efforts of all such organizations. As culturally based organizations, we strive to promote and uplift our common heritages and history. As a council we shall uphold our commitment to service, scholarship and the values of sisterhood and brotherhood.

Organization.Summary: The National Council of Negro Women, NCNW, serves to lead, develop, and advocate for women of African descent by uplifting the community at large and negating negative stereotypes that plague the African American women community.

Organization.Summary: To improve the retention of Native American students in secondary, post-secondary schools, and other forms of higher education locally and statewide. Also, to actively recruit and inspire secondary and transfer students to apply to UC Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Nourish International at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Nourish International at Berkeley's mission is to eradicate poverty by engaging students and empowering communities. Join today and help change the world.
Organization.Description:
NI serves to help students make a stand against the poverty crisis in a tangible way. Through innovative social entrepreneurship, Nourish International at Berkeley works alongside developing communities to implement sustainable development projects. In addition to our international sustainable development projects, our purpose is to engage students, serving as a medium to help students figure out our role in the ever-evolving world economy as we enter the workforce as global leaders in our respective professions.

Check out our website at Berkeley.Nourish.org

Organization.Name: Oakland Asian Student Educational Services
Organization.Summary: OASES was founded in 1983 by a group of UC Berkeley undergraduates who wanted to provide a critical safety net for youth living in Oakland’s Chinatown.
Organization.Description: Today, OASES has grown into an organization of more than 400 volunteers, serving over 400 students in grades K-5 each year regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual identity, or religious belief. OASES's vision is that  all students in the public education system reach their fullest potential and are supported to achieve success in school, careers and civic life. OASES achieves this by empowering youth with limited resources through education, mentorship, and service to strengthen the Oakland community.

Organization.Name: Open Computing Facility
Organization.Summary: The Open Computing Facility (OCF) is an all-volunteer student organization dedicated to free computing. We currently offer free web hosting, file storage, email, Unix shell accounts, and printing.
Organization.Description:
The Open Computing Facility (OCF) provides computing opportunities for all students, student groups, faculty, and staff. We offer free web hosting, file storage, email, Unix shell accounts, and printing, and we do this by providing our entirely-volunteer staff an opportunity to explore serving practical computing services.

We have a computer lab with 13 desktops and a server closet with our backend equipment in Hearst Gym basement. We work jointly with the ASUC Publications Center and Blue & Gold Yearbook.

As of 4/11/13, we serve 5,471 currently-registered students (10:1 ratio of undergraduates to graduates), 361 registered student organizations, 75 faculty members, 227 staff members, 21 other affiliates, and 4,507 alumni.

Organization.Description: The People's Test Preparation Service (PTPS) was founded in 1995 at the University of California, Berkeley and is a non-profit, student-run organization dedicated to providing standardized test taking skills to urban communities. We strive to provide free test prep services to high school students in need of help. PTPS trains 40 Cal students per semester to teach 300 high school students in 13 sites across the East Bay.

Organization.Name: Project Vision
Organization.Summary: PV is a community service group that works to increase access to vision care in the East Bay Area. Our volunteers connect low-income communities to discounted eye exams and glasses!
Organization.Description:
Are you aiming for a career in medicine, optometry, social work, or healthcare-related community service? Come check out Project Vision – a student-run volunteer organization in its seventh year that helps connect low-income communities around UC Berkeley to low-cost vision care (eye exams, glasses, etc.). We aim to break down the barriers to healthcare access among medically underserved populations while giving students the hands-on opportunity to work with such populations.

Come learn more about us at one of our information sessions!

Thursday, Sept. 5, 2013: 7PM-8PM (228 Dwinelle)

Monday, Sept. 9, 2013: 7PM-8PM (183 Dwinelle)

Contact Gail or Anne at pvmembership@gmail.com with any questions, or visit our website at https://sites.google.com/site/calprojectvision/home.
