Organization.Name: Queer Alliance & Resource Center
Organization.Summary: The Queer Alliance and Resource Center (QARC) provides social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer community on campus. QARC also acts as an umbrella organization and caucus for all active queer and queer-allied organizations at Cal.
Organization.Description:
The Queer Alliance and Resource Center, formerly the Queer Resource Center and Queer Alliance, was united for the first time by a Senate Bill written by Gregory Stevens and Senator Corey Jackson and sponsored by Senator Corey Jackson.

The Queer Alliance and Resource Center is in charge of providing social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer community on campus, and also acts as an umbrella organization for all active queer communities on campus.
 
The Queer Alliance and Resource Center also maintains the QARC room in A15 Hearst Annex; it is a safe space and open to all students and queer student groups.
 
QARC meetings, acting as a caucus for all active queer organizations on campus (as well as queer-allied organizations), take place every Friday at 5:00 PM.

QARC would like to remind everyone to support the queer and queer-allied groups on campus including: 
 

-Queer Alliance and Resource Center (QARC)                                                               -Biyuti
-Cal Queer & Asian (Cal Q&A)                                                                                   -Gender Equity Resource Center (GenEq)                                                                      -GRL (Gamma Rho Lambda)-Khush                                                                                                                    -Oscar Wilde House                                                                                                  -QPOC Together
-SEO (Sigma Epsilon Omega) 
-Queer Womyn at Berkeley (QW@B)
-Queer Straight Alliance (QSA)                                                                                    -O4B (Out 4 Business)
-oSTEM (out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics)                                 -T-Cal                                                                                                                               -Trans*Action                                                                                                            -Unity House                                                                                                            -YQUE! (Young Queers United for Empowerment)-Zawadi                                                                                                                -FemSex (Female Sexuality Decal)

Organization.Name: Queer Straight Alliance
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Queer Straight Alliance is a) To create a safe and inclusive environment at UC Berkeley for students to support each other and to learn about various forms of oppression such as but is not limited to: homophobia, sexism, racism,
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Queer Straight Alliance is


a) To create a safe and inclusive environment at UC Berkeley for students to support each other and to learn about various forms of oppression such as but is not limited to: homophobia, sexism, racism, transphobia, ablism, and classism and to learn ways and skills to fight such oppressions.


b) To educate and raise public awareness about diverse issues surrounding the LGBTQQIA and Berkeley community through multiple perspectives. Some of these issues will include topics such as homophobia, gender identity, sexual orientation, queer people of color, and many more.


c) To fight discrimination, harassment, and violence on campus through educational workshops, caucuses, and other public events promoting equity and unity.


d) To reach out to those out side of UC Berkeley by welcoming other community members to participate in certain events and holding state/nation-wide workshops.

 

Through these functions, QSA hopes to further grow as a community leader and to empower others. Members of the QSA will work together and reach out to other organizations/clubs on and off campus.

 

QSA strives to provide a “safe space” where every individual can be free of harassment, discrimination, isolation, judgment, and/or violence that occur because of who they are. We will achieve these results by empowering and motivating students and student/community leaders to end inequalities that exist at Cal and in our society.

 

Ultimately, QSA strives to create an accepting and united community.

Please refer to our website for more information.
raza.berkeley.edu
Organization.Description:
"An effort to demystify education, conceptualized and realized by Raza!"

 

The RRRC's goal is to increase the enrollment of Chicano/Latino high school students in institutions of higher education by sending UCB students on recruitment trips to local area high schools. The center also helps improve the retention rate of Chicano/Latinos through various programs and events throughout the academic year.

Organization.Name: Reach! Asian Pacific American Recruitment and Retention Center
Organization.Summary: "Committed to the service, empowerment, and mobilization of immigrant, refugee, and under served Asian/Pacific Islanders by promoting higher education to empower ourselves and challenge the economic and social inequalities facing our communities."
Organization.Description:
In 1994, REACH! began with a handful of committed folks, as a program under the Asian Student Union (ASU) at UC Berkeley to target “Asian Pacific American, high school students, especially those who are underrepresented, low-income, and non-college tracked”. Its goals were two-fold: 1) promoting higher education as an attainable goal and 2) empowering students through “building ethnic pride and programs that foster community activism and support APA youth culture”.

As REACH! grew organizationally, the vision and purpose of REACH! grew with it. While the mission remained, “the service and empowerment of recent immigrant and urban Asian Pacific Americans living in at-risk life situations,” we added on that “Our goal is to promote higher education as a means to empower ourselves and improve the economic and social conditions facing our communities.” We saw that REACH! had a unique role on campus and in the API community at large, because REACH! was not just going to increase the numbers of underrepresented Asians at Berkeley but REACH! would be a training ground for future educators, activists, and leaders who would address society’s injustices through their life’s work. Thus, we created programs to raise political awareness, build coalitions, develop youth leaders, and build leadership in ourselves.

Each year, programs have been refined and recreated by (insanely) dedicated and intelligent coordinators, who look for a better way to do things. However, our single most important legacy is the steady stream of community leaders we have and will produce.

Organization.Name: Re-entry and Transfer Student Association
Organization.Summary: The mission of the RTSA is to create a support group and to encourage all re-entry and transfer students attending the Berkeley Campus, or wishing to attend the Berkeley Campus, to succeed at their scholastic endeavor.

Organization.Name: Remedy Music Project
Organization.Summary: Originally founded in 2006, Remedy Music Project is UC Berkeley's premier, student-run, concert production group that aims to feature not big-name artists, but artists who are students just like you.
Organization.Description: Originally founded in 2006, Remedy Music Project is UC Berkeley's premier, student-run, concert production group that aims to feature not big-name artists, but artists who are students just like you. Our goals are twofold: (1) provide student artists the opportunity to share their work and (2) use the campus' musical talent to promote awareness of important community issues. We believe that each individualal's perception of the world is only a small fraction of what the world truly is; this often times prevents each one of us from being able to recognize the unfortunate realities that exist in the world. We believe that by using the power of music, we can help inspire people to create and become remedies for these realities and build communities of people who are motivated by and work for similar passions.

Organization.Name: Renters' Legal Assistance
Organization.Summary: RLA offers assistance to U.C. Berkeley students and the surrounding community through counseling, educational workshops, and public interest research.
Organization.Description:
ASUC Renters' Legal Assistance was established in 1981 as a joint project of the ASUC, CALPIRG, and the Municipal Lobby to help educate tenants about their rights. Renters' Legal Assistance offers free advice to U.C. Berkeley students and the surrounding community through counseling, education, and public interest research. RLA provides in-office counseling, group counseling, phone counseling as well as workshops and seminars for the public. To aid students inasserting their rights, RLA distributes pamphlets and sample letters covering numerous topic. RLA maintains a comprehensive library containing material on housing issues and tenant's rights, current California Civil Codes, Berkeley Rent Control regulations and other housing related legal texts.

RENTERS' LEGAL ASSISTANCE INTERNSHIP PROGRAM

UC Berkeley student can apply to intern at Renters' Legal Assistance every semester. Initially, interns will familiarize themselves with California and Berkeley rent law through trainings, reading and observation. As interns become more familiar with the law, they may begin counseling clients. Interns can expect to develop skills such as public speaking, counseling, legal researching, problem solving, program development and enhanced writing skills.

The Renters' Legal Assistance program falls under the Education fields studies course 97/197 and can be taken for up to 2 units. Interns must hold a minimum of 4 office hours per week and attend weekly meetings. Interns must also attend a training session early in the semester and pass a written exam.

Organization.Name: Rising Immigrant Scholars through Education - RISE
Organization.Summary: Rising Immigrant Scholars through Education (RISE) is a group of students promoting awareness for current college and high school students on educational issues that affect the immigrant community.
Organization.Description:
R.I.S.E. provides support services, leadership training, and promotes collective empowerment of AB 540 students at U.C. Berkeley to fight and organize for equal access and affordable higher education

RISE is a student-led, student run organization that develops student leadership skills in organizing from the bottom up to change current barriers to accessing a higher education for AB 540 Students. As such RISE consciously does not follow a traditional hierarchical structure in governance. Instead RISE acknowledges every member as having equal power and voice by structuring the group based on a consensus decision making process with rotating facilitators to build leadership and to allow all members to contribute.

Organization.Name: Rotaract
Organization.Summary: Sponsored by the world's oldest service organization Rotary International, Rotaract is a service club for those interested in humanitarian service, networking, building goodwill, and promoting peace around the world.
Organization.Description:
What is Rotaract?

Sponsored by international service organization Rotary International, Rotaract is a service club for young men and women ages 18-30.

Modeled after similar goals and standards to those of Rotary, Rotaract brings together college students and young business professionals for the purpose of humanitarian service, networking, building goodwill and promoting peace around the world. As one of the fastest-growing Rotary programs, Rotaract on the international scale includes more than 8,000 Rotaract clubs in some 155 countries.

Each individual Rotaract club is sponsored by a local Rotary club, and is generally either university- or community-based. Each chapter has its own unique personality, sometimes with special emphases and focuses dependent upon the array of members and their particular interests. Like Rotary, Rotaract clubs meet on a regular basis, and are nonpolitical, nonreligious and open to anyone interested.

Rotaractors address many of global and local issues pertinent to today’s society, developing projects that promote service, build friendship and provide a forum for cultural exchange.

Why Join Rotaract?
  • Service opportunities: The main focus of Rotaract is humanitarian service on all fronts–locally, nationally and internationally. UC Berkeley offers a variety of community service opportunities several times a month, many of which are local. Additionally, transportation is always arranged for members, so members can always get to events regardless of distance.
  • Networking: Networking is key to any profession, so what better way to make connections than in a club that gives you direct access to Rotarians, all of whom are professionals at the top of their field, both undergraduate and graduate students in a variety of majors and fields of study, and young business professionals?
  • Awards & Scholarships: Rotaract will give you the inside on Rotary-related scholarship opportunities as they come along, including those that have specific scholarships set aside for Rotaractors. These include the extremely prestigious Rotary Ambassadorial Scholarship, The Scholar Ship and International RYLA (Rotary Youth Leadership Awards).
  • International connections: One of the key benefits of Cal Rotaract is our affiliation with Rotary International, an influential community service organization that has clubs all over the world.

Organization.Name: Sigma Pi Alpha
Organization.Summary: Sigma Pi Alpha Sorority, Inc. is a Chicana/Latina Sorority. It was founded in May 2nd, 1996 at Berkeley by nine women who saw the need to create a close network of Latinas who wanted to make a difference in their communities starting by themselves.
Organization.Description:
Sigma Pi Alpha is a Chicana/Latina Sorority. It was founded in the Spring of 1996 at the University of California at Berkeley by nine women who saw the need to create a close network of Chicana/Latinas - Chicana/Latinas who want to make a difference in the community starting with themselves. Sigma Pi Alpha addresses the academic, cultural, communal, and social needs of its members.

For ourselves we are a sisterhood of academic and personal support, trust, and understanding. We base our work on our three pillars of academics, service and sisterhood. We work on the basis of our pillars and follow our following seven goals: 1. To enhance Chicana/Latina heritage within the sorority. 2. To be involved within campus and our communities. 3. To promote higher education in future generations. 4. To address academics, sisterhood, and personal and individual needs. 5. To create a sisterhood in which we can communicate and express ourselves with trust and security. 6. To form a sisterhood where we can receive support and a commitment that will last a lifetime. 7. To follow a code of conduct representative to us as a sorority and as Chicana/Latina women.For our campus we sponsor informative and social activities. We support our fellow RAZA organizations and network with other campus resources and groups. For our community our priority is to promote higher education through mentoring, tutoring, scholarships, and to support Chicana/Latina youth.

Organization.Name: Smart Ass, The
Organization.Summary: Have you ever been called a smart ass? If you haven't, then you are missing out on the experience of a lifetime! Come join the Smart Ass team this semester and become part of one of the best-named publications on campus.

Organization.Name: Southeast Asian Mentorship
Organization.Summary: Southeast Asian Mentorship academically as well as politically tries to motivate and empower high school youth through workshops, academic advising, and activities every Saturday in Berkeley. SEAM also works with Richmond's non-profit organization SEAYL.
Organization.Description:
Our mission statement is "to empower high school youth and mentors by utilizing academic advising and mentorship as a way of addressing political and socio-economic issues facing the Southeast Asian community; to build a two-way exchange of knowledge and resources, instilling within both mentees and mentors the power to create social change.”

Southeast Asian Mentorship academically as well as politically tries to motivate and empower high school youth, particularly from Richmond, through workshops, academic advising, and activities every Saturday in Berkeley. SEAM also works with Richmond's non-profit organization SEAYL (Southeast Asian Young Leaders) to promote awareness against gang violence and provide academic support every Wednesday in Richmond.

Organization.Name: Southeast Asian Student Coalition
Organization.Summary: "To unite Southeast Asian communities, particularly those bounded by the historical context of the Viet Nam War, and to address the social injustices, economic inequalities and political under-representation that they face."&nbsp
Organization.Description:
"To unite Southeast Asian communities, particularly those bounded by the historical context of the Viet Nam War, and to address the social injustices, economic inequalities and political under-representation that they face." 

SASClove<3

Organization.Name: Stop the Traffick
Organization.Summary: STOP the Traffick is a campaign whose purpose shall be to raise awareness about sex trafficking and modern day slavery. STOP the Traffick is committed to achieve this through education and advocacy

Organization.Name: Student Anti Genocide Coalition (AKA STAND)
Organization.Summary: TBD

Organization.Name: Student Art Publishing
Organization.Summary: Our goal is to develop and promote the graphic arts in the student body at Cal.

Organization.Name: Student Food Collective
Organization.Summary: The mission of the Student Food Collective is to educate the berkeley student community about the BSFC and support its goal to provide fresh, healthy, environmentally sustainable, and ethically produced food that is affordable.

Organization.Name: Student Parent Association for Recruitment and Retention
Organization.Summary: We are the Student Parent Association for Recruitment and Retention (SPARR), an ASUC funded student group at the University of California, Berkeley. Our Mission is to reach out to prospective and current students who are or are soon to be parents, to
Organization.Description:
We are the Student Parent Association for Recruitment and Retention (SPARR), an ASUC funded student group at the University of California, Berkeley. Our Mission is to reach out to prospective and current students who are or are soon to be parents, to create a network of mutual support and build an inclusive, connected community.

 

Although our focus is on student parents, we welcome anyone who would like to be a part of our organization.  Visit our web page to learn more about us!

 

Thanks.

Organization.Name: Student Society for Stem Cell Research
Organization.Summary: Berkeley student network dedicated to spreading knowledge and awareness of stem cell research.
Organization.Description: Cal-SSSCR is a Berkeley student network dedicated to spreading knowledge and awareness of stem cell research. The Berkeley chapter actively participates in stem cell activities on campus and creates opportunities for Berkeley students to learn more about research through meetings and lectures with student researchers, professors, and staff from on campus. We also give presentations to local high schools and community colleges about stem cell basics and their current applications in medicine. We are part of a larger organization, the international SSSCR, which oversees development of chapters in the US and abroad. A list of chapters can be found on www.ssscr.org.

Organization.Name: Student to Student Peer Counseling
Organization.Summary: Student-to-Student Peer Counseling offers free and confidential counseling and referrals for UC Berkeley students on a walk-in and phone-in basis. For more information, visit our website at sspc.berkeley.edu.

Organization.Name: Students for Ugandan Refugee Education
Organization.Summary: To provide for the education and empowerment of Ugandan refugees, thereby helping them to reach their full potential as socially engaged leaders of the future.

Organization.Name: Suitcase Clinic
Organization.Summary: The Suitcase Clinic is a student and volunteer run organization founded by students from the UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program (JMP) and UC Berkeley's School of Public Health out of a desire to address the unmet needs of the city of
Organization.Description:
The Suitcase Clinic is a student and volunteer run organization founded by students from the UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program (JMP) and UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health out of a desire to address the unmet needs of the city of Berkeley’s homeless and low-income population. Structured around the principles of public health, social welfare, community activism and empathy, the Suitcase Clinic currently operates three weekly multi-service drop-in centers in the city Berkeley: the General Clinic, the Women’s Clinic and the Youth Clinic. In addition to providing services, the Suitcase Clinic strives to educate students, promote health care access, engage in community organization, and support public policy efforts that address homelessness and the needs of the underserved in the local community.

The mission of the Suitcase Clinic is to promote the health and overall wellbeing of underserved individuals through service provision, cooperative learning, and collective action among community and professional volunteers, students, and participants.

Organization.Name: Take Back the Night
Organization.Summary: Take Back the Night is a student run organization that raises awareness and breaks the silence against sexual and relationship violence through art, music and open storytelling.

Organization.Name: Teahouse
Organization.Summary: to provide an intellectual, literary and artistic forum, in which they find the opportunity to publish their writings in Chinese, and to contrbitue to the cultural diversity of Cal a period of student publication written in Chinese.

Organization.Name: Team HBV
Organization.Summary: Team HBV aims to spread awareness about hepatitis B and liver cancer, which are both disproportionately high among those in the Asian and Pacific Islander community.
Organization.Description: Team HBV at UC Berkeley, along with other chapters across the U.S., is dedicated to raising awareness of the disproportionately high incidence of hepatitis B (HBV) and liver cancer among the Asian and Pacific Islander (API) community. ------- Did you know? * 1 in 10 (!!) Asian Americans are infected with Hepatitis B * 1/4 of those that have Hepatitis B will die from liver cancer * Berkeley requires us to get vaccinated for Hepatits B, however that just prevents us from contracting it from freshman year on * That means if you had it at birth, the vaccination does nothing for you * There are NO symptoms, until it is too late --------- SO, get screened (aka tested) and urge your parents and loved ones to do so as well! Please contact one of the officers if you are interested in joining us in our cause!

Organization.Name: Tech Chair
Organization.Summary: TC

Organization.Name: The Triple Helix: The Journal of Science, Society, and Law
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the organization is to encourage critical analysis of legal and socially important issues in science through the free exchange of ideas. Our goal is to involve students in the exploration of the dynamic relationships between science,
Organization.Description: The purpose of the organization is to encourage critical analysis of legal and socially important issues in science through the free exchange of ideas. Our goal is to involve students in the exploration of the dynamic relationships between science, society and the law and to educate and inspire our readers to learn more about the growing connection between science and other institutions. We will accomplish these goals through the publication of a bi-annual journal and the organization of science policy events that promote the understanding of the impact of science and technology on society and their interaction with the law.

Organization.Name: Theater for Charity
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley's premiere student-written comedy theater group, where every penny goes to charity! Your home for foul-mouthed philanthropy!
Organization.Description:
Theater for Charity is a non-profit theater group on the UC Berkeley Campus that puts on a bunch of awesome shows each semester, and donates all the proceeds to charity! 

Everything is student run, written, directed, produced, and performed. We do 2-3 shows a semester, so keep an eye out if you want to try out! Even if acting isn't yo thang, we are always on the look out for writers, directors, and technical people as well!

If you have any questions, email us at ucbtheaterforcharity@gmail.com

Organization.Name: Timber Publication
Organization.Summary: Timber is an annual publication serving primarily as a yearbook and magazine for students, faculty, alumni and community members interested in the field of forestry and natural resources.
Organization.Description: Timber is an annual publication serving primarily as a yearbook and magazine for students, faculty, alumni and community members interested in the field of forestry and natural resources. The publication will focus on the activities of students studying Forestry and Natural Resources as well as the Forestry Club student organization

Organization.Name: To An Unknown God
Organization.Summary: To An Unknown God is UC Berkeley’s first student-run Christian journal. Every semester, we publish writing and artwork produced by Cal students, hoping to foster dialogue both between Christians and with students of other faiths and philosophies.
Organization.Description:
Vision


Therefore, the One whom you worship without
knowing, Him I proclaim to you.
—Acts 17:23-

To An Unknown God is UC Berkeley’s first student-run Christian journal. Every semester, we publish writing and artwork produced by Cal students, hoping to foster dialogue both between Christians and with students of other faiths and philosophies.

We are not affiliated with the university or any church or other religious group, and opinions expressed in articles and posts do not necessarily represent those of the editors. We are completely student-run and funded partly by the student body as an asuc-sponsored student publication. The majority of funding, however, comes from private donations. (Donate!)

Distribution is free while supplies last. If you would like a print copy, please email us your mailing address.

Organization.Name: TRENZA
Organization.Summary: TRENZA has provided a support network for the many young women that have stepped foot on the UC Berkeley campus. Socials, parties, community events, and weekly meetings.
Organization.Description:
"Eighteen Years Stong"
For the past 18 years TRENZA has provided a support network for the many young women that have stepped foot on the UC Berkeley campus. Socials, parties, community events, and weekly meetings have allowed TRENZUDAS to share numerous precious memories with each other. Positive attitudes and warm smiles characterize the exemplary organization that is TRENZA. The women of this organization hold it very dear to their hearts as they reminisce. Remember the smiles, the hi's as you passed each other on Sproul, the laughs, the talks, the cries, the banda dancing, the cooking, the retreats, and those special moments that occurred when you chose to become a TRENZUDA.

Organization.Name: True Asian Leaders
Organization.Summary: True Asian Leaders is dedicated to the mentorship & empowerment of Asian high school youth in the neighboring communities of Oakland & Richmond, bringing them together through similar experiences by supporting dialogue about community and political issue
Organization.Description: TAL instills students with the motivation and passion to bring about lasting and positive change in our communities by promoting critical thinking and leadership skills. Students are provided with continual support and guidance as needed in order to achieve higher education.

Organization.Name: Undergraduate Journal of Psychology at Berkeley, The
Organization.Summary: Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further
Organization.Description:
Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further undergraduate research in psychology.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

CALL FOR UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH PAPERS

 

If you have completed a research paper in a psychology-related field, we invite you to submit your paper for publication in Psychology at Berkeley!

 

Psychology at Berkeley is a biannual publication that allows undergraduate students who have completed scientific studies in psychology to disseminate their findings to the campus at large, thereby promoting excellence in and encouraging further undergraduate research in psychology.

 

Psychology at Berkeley is currently accepting submissions for its fourth edition, to be published during the Fall 2010 semester.


Psychology at Berkeley accepts and reviews submissions from all psychology-related fields, as long as the papers are completed by undergraduate students; this includes senior honors theses, course term papers, independent research projects, theoretical papers, and all other excellent undergraduate writing. Multiple submissions are welcome.


To submit an original research article for review and publication:

  • Verify that your submission does not contain any identifying information (to ensure anonymity during the selection process), and attach a word or pdf copy of the article in an e-mail to berkpsychjournal@gmail.com.
  • Include your full name, paper title, telephone number, and preferred e-mail address in the body of your e-mail message
  • If you are a Berkeley student, please send your paper using your CalMail address and note in the body of your e-mail that you are a Berkeley student so that you will receive Cal student priority for publication

 

The deadline to submit papers is midnight on February 28, 2010. However, papers received earlier will have higher priority. Applicants will be notified by early March if their paper is being considered for publication.

 

If you have any questions about or difficulty in submitting your paper, please contact berkpsychjournal@gmail.com for further information. We look forward to reading your submissions!

Organization.Name: V-Day at Berkeley
Organization.Summary:
Become a fan of V-Day at UC Berkeley on Facebook to get updates on ticket sales, events, opportunities to get involved, and of course, when and where the show will be in February!!
({}) V-Day at UC Berkeley ({}) is not only a group that
Organization.Description:
Become a fan of V-Day at UC Berkeley on Facebook to get updates on ticket sales, events, opportunities to get involved, and of course, when and where the show will be in February!! 

 

({}) V-Day at UC Berkeley ({}) is not only a group that puts on playwright Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues every year to raise money to end violence against women, but we are a movement on campus and in our community. 
Every fall, we assemble a cast and crew through auditions to form a community for strong, motivated students who have, do or will identify as a woman. This community becomes a place of strength where women empower each other, learn from each other and prepare themselves to become a vagina warrior. 


Through alliances with other student groups and through the support of UC Berkeley's Gender Equity Resource Center and the ASUC, we strive to make this a learning experience not for those part of the movement but for all of those on campus. 


Every spring, as part of the culimination of our community and movement building, we bring our awareness and strength to the public through benefit performances of The Vagina Monologues to raise money and awareness to stop violence against women.

Organization.Name: VOID
Organization.ParentName: Associated Students of the University of California

Organization.Name: Volunteer Health Interpreters Organization
Organization.Summary:
“Hi! We’re the Vounteer Health Interpreters Organization”
Better known as VHIO, we provide verbal interpretation and document translation for healthcare related services in the San Francisco Bay Area.
Organization.Description:
**FOR MORE INFO: <www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~vhio>

also look <calhbc.wordpress.com/>‎ for past events

 

VHIO strives to eliminate language barriers in healthcare settings by providing trained volunteer interpreters from UC Berkeley to healthcare organizations and facilities for underserved, limited English proficient (LEP) communities in the Bay Area.

VHIO is a University of California, Berkeley undergraduate student-led organization whose roots trace back to 2007, when it was established as the San Francisco Hepatitis B Collaborative (SFHBC) in partnership with University of California, San Francisco health professional students. SFHBC at Berkeley provided trained bilingual students as Asian language interpreters for two monthly UCSF hepatitis B student-run clinics, which we continue to volunteer at.

Dedicated to helping stop the spread of Hepatitis B, SFHBC partnered with organizations such as the San Francisco Hepatitis B Free Campaign and helped at various screening, vaccination, and education events. Four hundred million people worldwide suffer from chronic hepatitis B infection, which tragically can lead to liver cancer early in adult life. It is the 10th leading etiologic cause of death in the world. Fortunately, the spread of the hepatitis B virus is preventable with a simple, safe, and effective vaccine.

Due to an increase in demand for interpretation services, we have been expanding to provide interpretation and volunteering services for a broader range of issues beyond hepatitis B. In August 2010, SFHBC at Berkeley was renamed the Volunteer Health Interpreters Organization (VHIO) to reflect its expanded scope of language capacities and its service base across the San Francisco Bay Area.

Working closely together with UCSF medical and pharmacy students, health-workers and medical providers,  we are able to serve Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Vietnamese, Spanish, Tagalog and Khmer speaking patients to help them overcome the healthcare language barrier. Each of our language groups have their own regular clinics established.

Outreach is a major part of our work. Since many health fairs aim to target underserved populations, we help attain this goal by assisting immigrant neighborhoods with our interpretation services.  

Stressing empowerment, VHIO is passionate about community education. Our volunteers have also interpreted for a number of presentations, ranging from colorectal cancer prevention to disaster preparedness.

VHIO seeks committed volunteers who are fluent in a second language and passionate about outreaching to under-served communities. We recruit once a year at the beginning of the fall semester.

 

VHIO provides the following valuable experiences for pre-health students.

Interpretation: Clinical Experience, working with underserved communities

Outreach: Make connections with medical students and local organizations

DeCal: Professional training in healthcare interpretation

 

Members Expectations

-minimum of 10 volunteering hours per semester (20 per year)

-minimum 1 social per semester (2 per year)

-attend monthly Language Committee meetings (max. 1 excused absence per semester)

-attend Fall Welcome Meeting

-attend Spring workshops (max. 1 excused absence, 3 total)

- If new member, must be enrolled in DeCal (follow DeCal rules)

 

 

 

Proud Partners with:

Affordable Housing Associates  •   Alameda Hep B Free  •  American Liver Foundation  •  Asian and Pacific Islander Wellness Center  •  Asian Community Mental Health Services  •  Asian Health Services  •  Asian Liver Center  •  AsianWeek  •  California Pacific Medical Center  •  Center for Elderly Independence  •  Chinese American Coalition for Compassionate Care  •  Chinese Community Health Plan  • Chinese Hospital in San Francisco  •  Chinatown Public Health Center  •  Clinic by the Bay  •  Korean Community Health Center  •  Street Level Health Project - School of Optometry  •  Labor Coach  •   San Francisco Hep B Free  •  Street Level Health Clinic  •  Team HBV at Berkeley  •  The Hep B Project  •  UCSF Partners in D  •  UCSF Operation Diabetes  •  UCSF San Francisco Hepatitis B Collaborative  •  Vietnamese American Community Center of the East Bay  •  Women's Cancer Research at Berkeley

Organization.Name: Women and Youth Supporting Each Other
Organization.Summary: Women and Youth Supporting Each Other (WYSE) is a national all-girls social mentoring program that provides young women with the resources, information and support necessary to make informed decisions about relationships, sexuality, and their futures.
Organization.Description:
Women and Youth Supporting Each Other (WYSE) is a national all-girls social mentoring program that provides young women with the resources, information and support necessary to make informed decisions about relationships, sexuality, their futures and to create community change. The WYSE chapter at Berkeley mentors girls from Longfellow Middle School in Berkeley every Monday, where both mentors and mentees collaborate, create, discover, explore, and grow together!

 

Follow us on Twitter!

Organization.Name: Wonderworks
Organization.Summary: Wonderworks members adopt an elementary school class for a semester and engage students in interactive science demonstrations.
Organization.Description:
Wonderworks is a program stemming from one member's experience with a like minded project in high school. Wonderworks is not here to teach; that is already covered by teachers, and by many other organizations on the UC Berkeley campus. Using science as our tool of choice, our goal is to pique the interest of young students. This interest can be in the specific demonstration presented in the field of science, or in the whole idea of education.

The students volunteering their time to support Wonderworks would, in groups of 3-5, design or choose from existing GEM module presentations from the Lawrence Hall of Science. They would then adopt an elementary school class for a semester and perform interactive demonstrations during prearranged visits. These presentations usually occur about twice a month depending on outstanding factors, including the desires of the teacher of the class involved. Visits last about 2 hours; 1 hour for interactive demonstration and 1 hour of preparation and clean-up.

Organization.Name: Xinaxtli
Organization.Summary: OUR MISSION... In Nahuatl, Xinaxtli represents a seed's energy and its eminent possibility of growing/blossoming into any form. Our purpose is to serve as a circle of growth and support for the empowerment of the Xican@/Latin@ community. Our
Organization.Description:
OUR MISSION... 

In Nahuatl, Xinaxtli represents a seed’s energy and its eminent possibility of growing/blossoming into any form. Our purpose is to serve as a circle of growth and support for the empowerment of the Xican@/Latin@ community. Our goal is to provide a space for Raza to become politically active and engaged in the Raza community in a way that goes beyond “community service”. 

Our philosophy emphasizes the knowledge that exists in our various indigenous roots. Through our participation in diverse community efforts, we will grow to become a stronger, humbler, more progressive, and unified communidad. 

In order to expand and strengthen our political, spiritual, and community knowledge, we recognize the need to break down cultural and regional borders on campus and the Raza community at-large. 

Our goal is to continue to fight for social justice, as our ancestors have done for the past 500 years… 

THEREFORE... 

WE will provide a safe cultural and political space, which will serve as a vehicle for action and change for our community. We will take an active stance against all forms of sexism, heterosexism, racism, ablism, classism, and all other forms of colonization. 

WE will encourage Xican@/Raza youth to attend institutions of higher education 

WE will empower Raza youth through cultural education and mentoring as a way to encourage community involvement 

WE will educate oursevelves and our respective campus on the issues facing Raza in our in our communities…. 

WE will support the struggles of other progressive movements on campus, in our community, and internationally 

WE, Xinaxtli, are committed to advancing the human and civil rights of all Raza and we will attempt to address any educational, political and social inequalities that Raza students or community members--with the ultimate goal of self-determination and libertad de la mente. 

THE STRUGGLE CONTINUES...

Organization.Name: Young Queers United for Empowerment
Organization.Summary: YQUE is a student group for those who identify as queer and latino/a (however, we welcome allies of other ethnic backgrounds and sexualities).
Organization.Description: YQUE is a student group for those who identify as queer and latino/a (however, we welcome allies of other ethnic backgrounds and sexualities). The group primarily focuses on providing a safe space for dialogue, creating a social environment for networking and community building, and on being active on campus and the community at large.

Organization.Name: Youth Support Program
Organization.Summary: The Youth Support Program (YSP) is a mentoring program that pairs UC Berkeley mentors with middle school students at Willard Middle School, Claremont Middle School and MLK Elementary school.
Organization.Description: YSP is a mentoring program that trains UC Berkeley students in the theory and practice of mentoring.  Housed on the campus of Willard Middle School, YSP matches UC berkeley students (one-on-one) with 6th, 7th and 8th grade students.  The mentors are positive role models who provide guidance and instill civic and social responsibility.  These services are provided through tutoring, counseling, academic support, cultural arts education, community service events and after-school activities.

Organization.Name: *UC Berkeley Public Service Center*
Organization.Summary: UC Berkeley Public Service Center engages the University and the community in reciprocal partnerships to foster social justice and civic engagement.
Organization.Description:
Founded by students in 1967 as Cal Corps, the UC Berkeley Public Service Center partners with the community, student leaders and faculty to engage over 4,000 students each year as volunteers, and through jobs, internships, and courses.

The UC Berkeley Public Service Center connects ideas, resources, and people to act for social justice, build healthy communities, and foster life-long commitments to public service.

Through academic, social, and outreach events, AIGSA works towards strengthening the Native American/Indigenous student community on-campus and beyond. AIGSA also provides opportunities for Native grad students to connect with other students, staff, and faculty who are Native or work in areas that impact Native peoples.

Organization.Name: American Lung Association's Oakland Kicks Asthma
Organization.Summary: OKA teaches an innovative school-based asthma education curriculum designed to help asthmatic children. As asthma instructors, we help school children manage their asthma so they spend more time in the classroom and less time in the emergency room.
Organization.Description:
Our goal is to provide our curriculum (Open Airways for Schools) to elementary and middle schools within our target area, the East Bay. Because asthma disproportionately affects lower income children, schools that serve these children will be given priority. The American Lung Association of the East Bay will provide trained college student instructors to teach the curriculum, supply all curriculum materials, and provide technical assistance.


Oakland Kicks Asthma is an American Lung Association of California intervention program for indigent youth with asthma. Our program works closely with partners from the University of California at Berkeley School of Public Health, Oakland Unified School District, and Children's Hospital Oakland.

Organization.Name: Cognitive Science Students Association
Organization.Summary: The Cognitive Science Student Association (CSSA) is an undergraduate student organization at UC Berkeley whose mission is to support and enrich the academic life of students interested in the interdisciplinary field of Cognitive Science
Organization.Description: The Cognitive Science Student Association (CSSA) is an undergraduate student organization at UC Berkeley whose mission is to support and enrich the academic life of students interested in the interdisciplinary field of Cognitive Science. The CSSA strives to build a sense of community among students and provides them with valuable opportunities for personal, academic, and career development. The CSSA regularly coordinates academic events such as guest lectures and information sessions; plans social events like professor-student dinners and movie nights; and advocates for Cognitive Science students by working with CogSci faculty and university officials. Each year, the CSSA also plans, organizes, and hosts the California Cognitive Science Conference, a large academic conference featuring talks from Cognitive Science researchers from across the state as well as showcasing the exceptional work of undergraduates conducting research in Cognitive Science.

Organization.Name: East Bay Workers' Rights Disability Law Clinic
Organization.Summary: The East Bay Workers’ Rights Clinic is a graduate student-run legal clinic that has served low-income individuals in the greater Bay Area with employment-related legal concerns for over a decade.
Organization.Description:
The East Bay Workers’ Rights Clinic is a graduate student-run legal clinic that has served low-income individuals in the greater Bay Area with employment-related legal concerns for over a decade. Every Thursday, our organization holds a session to provide low-income workers around the Bay Area community with employment advice on a range of issues, including employment discrimination, unemployment, workers’ compensation, wage and hour problems, and unreported overtime.

The clinic begins at 5:30pm and often lasts past 10:00pm—depending on when the last client leaves and the last legal question is addressed. Clinic meetings take place after-hours to best serve the working individuals who rely on the clinic’s services.

Organization.Name: Graduate Women of Engineering
Organization.Summary: We support women pursuing their graduate degrees in Mechanical, Nuclear, Industrial, Civil, Environmental, Chemical, Electrical and Bio Engineering.
Organization.Description:
The Graduate Women of Engineering is a group of graduate engineering students from all engineering disciplines at the University of California, Berkeley. Our primary purpose is to support female graduate students in all their engineering endeavours.

Throughout the year a number of informal events are held to allow women engineers (and those who support women in engineering) to welcome new students, network, share experiences, develop study groups, discuss issues and just socialize. We are always looking for new faces to join us and welcome any suggestions for new events.

Our events are advertised throughout the year via email and on the events page. If you are a women graduate student in ME, NE, IOER or BioE at UCB you should already be receiving our emails. If you want to be notified of our future events please sign up for the GWE mailing list.

Organization.Name: Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project at Berkeley Law
Organization.Summary: The Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project at Berkeley Law School is part of a national organization that uses a combination of direct legal aid and broad policy advocacy to develop and enforce a system of legal and human rights for Iraqi and Afghan refugees.
Organization.Description:
The Iraqi Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) at Berkeley Law School is part of a national organization of 22 law schools and 49 global law firms in the Middle East, Canada, and the United States. We use a combination of direct legal aid and broad policy advocacy to develop and enforce a system of legal and human rights for Iraqi and Afghan refugees.

IRAP case teams take on urgent refugee cases that include: Iraqis and Afghans at risk of persecution because of their work as interpreters for the U.S. military; female survivors of sexual assault, domestic abuse, or human trafficking; and LGBT refugees. Law students are teamed up with attorney supervisors to provide free legal representation and services for the duration of the client’s resettlement application or appeals process.

IRAP’s policy team works directly with IRAP National to lobby the U.S. Congress. Our projects this year include lobbying Congress to extend the Special Immigrant Visa program, expand refugee programs for Afghans, and create comprehensive policy for LGBT refugees.

For more information, please contact May Whitaker, IRAP-Berkeley Chapter Director, or visit www.refugeerights.org

Organization.Name: Aesthetics at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To encourage and foster a community supporting the artistry and passion of bodybuilding held among UC Berkeley students.
Organization.Description:
“Every block of stone has a statue inside it and it is the task of the sculptor to discover it” - Michelangelo

What is art but simply a physical manifestation of grace and creativity sourced from the mind of its creator. Nothing is as immediate to an artist’s mind as the body itself. This direct relationship offers an absolute means of access to a medium possessed by all. Bodybuilding utilizes this relationship with the intent of creating a masterpiece unique to each artist capable of committing to the craft.

Organization.Name: Board of Advocates
Organization.Summary: Board of Advocates consists of the Alternative Dispute Resolution, Appellate, and Mock Trial teams of U.C. Berkeley School of Law. BOA has won competition awards at multiple levels and consistently outperforms other top-ten law schools.
Organization.Description:
The Board of Advocate’s general membership includes over 60 students who participate in both regional and national competitions in three main areas: Alternative Dispute Resolution, Trial Advocacy, and Appellate Advocacy. Competition for a place on these teams is fierce during the Board’s yearly try-out process, with multiple students vying for each spot. Teams receive coaching from professors, Executive Board Members, alumni, and fellow students.

The Board also places a strong emphasis on training fellow students and future members through internal competitions, offering scholarship money and the opportunity to be heard by federal judges in mock argument. The Board of Advocates provides further opportunities for students to hone their advocacy skills, hosting multiple skills workshops throughout the year. Finally, the Board organizes other annual events such as Ninth Circuit Day, which provides students a rare chance to see the federal court in action in an academic setting.

Organization.Name: College Ski and Snowboard Club
Organization.Summary: The College Ski and Snowboard Club, commonly known as the CSSC, provides Cal students with the best, cheapest, and funnest way to get to the snow.
Organization.Description:
The College Ski and Snowboard Club, commonly known as the CSSC, provides Cal students with the best, cheapest, and funnest way to get to the snow. Our main event is our Big Trip, held during the last week of winter vacation. Each year we travel to a different ski resort in the Western U.S. for a week of skiing at a price you cannot find anywhere else. During the spring semester, we host weekend trips to Tahoe. When we're not skiing, we hold parties, sales, and movie nights in Berkeley to get members excited before they even see the snow. Come visit us on Sproul, M-F from 11-2, for more information.

We're the kids in Berkeley who smile when it's raining . . .

Organization.Name: Colleges Against Cancer
Organization.Summary: Colleges Against Cancer: Relay for Life's purpose is to help eliminate cancer by supporting the programs of the American Cancer Society on college campuses. Students focus on four channels: advocacy, cancer education, Relay For Life, and survivorship
Organization.Description:
Colleges Against Cancer: Relay for Life is a program created to help eliminate cancer by initiating and supporting the programs of the American Cancer Society on college campuses. It is a program designed by and administered by college students from across the country and is supported by the American Cancer Society.

The program is designed to allow students and staff to work through many different channels to eliminate cancer. These channels are our strategic directions—advocacy, cancer education, Relay For Life, and survivorship. Local chapters work alongside their local offices and national leadership to support the efforts of the American Cancer Society in these directions. Whether it is writing letters to Congressmen, organizing Relay For Life, or teaching students about preventing cancer, the program enables college students to battle cancer on their campuses.

Organization.Name: Cooking Club
Organization.Summary: The Cal Cooking Club is a student organization intent on expressing creativity, inspiring learning, and developing cultural awareness through the medium of food. Monthly general meetings, open to all, feature prominent local chefs training the audience
Organization.Description: The Cal Cooking Club is a student organization intent on expressing creativity, inspiring learning, and developing cultural awareness through the medium of food. Monthly general meetings, open to all, feature prominent local chefs training the audience in the creation of signature dishes. On going restaurant clinics allow members to get first hand experience in professional kitchens as they team up with local chefs to make delicious food. Home cooking workshop, taught by fellow Cooking Club members, allow members to learn new kitchen skills and techniques, or allow those already seasoned to teach other members how they do what they do so well. For those looking more to kick back and socialize over food, or to show off some real creativity, join us for our frequent potlucks. The Cal Cooking Club is Cal's number one club to express your interest and admiration for food. Join us anytime, there's always room at our table.

Organization.Description: The Entomology Students Organization (ESO) is hosted by the Department of Environmental Science Policy and Management, but represents approximately 30 graduate students from various departments, all with an interest in insects. ESO provides peer-academic support for the entomology community through hosting workshops and events. We hold monthly meetings on topics ranging from macro-photography, presentation and grant writing advice, insect education, as well as coordinating field trips and participating in public events such as Cal Day and Darwin Day. In addition, we co-host the Essig Brunch weekly seminar series, along with the Essig Museum of Entomology.

Organization.Name: Gift to Life at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to give hope and raise funds for the medical treatment of indigenous children in the world who suffer from plastic anemia as a result of pollution and environmental contamination caused my mining, oil drilling and pesticides. Our current
Organization.Description:
Our mission is to give hope and raise funds for the medical treatment of indigenous children in the world who suffer from plastic anemia as a result of pollution and environmental contamination caused my mining, oil drilling and pesticides. Our current target is Peru.
Plastic anemia is anemia that is characterized by defective function of the blood-forming organs (as the bone marrow) and is caused by toxic agents (as chemicals or X-rays) or is idiopathic in origin
Our specific aims include:

  • To provide funds for the DNA testing needed to find matching donors
  • To provide funds for blood transfusions for patients
  • To provide funds for bone marrow transplants
  • To engage corporate sponsors for the medical treatment of each child
  • To secure sponsorship for the education of the effected children following treatment
  • To raise awareness to people who live in contaminated environment

Organization.Description:
The International Public Policy Group at UC Berkeley is an association and working group of policy students and professionals. We analyze and devise foreign policies and global policies, as well as comparative domestic policies across a range of issue areas–economics, security, health, environment, governance, and technology, among others.

Situated primarily in the Goldman School of Public Policy at UC Berkeley, IPPG welcomes students and alumni from all departments at UC Berkeley. Unless otherwise noted, all IPPG events are open to the UC Berkeley community.

Organization.Name: STEP
Organization.Summary: Science Technology and Engineering Policy Group aka STEP is focused on creating better informed science and technology policy through collaborations between scientists and policy-makers.
Organization.Description:
STEP is focused on creating better informed science and technology policy through collaborations between scientists and policy-makers.

Many of our most pressing public policy issues have a strong science and technology component, such as developing clean sources of energy and using information technology to reduce medical errors and administrative costs in our healthcare system. However, elected officials often lack the technical expertise to make informed decisions on these issues, and scientists and engineers rarely engage in the political process.

To address these needs, STEP is helping students build interdisciplinary skills at the intersection of science and policy. STEP works toward this goal through three activities: an annual White Paper Competition, a monthly Seminar Series and a Science Policy Journal Club.

Organization.Description: Students for Liberty is a non-partisan political student organization at UC Berkeley dedicated to promoting the ideas of of limited government, free markets, sound money, non-intervention, and maximum individual liberty to campus and the surrounding community. We spread our message through weekly internal club meetings (held Wednesdays from 7-8 PM in 263 Dwinelle Hall), external debates with other student organizations, speaker events, and tabling on Sproul Plaza.

Organization.Name: Teach in Prison
Organization.Summary: Cal Students Tutoring Inmates at San Quentin Prison
Organization.Description: Teach in Prison is a student run DeCal class that sends Cal student tutors to work with inmates at San Quentin Prison (SQ).  The primary tutoring groups work on phonics, proof-reading papers and grant proposals, counting and numbers, H.S. math, GED prep, and more.  We also have a team of mechanical engineering graduate students who teach computer aided design to inmates in San Quentin's machine shop.  Furthermore, there is a weekly class room meeting where guest lectures from all facets of the prison system present lectures that help students understand topics like: how prisons operate; what sort of education a person gets in prison; what it’s like to be a prison guard; what prison programs are there beyond Cal to get involved with.  It’s a very unique and rewarding experience for many students, and the program is in it’s 12 year as a DeCal.  We also recently won the Campus Community Partnership Award.
Organization.AddressStreet1: Teach in Prison c/o ASUC Student Affairs U.C.

Organization.Name: Vagabond Multilingual Journal

Organization.Description:

Vagabond publishes original poetry and prose, written in various languages and accompanied by English translations. All works are written by UC Berkeley students, professors, and staff members. Our past issues have published works written in languages like Chinese, Finnish, Hindi, Italian, Russian, and many more.

Organization.Name: Crossroads Christian Fellowship: Chinese for Christ Berkeley Church
Organization.Summary:
Crossroads Christian Fellowship is the college fellowship of Vinewood at Chinese for Christ (CFC) Church in Berkeley.
Our vision is to seek and raise up believers and to nurture a maturity amongst them that will transcend their college years. We
Organization.Description:
Crossroads Christian Fellowship is the college fellowship of Vinewood, the English ministry at Chinese for Christ (CFC) Church in Berkeley.

We are a student-led Christian fellowship on the Berkeley campus. We meet together on Friday nights at 7:30pm to worship, study the Word, and socialize with followers of Christ. We also offer weekly small groups to nurture personal spiritual growth in a more intimate setting. We are a ministry of Vinewood at Chinese for Christ Berkeley.  Our church is located two blocks past Ashby on Prince Street and College Avenue. 

Our vision is to seek and raise up believers and to nurture a maturity amongst them that will transcend their college years. We foster leadership opportunities so that members of our fellowship can develop their spiritual gifts and grow to become dependent on God alone by being challenged by the Word. CFC Berkeley also sponsors a young adult fellowship that offers spiritual mentors for college students.

Organization.Summary: The purpose of the organization is to spread interest in electrochemistry and provide a forum through which students and researchers may share expertise and build personal connections.
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the organization is to spread interest in electrochemistry and provide a forum through which students and researchers may share expertise and build personal connections.  The Electrochemical Society, Student Chapter of Berkeley will provide members with educational opportunities to prepare members for future success in a variety of related fields.

 

Membership is open to any individual who has an interest in electrochemistry.  Registration with the national parent organization, Electrochemical Society, is strongly encouraged though not required.  There are no academic restrictions for membership for University students.

Organization.Name: Entrepreneurial Society of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ES renamed from FSES per ASUC Senate Bill 133 10-31-12
Organization.Description:
FSES, UC Berkeley's newest business club founded in 2010, was the result of an entrepreneurial passion shared by two friends and college entrepreneurs.  Arian Rezazadeh (Class of 2013) and Ethan Mark (Class of 2013) had a unique idea for the 2009 Cal vs. Stanford Big Game to help Cal fans show their team pride.  As Arian and Ethan always describe it, "It all started with a small idea for a big game, and it turned out to be a big idea for an even bigger game." Arian and Ethan designed Big Game t-shirt people went crazy for, marketed it on campus, and sold a significant quantity of them. But it didn't end there. This business venture that they created from scratch took a lot of time and work. This prompted them to seek a club on campus that could help them out, make the process easier, and allow them to have a support group. To their dismay, Arian and Ethan could not find any clubs on campus that could assist freshman and sophomore students in this, and so they co-founded FSES to meet the needs of this part of the student body.  

Today, FSES has rapidly grown into a premier business club focused on a niche of meeting the needs of freshman and sophomore students at the University of California, Berkeley to develop their ideas and make them into full-on business ventures that can operate as stand-alone businesses. With a speaker series of successful entrepreneurs, case studies of entrepreneurial ideas, the 'Best Entrepreneurial Idea of the Semester' competition, and legal assistance team for start-ups, FSES is the club you want to be a part of. It's practical knowledge, a support group, and a place where you can make your ideas a reality.

Organization.Summary: To organize and host the annual Graduate Student Research Symposium dedicated to showcasing graduate student research and facilitating interdisciplinary exchange among divisions and between students and faculty.

Organization.Name: Friends of Northern Uganda
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this group is to bring awareness to the University of California, Berkeley campus and the surrounding community in regards to the war and the use of child soldiers in Northern Uganda, as well as to foster international relations
Organization.Description:
The purpose of this group is to bring awareness to the University of California, Berkeley campus and the surrounding community in regards to the war and the use of child soldiers in Northern Uganda, as well as to foster international relations through the implementation of a pen-pal system. We will provide support for affected families of the war through contact in the form of letters, advocacy on their behalf, and possibly fundraising. We will work closely with the Concerned Parents Association, a non-governmental organization in Northern Uganda, to achieve our goals.

We are a relatively new student group and are always looking for more members pasionate about these issues.  If you are at all interested in the war in Uganda, human rights, or social justice, please join us!

Organization.Name: Global China Connection at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Global China Connection (GCC–å?¨ç??ä¸­å?½è??æ?¥) is the world's largest International-China student organization. GCC has developed chapters at top universities in the United States, Canada, England and China all working to promote cultural
Organization.Description:
Global China Connection (GCC–å?¨ç??ä¸­å?½è??æ?¥) is the world's largest International-China student organization. GCC has developed chapters at top universities in the United States, Canada, England and China all working to promote cultural awareness and understanding, develop friendship and language exchange, as well as participate in philanthropic projects and community engagement; though most importantly, to develop a network of the top international talent of the 21st century. GCC is currently partnering with other networks and organizations including PKU's Student International Communication Association, US-China Exchange Association, Givology, China Institute, Weatherhead East Asian Institute, Peking Globalist, and many others, in an attempt to bring together the various resources and opportunities available to Chinese and Western students, in order to promote the common goals of sustainable development, social entrepreneurship, and international communication. For more information, please visit online at www.globalchinaconnection.com.

------

GCC @ UC Berkeley

As a new chapter here at Cal, we are looking for a group of distinguished and capable students who are passionate about international affairs and business communications.
Each participant has the opportunity to improve leadership and management skills, gain technical and industry experience, and expand social and business networking.
GCC, UC Berkeley Chapter plans to host events (including panels, conferences, and cocktails), stage delegations (inter-collegiate, both to and from China), and run various programs (internship and charity initiatives).

Organization.Summary: Patent Pending! is a group dedicated to promoting further understanding of patent law and policy and how it affects different areas of science and technology. Our group also provides a forum where scientists (grad students, postdocs, or
Organization.Description:
Patent Pending! is a group dedicated to promoting further understanding of patent law and policy and how it affects different areas of science and technology.  Our group also provides a forum where scientists (grad students, postdocs, or undergrads) can obtain information about careers at the intersection of law and science.

 

Come to our  Spring Social on March 3, 2010 in 421 Stanley (3:30pm to 5pm), where we will plan for our upcoming symposium, tentatively entitled "Bright Lights in a Big Thicket: Finding and Fixing Legal Uncertainty Surrounding Quantum Dot Technologies." We will also plan for officer elections which are scheduled for late March.  The available officer positions are:
1. Vice-President (assists president in organizing professional events)
2. Treasurer (maintains all club financial records, applies for grants)
3. Secretary (maintains all membership, general meeting, and election records)
4. Webpage Developer (coordinates with officers to develop club and special event webpages)

All Berkeley students, staff, and alumni are welcome to attend our events; please RSVP to our Spring Social by emailing acavazos@berkeley.edu by March 1, 2010. Light snacks and refreshments will be provided.

Organization.Name: SEEDS: Strategies for Ecology, Education, Diversity, and Sustainability
Organization.Summary: The purpose of our group is to engage student of underrepresented groups in ecology through graduate-undergraduate mentorship, field trips, community outreach, and special events.
Organization.Description:
SEEDS is a club with a lot of words in the name! But we've found ways to make it all work together. We are a Chapter of the national SEEDS program established by the Ecological Society of America. The ESA saw that diversity was lacking in the field of ecology, especially in the professional world.  They decided to address this by encouraging diversity amongst younger generations of ecologists in order to create a sustaining and lasting change.

At UC Berkeley, we wanted to see those working on sustainability efforts to represent a more diverse background.

What we do

  1. We can hook you up with some opportunities to get a grad student mentor.

  2. If you're a grad, allow you to share your experiences with an undergrad and get their help with research.

  3. Get engaged in a some environmental action going on in the vibrant city of Berkeley, and maybe even Oakland.

  4. Get experience in environmental education, teaching kids about ecology!

  5. Get involved in a nation-wide ecology program with lots of opportunities to travel and network around the country.

Either way, we always enjoy ourselves thoroughly and in one another's company!

Organization.Description: Strait Talk is a student-run, student-focused conflict transformation and dialogue program focused on the Taiwan Strait conflict and US-China relations. Organization.Name: 2048 Project for Human Rights
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to educate students and the public about the evolution of international human rights through occasional conferences and events. The student group will promote campus-wide involvement with 2048 project (www.2048.berkeley.edu) hosted by the
Organization.Description: Our mission is to educate students and the public about the evolution of international human rights through occasional conferences and events. The student group will promote campus-wide involvement with 2048 project (www.2048.berkeley.edu) hosted by the Berkeley law school. The student group will also organize campus-wide effort to contribute commenting to the drafting process of an international framework for enforceable human rights that can be in place by 2048, the 100th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Additionally, this group will conduct extensive fund-raising events for the 2048 project. The 2048 Project student group will organize bi-weekly events to discuss updates, organize events, and publish comments on the website. Furthermore, it will assist interested students to learn about internship opportunities.

Organization.Name: AAVPG - Arts and Creativity Fund
Organization.Summary: The Arts and Creativity Grant provides up to $500.00 for activities described at our home page.
Organization.Description:
Applications for Spring 2011 have hereby ended.


If you are not a member yet, click Join Organization. Once you are added as a member, you can go to Surveys & Forms to fill out the application.

 

**IMPT: You must login (top right of screen) with you calnet ID and passphrase in order to fill out an application!!**

 

Welcome and thank you for your interest in the Arts and Creativity Fund!!

 

ARTS AND CREATIVITY FUND

The Arts and Creativity Fund provides financial assistance to students and student groups that seek to enhance the exposure of visual, performing, and creative art endeavors on campus. The objective of the program is to foster greater creativity through arts on campus.  Funding is allocated to students or groups that organize and widely advertise artistic events.

Applications are accepted on a rolling basis by the ASUC Academic Affairs Office.  All registered individuals and student groups are encouraged to apply for a grant up to $500 per event.  The Committee may waive this limit under compelling circumstances.  Since all graduate and professional student fees are directed to the Graduate Assembly, undergraduates will have the highest priority for this fund, though we do encourage all students to apply.  Applicants who have not received funding in the past will be given greater consideration.  Awards are contingent upon the availability of current funds and the number of received applications.

There are 4 simple steps in applying for an ACF grant.

 

Step 1.  Starting November 10, 2010 applications will be available on this website.  Log in with your user ID and passphrase on the top right corner,  If you are not a member yet, click "Join Organization." After you are added, click on the "surveys and forms" button the the right panel and fill out the application with relevant information.  Make sure every question is answered.  The more thorough and thoughtful your answers are, the better we understand the ideals of your event.

 

Step 2.   Come to Eshelman Hall located on Lower Sproul.  Go to the second floor and sign up for an interview time in front of the AAVP Grants Office, room 205.  There will be a section specifically for MCF applicants so that they will be interviewed by someone involved in that particular fund. After you have signed up for the interview you will receive a confirmation email asking you to come back to 205 Eshelman at the time of the interview.  Interviews will be 15 minutes long. Only one representative of the applicant or applicant group should attend the interview.  Please come prepared to answer questions regarding the event details, including an itemized budget. 

 

Step 3.  After the interview, wait for an email from us to inform you about your award.  This will approximately take 2 weeks after you interview. If you are awarded a grant, ASUC Grants will also send you an email inviting you to become a 1st Stage Financial Requestor.  You will need to accept this invitation in order to file an Expenditure Request Form (ERF) to be reimbursed after your event.

 

Step 4.  After your event, please fill out a Expenditure Request Form and submit it within TWO WEEKS of the completion of your

The UC Berkeley student chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects(ASLA@Berkeley) is the student group representing all students studying landscape architecture, environmental planning and urban design (serving BLA, MLA, MLA-EP, MUD, and Ph.D students).

ASLA@Berkeley coordinates professional development and skill-building opportunities, organizes social and community service activities, and represents the student’s voice at faculty and curriculum committee meetings, to the ASUC and GA, to the CED Dean’s office and to the regional and national ASLA organizations.

Organization.Summary: The Ballet Company at Berkeley (BC@B) is UC Berkeley’s first ballet company, committed to excellence in ballet and the enrichment of the arts community on campus, as well as expanding the aesthetic horizons of both dancers and audiences.
Organization.Description: The Ballet Company at Berkeley (BC@B) is UC Berkeley’s first ballet company, committed to excellence in ballet and the enrichment of the arts community on campus, as well as expanding the aesthetic horizons of both dancers and audiences.  It will strive to provide a professional environment in which dancers and choreographers can share the joys and innovations of the art of ballet with the UC Berkeley community.

Organization.Name: Bay Against Brain Cancer
Organization.Summary: Bay Against Brain Cancer aims to find a cure for pediatric brain cancer.
Organization.Description: We plan to accomplish this by raising money, garnering awareness, and influencing public policy to support cancer research. We raise money for a lab at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center that has a record of producing groundbreaking, life-saving technologies.  Bay Against Brain Cancer is unique in that we are focused on one specific type of cancer and one research lab. After losing a friend to a brain tumor at age 11, we are passionate about ending this disease. Brain cancer is the second most common cancer in children and is one of the most difficult cancers to operate on. The lab that we raise money for is close to our hearts, as the head researcher at the lab was also our late friends' attending physician.

Organization.Name: Bay Area Student Ambassadors
Organization.Summary: We are currently a Student Initiated Service Group dedicated to showcasing our university in front of high school and community college students through local presentations and online outreach.
Organization.Description: Bay Area Student Ambassadors advocates for higher education by promoting the University of California, Berkeley at under-served high schools and community colleges on the basis of socio- economic status and need. We offer overarching knowledge of the admissions process concerning applications and alternative paths to and in higher education institutions whether it be a UC, state college, or community college. We hope to encourage students to pursue opportunities in higher education by sharing our individual stories and personal experiences. BASA members do this by participating in outreach trips at high schools and community colleges in the Bay Area.
