Organization.Name: Creative Applications to Life in Origami
Organization.Summary: Our members strive to learn how to fold simple to advanced origami (no experience required!), to be able to visualize the geometry of origami and be able to execute a diagram correctly, further learning how to "read" crease patterns. We also aim to be
Organization.Description:
Our members strive to learn how to fold simple to advanced origami (no experience required!), to be able to visualize the geometry of origami and be able to execute a diagram correctly, further learning how to "read" crease patterns. We also aim to be able to apply the concepts of origami to other use than art (i.e. physical therapy, compacting, mechanics, etc.) 
Interested in origami? Join us!

Our current and on going project is to fold 1000 cranes for various hospitals and organizations.

Organization.Name: Cultural Analysis
Organization.Summary: Cultural Analysis is an interdisciplinary, peer-reviewed journal dedicated to investigating expressive and everyday culture. The journal features analytical research articles, but also includes notes, reviews, and cross-disciplinary responses.
Organization.Description:
Cultural Analysis is global in scope, with an international editorial board.

Online Access: Cultural Analysis is published electronically in HTML and PDF formats. Access to these files is available free of charge at the Cultural Analysis website. Electronic publication of articles, notes, and reviews is ongoing.

Bound copies of current and selected previous volumes are available for purchase at Lulu.com. Free PDF downloads are also available.

Organization.Description:
Golden Bears Aikido Club (GBAC) is a student organization approved by the LEAD Center at UC Berkeley and sponsored by ASUC.

The members of GBAC train Aikido under instructions from Brandon WilliamsCraig who established Free Aiki Dojo.

 Free Aiki Trainings are from 7AM to 8AM on  Wednesday, 3:30AM to 5:30PM on Friday at Seido Karate Dojo (1934 Bonita Ave. Berkeley CA)

We train aikido at Faculty Glade on Mondays from 12 to 1PM.

Organization.Name: Goldman Health Policy Group
Organization.Summary: The Goldman Health Policy Group's purpose is to provide a forum to connect students interested in domestic health policy and related issues.
Organization.Description: Each year the group picks a "hot topic" policy focus, based on the national agenda for the year. Our goal is to provide a forum to disseminate up-to-date information about current health policy topics, to provide a venue for organized policy action, and to connect students with other health student groups on campus, including at the Law, Business, and Public Health schools.

Organization.Name: Graduate Film Working Group
Organization.Summary: GFWG
Organization.Description: Provides members with unique opportunities such as conference organization, colloquia, peer review, film screenings, and technical workshops that normally are not available to graduate students with an interest in film studies. The main purpose is t o give members with critical studies backgrounds a greater understanding of the media that they study and the social and academic communites that surround those media.

Organization.Name: Graduate Medievalists at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GMB
Organization.Description: Graduate Medievalists at Berkeley (GMB) is an organization comprised of doctoral students engaged in the study of medieval literature, history, art, music, languages, and culture at the University of California, Berkeley. Since its establishment in 1993, GMB has witnessed and actively participated in the continued growth of medieval studies here at Berkeley. By organizing lectures, faculty conversations, social activities, reading groups, and other events we have created a strong community of graduate students that extends throughout nearly every humanities and social sciences department in the University.

In a commitment to our mission of quality education and personal enrichment, GSPOC will organize and sponsor cultural activities, academic workshops and lectures as well as provide a forum of debate for improving the conditions of our education.

Organization.Name: Graduate Students for Global Development and Practice at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GDP
Organization.Description: The groups aims to connect graduate students interested in global economic, health and social development with each other and with relevant resources, programs, and centers on the UC Berkeley campus and beyond. The rationale behind the GDP is the increasingly global perspectives of students, the globalization of universities, and the expanding role of academia in problem solving to meet global challenges. Long term, the project aims to nurture and maintain a multi-disciplinary, vibrant community of students and faculty engaged in research, training, entrepreneurship and practice related to global development.

Organization.Name: Korea Campus Crusade for Christ
Organization.Summary: Korea Campus Crusade for Christ (KCCC) is a Christian campus ministry driven by students. It is established in many universities and colleges such as: UCLA, UCI, USC, UCD, UCSC, UCSB, UCSD, UCR, Cal Poly, CSUF, CSULB, CSUN, SUSJ, and much more.
Organization.Description:
KCCC's emphasis is to help out in the Great Commission as commanded by Jesus Christ in Matthew 28:18-20: 

"Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you." 

Win the campus today means for KCCC to train members to be disciples on each of their campus, sharing and witnessing the Gospel and Jesus Christ to anyone and everyone 

Win the world tomorrow means for KCCC to train members to become not just campus disciples but to extend the ministry outside of campus, to the community, and to the ends of the earth.

Organization.Name: Korean Networking Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: KNAB, officially known as Korean Undergraduate Networking Association (KUNA), provides networking ground for mainly Korean-speaking students in Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
KNAB, officially known as Korean Undergraduate Networking Association (KUNA), is one of the largest Korean clubs in UC Berkeley. It provides networking ground for mainly Korean-speaking students in Berkeley who struggles to assimilate to the new environment, providing opportunities to meet others, get recruitment info, get involved in sport subcommittees, and KORE activities.

Website: www.berkeleykorean.com

Email: admin@berkeleykorean.com

Organization.Name: La Raza Workers' Rights Clinic
Organization.Summary: To provide comprehensive legal services to immigrant, low-income and Latino communities in the Bay Area.
Organization.Description:
The Workers' Rights Clinic provides an opportunity for both undergraduate and graduate students to work directly with clients who have been impacted by wage and hour violations, employment discrimination and/or retaliation, and other areas of employment law. In particular, students are given the opportunity to meet directly with clients, prepare their demand letters or wage claims, research different areas of the law (in the event the clinic does follow-up work for the client), and in some cases, represent them at agency hearings.

Membership requirements: All members must participate in a 2-hour training session and attend four clinics per semester. Membership terms last one semester and are renewable. Membership is open to all Berkeley students. Spanish speaking ability not required as we have several members who can serve as interpreters.

Organization.Name: Latino/a Association of Graduate Students in Engineering and Science

Organization.Name: Latino/a Undergraduate Mentorship Program in Public Policy
Organization.Summary: LUMPPP
Organization.Description: Our mission is to help Latino/a undergraduate students at UC Berkeley interested in pursuing studies or careers in public policy identify academic courses and internship/fellowship/learning opportunities; promote public policy-related interests; educate Latino/a students about current public policy issues; and support students by providing academic, professional, and personal mentorship by Goldman School of Public Policy (GSPP) graduate students.

Organization.Name: Law Students of African Descent
Organization.Summary: The purpose of LSAD is to provide support for Black students at Berkeley School of Law.
Organization.Description: With this purpose in mind, our mission is threefold: (1) to facilitate the successful completion of the Juris Doctor program at Boalt Hall for every Black student at Boalt; (2) To solidify LSAD's place in Boalt Hall as an institution; and (3) to promote LSAD's influence and social responsibility through conscious advocacy and community outreach. In order to achieve these goals we will implement the following academic and social programming to the benefit of the LSAD membership and our greater diasporic community.

Organization.Name: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Incorporated
Organization.Summary: Beta Psi Chapter's aim is to enhance the quality of life for individuals within and around Northern California (East Bay), through public service, leadership development and education of youth.
Organization.Description: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was founded on November 12, 1922 on the campus of Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven accomplished community-driven young educators. They believed that the self-respect, knowledge and discipline gained through study would help individuals to recognize their duty and responsibility for their society. Founded on the precept of education, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, continues to meet the challenges of the day, promoting and encouraging high scholastic attainment, and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.

Organization.Name: State Crimes Against Democracy Policy Group
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the SCADs Policy Group of Berkeley is to examine the proliferation of State Crimes Against Democracy (SCADs) in recent US political history, understand their policy ramifications, identify structural vulnerabilities in the policy
Organization.Description: The purpose of the SCADs Policy Group of Berkeley is to examine the proliferation of State Crimes Against Democracy (SCADs) in recent US political history, understand their policy ramifications, identify structural vulnerabilities in the policy process that enable SCADs to occur, and develop policy solutions to prevent SCADs in the future.  The objectives of the group will be pursued through a series of lectures, panels and colloquia involving visiting scholars and experts, as well as student-led seminars.  State Crimes Against Democracy can be defined as concerted actions by public officials intended to manipulate democratic processes and undermine popular sovereignty in pursuit of a specific policy objective.  SCADs differ from lesser forms of political criminality in their potential to alter or distort the direction or priorities of an entire government or government agency.

Organization.Name: Steel Bridge Competition Team
Organization.Summary: ASCE's Steel Bridge Team

Organization.Name: Students for Economic and Environmental Justice
Organization.Summary: Organized through the Law School, Students for Economic & Environmental Justice is dedicated to the just distribution of environmental benefits to, and the amelioration of environmental harms in, communities of color and low-income communities

Organization.Name: Students for Integrative Medicine
Organization.Summary: Just as the name implies, we are students who have a deep interest in healthcare, both in the western modalities of medicine as well as the vast number of alternative global and cultural forms of medicine that many are unaware of.

Organization.Name: Students for the Promotion of Research and Action on Africa
Organization.Summary: Students for the Promotion of Research and Action on Africa
Organization.Description: We are an interdisciplinary organization comprised of graduate students at UC Berkeley. Our aim is threefold: 1. to promote scholarly inquiry into the political, social, economic, legal dynamics in Africa; 2 to promote action in response to pressing issues on the African continent; 3 to establish an Alumni network.

Organization.Name: Supporting Peers in Laid-Back Listening
Organization.Summary: SPILL is a free, anonymous, laid-back, and supportive organization where members of the UC Berkeley student body can "spill" via email to volunteer supporters about a variety of topics and expect a handful of helpful and anonymous replies within 24 hours
Organization.Description: SPILL's purpose is to act as a free, anonymous, laid-back, and supportive venting outlet for the UC Berkeley student body. The organization is comprised of volunteer supporters who have experience with a variety of issues relevant to college students. Interested students can "spill" whatever they want via email, and expect to receive a personalized, non-judgmental and immediate response to their problems. SPILL hopes to act as a technologically relevant, easily accessible, and completely confidential peer support network in order to support students' mental health and thereby their overall well-being.

Organization.Name: The Folio: English Academic Journal
Organization.Summary: "The Folio" is a student-run academic journal of the English Undergraduate Association. It publishes short undergraduate student-written literary analysis essays.
Organization.Description:
The purpose and objective of The Folio is twofold:

 

1. To provide an avenue for undergraduate English majors at Berkeley through which to publish their short literary analysis essays, and to reciprocally distribute these essays as an educational resource to Berkeley undergraduates.

 

2.To supply a platform for Berkeley undergraduates interested in literature in English to explore and gain experience in the business of publication and academic scholarship.

Organization.Description:
Universal Love and Peace is an organization that intends to spread awareness on human rights.  In unison with supporting groups, U.L.A.P. achieves this goal through community service, musical and dancing performances, demonstrations, fundraising events, community service retention and outreach, peaceful dialogue, speeches, weekly tutoring, and human rights proposals for legislative change.

 

goals:

We are also working to develop programs that support Math graduate students who come from traditionally underrepresented groups, as well as the wider community of Math graduate students.

Organization.Name: African Arts Society
Organization.Summary: The African Arts Society is a student-led, community service organization whose purpose shall be to confront misrepresentation and manipulation of Black art.
Organization.Description: Whereas, The African Arts Society is a student-led, community service organization whose purpose shall be to confront misrepresentation and manipulation of Black art, as to avoid long-term, adverse social effects on African and African Descent communities in the world; andWhereas, Including all forms of visual, digital, and performing arts, this society aims to encourage social change by celebrating the beauty and resilience of African and African Descent populations throughout the world with positive and productive representations of art; andWhereas, The African Arts Society functions under Afrocentric principles believing that there is unparalleled value in empowering communities of the African Diaspora to represent themselves in art; andWhereas, This organization will encourage artists from these communities to use their skills to spread awareness about important and urgent issues in Black communities; andWheras, The African Arts Society will enhance all communities at the University of California, Berkeley through its dedication to increasing education around African People; andWhereas, Through providing safe spaces to enjoy art in programs aimed at activism, the society enables more people to consider different perspectives and decrease prejudice; andWhereas, The student groups will host programs, outreach to the local communities, and build relationships across a diversity of cultures. Included in all events and initiative will be a focus of appreciating African art; and Whereas, By utilizing art as a form of activism, the society shall promote and support social justice causes related to African and African Descent communities and concerns.Therefore Be it Resolved, that the ASUC recognize the African Arts Society as a first year ASUC-sponsored student organization.

Organization.Name: Air Force ROTC
Organization.Summary: TBD

Organization.Name: Artists in Resonance
Organization.Summary: Artists in Resonance, commonly known as AiR, is Berkeley's premiere co-ed A Cappella group. Our repertoire includes self-arranged pieces, everything from alternative rock and hip-hop to traditional fight songs and Top 40 hits.
Organization.Description:
Artists in Resonance, casually known on campus as AiR!, is the premiere independent co-ed a cappella group based out of the University of California, Berkeley. From our humble beginnings in 1987, We now have fourteen amazing performers, performing every Monday at noon underneath Sather Gate on campus. Our repertoire includes self-arranged pieces, everything from alternative rock and hip-hop to traditional fight songs and Top 40 hits.

During the school year, you can find us singing on Sproul Plaza, but don’t be surprised if you also see us at the Telegraph Street Fair, Jack London Square, or even Santa Cruz! We also perform all over California at numerous events. We have made appearances at the Annual Big Sing-Off (UC Berkeley/Stanford), the California A Cappella Festival (UC Los Angeles), the West Coast A Cappella Showcase (UC Berkeley), and the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella.

Interested in hiring us? Email gigs@artistsinresonance.com

Interested in auditioning? Email auditions@artistsinresonance.com

Organization.Name: ASUC Green Certification Program
Organization.Summary: The goal of the A.S.U.C Green Certification Program is to encourage and educate student groups that are not necessarily focused on sustainability (i.e. cultural, service groups, performance groups, etc.) about ways their groups can reduce their
Organization.Description: The goal of the A.S.U.C Green Certification Program is to encourage and educate student groups that are not necessarily focused on sustainability (i.e. cultural, service groups, performance groups, etc.) about ways their groups can reduce their environmental footprint both on and off-campus. The program gives official recognition to student groups that make concerted efforts to become greener and encourages green purchasing via the Green Fund.

Organization.Name: Bay Area Urban Debate League Volunteers
Organization.Summary: The BAUDL Bears are Berkeley students committed to opening opportunities for young people in underserved schools in the Bay Area to succeed in competitive debate. WE work in collaboration with the Bay Area Urban Debate League (BAUDL) and
Organization.Description: The BAUDL Bears are Berkeley students committed to opening opportunities for young people in underserved schools in the Bay Area to succeed in competitive debate. WE work in collaboration with the Bay Area Urban Debate League (BAUDL) and the school districts it serves to help students build the skills and dispositions to succeed academically and to become confident, capable leaders for their communities.

Organization.Name: Berkeley City College Service Community
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley City College Service Community (BCCSC) brings UC Berkeley and Berkeley City College students together in service to develop leadership and assist community college students in the transfer process.
Organization.Description: The Berkeley City College Service Community (BCCSC) brings UC Berkeley and Berkeley City College students together in service to develop leadership and assist community college students in the transfer process. Our mission is to increase support for prospective transfer students and provide them with enhanced leadership and service opportunities. We believe student involvement is crucial in the college experience and vital to producing active citizens prepared for the world.  With access to education as a pressing social justice issue around the world, the BCCSC involves students in affecting the global issue of education by acting locally in their own communities.

Organization.Name: Bezerkeley
Organization.Summary: Bezerkeley is dedicated to the practice and evaluation of art as a catalyst for reflection and social change. Bezerkeley aims to allow students to provide themselves with the opportunity to use practice and evaluate art to change society and their lives.
Organization.Description:
Bezerkeley Constitution

Updated 3/20/2013

 

Mission:

 

Bezerkeley is dedicated to the practice and evaluation of art as a catalyst for reflection and social change. Bezerkeley aims to allow students to provide themselves with the opportunity to use practice and evaluate art to change society and their lives.  We believe art can heal on the individual and societal level, a necessity to explore for expressing creative talent and discovering the world. Bezerkeley realizes the new age in art is handmade self-projects with local collaboration.  Celebrating the products and process of meaningful arts.

 

Article I – Name

 

The exact title for this group is Bezerkeley.  Some may refer to this group as Bezerkeley Art.

 

Article II – Purpose

 

The purpose of this group is to practice and evaluate art as a catalyst for social reflection and change.

 

Article III – Membership

 

In order to join Bezerkeley, one must have a passion to learn.

 

Only currently registered students, faculty, and staff may be active members in a registered student organization. Only active members may vote or hold office.

We will not haze according to California State Law. 

We will not restrict membership based upon race, color, national origin, religion, sex, physical and mental disability, medical condition (cancer-related or genetic characteristics), ancestry, marital status, age, sexual orientation, citizenship or status as a covered veteran (special disabled veteran, Vietnam-era veteran or any other veteran who served on active duty during a war or in a campaign or expedition for which a campaign badge has been authorized).

While only current registered Berkeley students faculty and staff may be active members. Bezerkeley accepts does not discriminate those outside the Berkeley sphere and opens up official membership to all citizens and energy of the universe.

Article IV – Officers and Elections

Co-President: Miles Mathews

The president works with all members of the organization to make decisions based on consensus.  Influential membership is not a right to the active member, rather a status that is won through trust and commitment. The influential members vote on the figurehead of the president.  There are no restrictions for how long someone can stay in office as president.  Elections come during the current semester before it is time to register for decals for the next semester. 

Co-President: Calvin Li

Calvin Li shares the presidency with Miles Mathews as another figurehead of the organization. As figure heads, Bezerkeley and members look to the presidents for leadership and opinions.

 

Article V – Meetings

Meetings can occur at any time called by any member. Meetings are not mandatory, members know and choose when it is time to participate.  Due to Bezerkeley’s call to action nature, projects are often created the day of due to unique opportunities that arise. Sometimes a meeting is just a phone call between two or more members.  Large projects act as meetings and actions that involve the majority of the members.  Bezerkeley often hosts a decal class that acts as a meeting once a week as a trampoline for inspiration and reflection.

Article VI – Constitutional Amendments

 

Amendments to the constitution can be proposed by any member of the group and are voted on by every member of the group.  The proposition can pass with group consensus.  Amendments should be proposed in meetings and voted on in the next meeting.

All amendments, additions or deletions to this document must be filed with the Center for Student Leadership in 102 Sproul Hall.

All amendments, additions or deletions must be filed with the ASUC Office of Student Affairs, 400 Eshleman Hall, within one week of adoption.

 

Article VII – Dissolution

 

Any member of the group can call for dissolution if he feels it is in the best interest of the group to discontinue.

All unspent ASUC funds shall remain the property of the ASUC, all Graduate Assembly funds shall remain the property of the Graduate Assembly. Remaining privately-obtained funds may be donated to another nonprofit organization with prior approval of the ASUC Senate Finance Committee.

 

Article VIII – Activities

Students in Bezerkeley are prompted to think of creative ideas for apparel and artwork.  Some of the ideas will be turned into silk-screened or spray-painted apparel or art.  This apparel/art will be sold on Sproul.  Some of the profit made from the sales of this clothing will go to fund the Bezerkeley Decal in which students will learn how to create custom shirts through spray paint and possibly screen-printing.

Organization.Name: Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley is to provide a study group for students of Classical and Historical fencing who are training in and/or researching any of the various forms of heritage/traditional or reconstructed Western
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley is to provide a study group for students of Classical and Historical fencing who are training in and/or researching any of the various forms of heritage/traditional or reconstructed Western Martial Arts.  The group will give special attention to the pedagogy and practice of living lineages of traditional fencing as a basis for study.  The secondary goal of the group is to provide group members with a direct connection to the Classical fencing that existed in the early 20th and late 19th century in the Berkeley area. 

 

To achieve this, the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley draws on the expertise of local and non-local Classical fencing masters and certified instructors as well as the support of dedicated students and scholars of Classical fencing and non-profit organizations such as the Association for Historical Fencing. 

 

The meetings of this organization will help Classical fencers find ways to train the techniques and theory of Classical fencing but who may not have access to regular classes or training partners in Berkeley.  Having training partners is essential to fencing, because fencing, like any martial art, is a kinesthetic art that requires movement, sensibility, and interaction with other human beings much the way partner dance does. 

 

Today, Classical fencing is a rare traditional martial art that is not widely practiced.  Practicing Classical fencing will help to preserve its theory and philosophy and ensure its survival alongside more widely available and practiced modern styles of fencing (i.e. “sport” or “Olympic” fencing) that have departed from the traditional way of thinking and practicing. 

 

What makes the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley unique from other organizations is its focus on Classical theory in fencing, or fencing as a martial art, which treats training, bouting, academic assaults, etc. with the same respect and sincerity that good traditional fencing masters have always given to training for and participation in real combative encounters or duels.  This sort of training is contrasted with that of modern fencing which often trains to the rules of the sport or game of fencing as is defined by organizations such as the United States Fencing Association (USFA) and the Federation Internationale d’Escrime (FIE); the Historical Fencing Club of Berkeley recognizes “modern,” “sport,” “Olympic,” and other synonymous styles of fencing training as inappropriate and dangerous in the context of martial arts training.

Organization.Name: Human Journal at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Human Journal is a publication on campus created to break down stereotypes by sharing stories. All the stories are personal, specific, and true, and they are published with the hope that reading them will make the Cal campus feel a little smaller.
Organization.Description:
The Human Journal builds communities on the Cal campus in two ways. The first, more obvious, way is through the publication. The publication is a collection of true, personal, and specific stories written by Berkeley affiliates (students, faculty, staff. . .) with the intention of letting us know each other a little better.

The second way that HJB builds community is through the staff. The staff of the Human Journal are a close knit group of individuals dedicated to making Cal a little bit friendlier and a little bit more welcoming. They know each other well, and support each other not just in journal related issues, but in life.

Organization.Description: We work towards these goals through programming that addresses issues of faith, spirituality and religious affiliation to promote a faith-positive campus, as well as supporting a safe and secure space for students to express themselves openly and honestly. We aspire towards establishing and supporting an interfaith community which works together for social change, open dialogue, cross-cultural understanding that is sustainable and representative of the holistic student experience.

Organization.Summary: JEWSE
Organization.Description: JEWSE of the University of California, Berkeley is determined to motivate its members to reach their full potential as engineers and leaders, to provide a venue for Jewish engineering students to embrace their religion, culture, and heritage, and to help these students immerse themselves in the values and lessons contained therein. This multi-faceted mission will seek to create well-rounded engineering leaders who will also be the Jewish community leaders of tomorrow.We will apply Jewish values to influence our actions in professional and personal dealings, enhancing our integrity, morality, virtue, and honor. These Jewish morals will be ever-present in our activities, which will include networking, professional development, group interaction, and community outreach. While the organization will embrace Jewish values, customs, and traditions, and will explore how they apply to the field of engineering, it will be open to all students, regardless of faith or major.

Organization.Description:
MCBcDNA (Molecular & Cell Biology, Cell Developmental, Neurobiological Association) serves the needs of the Molecular and Cell Biology undergraduate community, providing our peers with the resources for success!

As a club, we provide a liaison between student and faculty members through a variety of organized events and workshops (e.g. MCB Emphasis Night, Research Night, MCAT Night, Summer Opportunities Night, and many more).

Aside from our duty to the MCB community, MCBcDNA provides a medium for its members to prepare for the professional world. Club members will develop essential social, organizational, and communication skills as they interact with their club peers, plan events for the MCB community, and participate in MCBcDNA.

Organization.Description: mcbUSA works in tandem with the MCB Undergraduate Advising Office (UAO) and other MCB clubs to provide information and a student perpsective on the MCB major. We hold events each semester that connects students with professors and each other, while striving to make the MCB major and its 5 emphases more understandable to current and prospective MCB students. We also realize that there are many career and further education options available for MCB students, and we work to hold events that reveal more about these choices as well.

Organization.Name: Neighborhoods Vision Project
Organization.Summary: NVP is a collaborative community service initiative that seeks to mobilize youth from various San Francisco neighborhoods to design, implement, and work together in community service projects in each other’s neighborhoods.
Organization.Description:
NVP pursues this mission by training college students to train youth leaders to conduct a leadership program at San Francisco high schools designed to unite youth with the vision of peace through interaction with different people of diverse cultures and neighborhoods. NVP offers an opportunity to engage in proactive ways to tackle issues of racism, youth violence, and environmental and social justice to foster positive relationships in our society.

Fiscally sponsored by the Metta Center for Nonviolence, Neighborhood Vision Project is a social business, national community service organization, and registered student chapter at the University of California, Berkeley. NVP is a collaborative community service initiative that seeks to mobilize youth from various San Francisco neighborhoods to design, implement, and work together in community service projects in each other’s neighborhoods.

Mission
Professional Development, Social, and Philanthropy

General Information
The Delta Tau/UC Berkeley chapter is the newest member of the national coeducational business fraternity, Phi Gamma Nu. The chapter was established in August 2010 and officially initiated into the Phi Gamma Nu brotherhood in April 2011.

Phi Gamma Nu prides itself on the diversity of brothers within our fraternity. Along with helping brothers and pledges in their application to the Haas School of 
Business, Phi Gamma Nu also welcomes those with business interests, no matter the major. Brothers of Phi Gamma Nu strive to uphold the fraternity's pillars of Professional Development, Social, and Philanthropy throughout their college career.

Organization.Name: Toxicology Student Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ToxSA supports students in the Molecular Toxicology major and non-majors interested in the field of toxicology by providing peer advising, career preparation, and community service opportunities.
Organization.Description:
ToxSA supports students in the Molecular Toxicology major and non-majors
interested in the field of toxicology by providing peer advising, career
preparation, and community service opportunities as well as exploring past
and current issues in toxicology.

Peer Advising-
Our peer advising services allow students in the same classes to get
together and form study groups as well as allow upper class-man to talk
with the lower class-man to direct and guide them through the courses at
Berkeley.

Community Service
A program sponsored by ToxSA called the Lead Education Awareness Program
(LEAP) allows students to become involved with toxicology related
community service. LEAP is a program that allows students to educate
children in low-income areas about the dangers from household hazards,
lead, and air pollution.

Career Prep-
Our career preparation services support students by touring the career
center, holding a resume writing workshop, and holding brown bag lunches
with the professors in the Molecular Toxicology department at Berkeley. 
Members of ToxSA also become members of the NorCal Society of Toxicology
(SOT).  This service has given students the opportunity to talk with real
life toxicologists in the field and learn what day to day life is like in
different toxicology fields.

ToxSA supports students not only through their years at Berkeley, but also
helps them for the future by exploring careers and networking

Organization.Name: C.R.E.A.T.E.
Organization.ShortName: Creative Residencies for Emerging Artists Teaching Empowerment
Organization.Summary: CREATE is a brand-new residency internship program at Cal Corps Public Service Center that gives artists, dancers, actors, filmmakers, and others an opportunity to apply creative skills through public service.
Organization.Description:
CREATE is a brand-new residency internship program at Cal Corps Public Service Center that gives artists, dancers, actors, filmmakers, and others an opportunity to apply creative skills through public service.

CREATE partners with Bay Area schools to place Cal student interns in their afterschool programs. Interns usually work in pairs to co-teach an afterschool enrichment arts, theater, or dance class. 

Applying to CREATE 

CREATE accepts applications for students interested in being an intern in August and early September for fall semester and in late January for spring. If you are interested in finding out more, contact us at calcreate@gmail.com. To apply, please click on the following link: Create Application Fall 2013.

For more information on the program please visit: http://publicservice.berkeley.edu/create

Organization.Description: The UCB Comparative Literature Undergraduate Journal will showcase the best undergraduate work in comparative literature across the nation as well as highlight more contemplative writing by students regarding multicultural issues, culture shock, or transnational experiences such as studying abroad.The bulk of the journal will be devoted to serious undergraduate work (such as honors theses) treating a broad range of topics including but not limited to theoretical literary discourse, international trends in literature, and comparisons of two particular national literatures.

Organization.Name: Danza In Xochitl In Cuicatl
Organization.Summary: Danza In Xochitl In Cuicatl provides a space for students to learn indigenous Mexica culture including dance, music, and history; we share this knowledge with the UC campus community; and promote research on Abya Yalan indigenous cultures.
Organization.Description:
The purpose of Danza In Xochitl In Cuicatl is to provide a space for students to learn and learn indigenous Mexica culture including dance, music, and history; to share this knowledge with the campus community; and to promote research on Abya Yalan indigenous cultures.  For the past ten years, the calpulli (organization) has provided a space on campus for students, faculty, staff, and community members to participate in danza mexica.  Our group invites other Danza and non-danza groups to participate in our calpulli.  We do not exclude anyone because of race, gender, sexuality or class.

 

The group will continue learning and becoming part of the rich traditions of danza Mexica community in the Bay Area, as well as sharing this knowledge to the greater campus.  The group aims to contribute to the production and transmission of indigenous knowledge and integrate danza into the members lifestyles and spirituality.

Organization.Name: Design For America
Organization.Summary: Design For America teaches human centered design, collaborating community partners and implements innovative solutions based on insights into human needs, rapid prototyping, user-testing, and interdisciplinary team work.
Organization.Description:
Nationally acclaimed and featured in Fast Company, Forbes, and the Chicago Tribune, DFA beautifully integrates the art of design with community engagement to tackle local issues. 

Using the human-centered design lens, interdisciplinary students are trained to scope glocal challenges, discover who their users are through deep dives and community partnerships, and derive solutions that address their users’ needs and desires. Design for America works outside the academic calendar so that all projects can be deadline-less, and student teams can work on their projects further into implementation.


ANY major is encouraged to participate! 

Join the likes of Barnard/Columbia, RISD/Brown, Cornell, Dartmouth, Northwestern, Stanford, UCLA and UO Eugene on the collaborative effort to tackling issues of the immediate community by helping kick-start UC Berkeley's own studio!

If you'd like to know more about the program, please visit designforamerica.com, and if you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact us at dfaberkeley@gmail.com.

Organization.Name: DIBS - Department of Integrative Biology Students
Organization.Summary: Supports the academic, professional and social development of students in, and interested in, the Integrative Biology major
Organization.Description:
Despite the numerous biology student organizations on campus, there is no available forum for Integrative Biology students. Our organization hopes to strengthened the unity between students and professors within the large department as well as highlight the courses and opportunities offered from Integrative Biology department. However, even though this organization centers around the Integrative Biology major, it is opened to students of all majors with an interest in biology.

Moreover, other biology organizations focus on a specific aspect of biology, but the Department of Integrative Biology Students wants to educate and unite students who are interested in a holistic study of biology. Certain topics such as evolution, ecology, animal science, and much more are often not discussed by other existing biology clubs, but this organization will focus on highlighting these topics as well as topics in biology regarding human and health sciences, thereby creating and sharing an integrated approach to the field of biology.

Organization.Description: Dr. Interns is the premier non-profit program for medical and health care internships abroad. Our organization is dedicated to providing not only a career enhancing experience, but a life changing one. Interns work side-by-side with doctors in developing countries to save lives and improve conditions. When interns aren�t at the hospital or clinic, they explore the country with locals, immersing themselves in culture, food, and making new friends. We share their travels by hosting their blogs, pictures, and videos on our site.

Organization.Description:
eSports at Berkeley is a student group devoted to promoting competitive videogames on the Berkeley campus. It is an outlet for other eSports fans to meet together and compete together in intercollegiate competitions such as CSL.

The Collegiate Starleague (CSL) is an intercollegiate StarCraft/LoL/DotA 2 league for North American colleges and universities. Members will take part in the CSL which now has over 240 participating schools and get an opportunity to meet others who also love eSports. eSports at Berkeley also provides an excellent gateway to those who are interested in eSports in general, as we have weekly social events, practices, and viewing parties.

eSports at Berkeley was formerly Collegiate Star League at Berkeley

Organization.Summary: Feeding Forward connects those with excess food to those in need through technology. Our vision is to assure no one goes hungry, no food is wasted, and no one is denied the opportunity or assistance to become self-sufficient.
Organization.Description: Feeding Forward (formerly known as BareAbundance) is built on grassroots action and community support; the project links volunteers directly to the Berkeley and Oakland communities. Essentially, we will distribute excess consumable foods from a network of local restaurants and cafes, farmer’s markets, UCB cooperative houses, Greek housing, local organic gardens, and small farms. This food will be afforded proper care by the Feeding Forward (formerly known as BareAbundance) team who will then redistribute the food to local shelters and low-income areas.

Organization.Description: Klesis is Greek for ‘divine calling’ or ‘invitation;’ God’s invitation and his divine calling first and foremost. We live it out, striving to be the church together: not only for believers and disciples, but also for our friends whose earnest and reasonable questions have gone too long unanswered in a culture jaded by religion but still intrigued by spirituality. We talk, eat, laugh, go out, study the bible, pray, study, share and more. We invite you to Klesis.

Organization.Name: Labor Justice Project
Organization.Summary: LJP is a student organization at UC Berkeley that organizes students around workers rights, economic justice, community organizing, and the labor movement.
Organization.Description:
Labor Justice Project is a student organization at UC Berkeley that works to energize students and young people around workers rights struggles, economic justice, community organizing, and the labor movement.

We are dedicated to:

  • Organizing students and young people to engage in labor/worker solidarity and economic justice campaigns locally and worldwide.
  • Educating students and the community about the labor movement and workers' struggles for social justice, especially workers often marginalized and excluded such as immigrant workers, women workers, and non-unionized workers.
  • Training students to be activists and organizers in the labor rights and economic justice movements. 
  • Actively opposing racism, sexism, classism, imperialism, homophobia/heterosexism, transphobia, ableism, and all other forms of oppression in our work, movements, and society. We support the struggle for social justice and collective liberation for all.

Meetings are held on Thursdays from 6-7 pm in the Barbara Christiansen Room (5th floor of Barrows). All are welcome and encouraged to come!

Organization.Name: Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Incorporated

Organization.Description:
LASSO:

  • Provides a forum to inform students of campus resources related to Latin America such as research grants, research opportunities, study abroad opportunities, access to special seminars and events, on-campus awards and honors, and mentorships.
  • Provides a forum where students can discuss Latin American issues and network with other interested in Latin American during brownbag lunches, film screenings, and social events.
  • Seeks to increase the number of students on campus who are interested in Latin America and encourage students to focus on Latin America within their majors.

Organization.Summary: GA Science and Engineering Community Outreach

Organization.Name: Medievalisms
Organization.Summary: We are dedicated to exploring the Middle Ages outside the Middle Ages.
Organization.Description: From chess to Chaucer, the Crusades to the Vikings, and the parliament to the university, the legacy of the Middle Ages can be found almost everywhere in contemporary institutions and culture. We interrogate how medievalisms are produced discursively and how the fluid referent of the �medieval� is deployed across cultures and mediums for aesthetic and ideological purposes. From pop culture to high theory, the medieval as �other� produces periodizations that lay the foundations of cultural and institutional identities.Using the Middle Ages as a nexus, we aim to foster a dialogue between classicists, medievalists, and modernists. From a fundamentally interdisciplinary standpoint, we are committed to rethinking the divisions within and between departments based on these periodizations. Our biweekly reading group focuses on medievalism in many contexts: film, literature, and theory; reenactments, performances, and festivals; religion, politics, and law; poetry, music, and visual arts; tourism, Eurocentrism, and globalization. The "medieval" forms the object, not the subject, of our study.

Organization.Name: Microfinance at Berkeley
Organization.Summary:
Microfinance at Berkeley (SB 148 Fall 2012 Submitted to ASUC Senate 10/31/12)
originally established by SB 105 S12 4/4/12 as Archer's Microfinance Institute as SAG
Organization.Description: Berkeley Microfinance is a UC Berkeley student-run group with a mission to alleviate poverty in the Bay Area by offering entrepreneurs access to financial resources and microloans. We promote entrepreneurialism in Berkeley and Oakland by facilitating 0% interest loans on Kiva Zip and through a student-led credit building and business training curriculum that we are currently developing.

Organization.Name: National Society of Collegiate Scholars
Organization.Summary: NSCS is an honor society that engages high-achieving first- and second-year students in the top 20% of their class.
Organization.Description: NSCS has established chapters at more than 300 schools across the country and more than 800,000 members. We are a proud member of the Association of College Honor Societies. NSCS exists to recognize and elevate high-achievers. We are dedicated to the ideals of Scholarship, Leadership and Service; ideals that are evident in every benefit and scholarship we offer. For over 17 years, our members have been united by scholarship and empowered to succeed.

Organization.Name: Olive Tree Initiative
Organization.Summary: The Olive Tree Initiative aims to promote dialogue and discussion regarding the Israeli-Arab conflict. Promotes civil, educational and intellectual dialogue concerning the Palestinian-Israeli conflict
Organization.Description: This educational, student-led initiative is modeled after empiricism - gaining knowledge through experience. Students travel to the region and learn about the conflict from a personal perspective, independent of the media. OTI also brings a variety of expert speakers and educational events to campus to help enrich the school-wide community.

Organization.Name: Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated
Organization.Summary: The mission of Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated is to serve and educate people of diverse backgrounds through sisterhood, leadership and guidance.
Organization.Description:
Established with ASUC 11/9/11 SB 137 Fall 2011

After 3 years of hard work, dedication, and perseverance, Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated received recognition by the Pan-Hellenic Council at the University of California, Berkeley. In May of 2011, five strong and dedicated women took Berkeley by storm as members of Omega Phi Beta Sorority, Incorporated first UC Berkeley line, Alpha line. These women came together to create an opportunity for other women at UC Berkeley to also find a sisterhood that they could identify with. Although many women were unable to join the sisterhood as undergraduates, and become part of the Alpha line, their hard work and dedication is and will forever be recognized.

Organization established with ASUC 11/2/11 SB 122 Fall 2011

One Economy at Berkeley is a student service organization focused on executing digital literacy trainings in the city of Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Paws and Claws of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To provide opportunities for students to interact and care for dogs and cats of need in the city of Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
Paws and Claws of Berkeley is a student organization at UC Berkeley that provides opportunities for students to help animals in need. 

You can foster a dog or a cat as a college student without worrying about leaving it alone over winter and summer breaks! Or you can just play and cuddle with them when you like!

We currently have two programs, one that provides students the opportunity to volunteer at the Berkeley Animal Shelter, and the other one provides students the opportunity to foster dogs and cats in their pet-friendly apartments.

Can't make it to one of our meetings? Catch us on Sproul, or email pnc.berkeley@gmail.com!

Also, invite all your friends and anyone you think will be interested to our meetings, events, and fundraisers!

Organization.Name: ReUSE
Organization.Summary: ReUSE is UC Berkeley's #1 organization when it comes to diverting reusable materials from landfills. We host Reader Giveaways, Clothing Sales, Office/Dorm Move-outs and run 15+ ReUSE Stations on campus! Contact ucberkeleyreuse@gmail.com for more info.
Organization.Description:
This past year, we gave away over 5,000 pounds of furniture for free from Eshleman Hall, and every semester we give away free readers and sell clothings which we collect during Move-Out in May. We also fosters the spirit of reusing materials instead of throwing them away by providing ReUSE stations across campus. We are a small student organization looking to expand by establishing a board of directors.

ReUSE is UC Berkeley's #1 organization when it comes to diverting reusable materials from landfills. We host Reader Giveaways, Clothing Sales, Office/Dorm Move-outs and run 15+ ReUSE Stations on campus! Contact ucberkeleyreuse@gmail.com for more info.

Organization.Name: San Quentin Education Project
Organization.Summary: The San Quentin Education Project aims to help improve educational opportunities available to prisoners housed at San Quentin State Prison.
Organization.Description: The San Quentin Education Project aims to help improve educational opportunities available to prisoners housed at San Quentin State Prison. The program will serve as a "clearing house" of sorts, coordinating efforts of the Berkeley Law community to partner with organizations currently providing education services at San Quentin. In the short-term, the program will focus on plugging Boalt students into existing programs; beginning in the Fall 2012 semester, however, Boalt students will play a greater role in designing and implementing curricula based on their particular interests and skills. Overall, the aim will be to foster a culture of volunteerism connecting Boalt and San Quentin, and to increase Boalt students' involvement with the CA corrections and rehabilitation system.

Organization.Name: Transnational Mixed Asians In-Between Spaces
Organization.Summary: To create an interdisciplinary space for mixed race studies dialogue and to provide a safe space for scholars to discuss issues of mixed race identity.
Organization.Description: In traditional Ethnic Studies categories, mixed race has been marginalized, misappropriated, tokenized or simply left out. In order to allow for a collaborative environment given the use of essentialized racial categories and the lack of scholarship on the experiences of mixed race people, the purposes of TMABS are follows: to create an interdisciplinary space for mixed race studies dialogue and to provide a safe space for scholars to discuss issues of mixed race identity. This group will also serve as a space for scholars doing work on this topic to present work current projects and to discuss collaboration on future research projects. We also plan to compose panels for conferences such as the Critical Mixed Race Studies Conference and the Association for Asian American Studies Conference as an organization. Some of the group members' research interests include mixed race identity and the US Census, mixed race youth political activism, Amerasian studies (Okinawan, Vietnamese, and other sites of US military involvement in Asia), transnational discourse, the Asian diaspora in Latin America and the effects of conquest and colonization on indigenous Asian peoples. A few of the theories the group is interested in exploring are Grounded Theory, Critical Race Theory, Racial Formation Theory, Mestizaje/Borderlands theory (Anzaldua) and theories of hybridity and the third space (Bhabaha). Overall, as a result of the discussions in the organization, we hope to encourage and promote research on this topic, to solidify a legitimate space in academia for the study of mixed race/bi-cultural/transnational peoples and to bring together scholars from multiple disciplines and research areas to collaborate on future research in this area.

Organization.Name: World Literacy Project at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: World Literacy Project seeks to positively impact the lives of children locally, nationally, and internationally by focusing on literacy and gender equality in education.
Organization.Description:
*General meetings on Wednesday at 7 pm in 215 Dwinelle. Join us!

We at the World Literacy Project believe that literacy is the key to a better world. This year, we will be hosting two reading programs for elementary students in partnership with the Berkeley Public Library and John Muir Elementary School, working with local and international NGOs to raise literacy awareness and designing another literacy program that Cal students will implement abroad over Summer 2014.

Begun in 2010, WLP has demonstrated its commitment to service by initiating literacy programs, supporting 9 Cal students to build a school in Nicaragua, hosting a Global Child Issues Forum in partnership with several SF-based nonprofits, designing a computer literacy curriculum in Guatemala and more! We regularly educate ourselves on cost-effective poverty solutions during general meetings, and continually seek partnerships with NGOs and other student groups to promote activism on the three topics we care about the most: poverty alleviation, literacy, and gender equity.

*E-mail us at worldliteracyproject@gmail.com
*Facebook group at http://www.facebook.com/groups/126992470712170/

Organization.Summary: The Youth Empowerment Program (YEP) provides a network of support and hope to immigrant children held in federal custody by connecting them to student role models from the University of California.
Organization.Description: Far from loved ones, family members and any support networks they may have, unaccompanied immigrant children face many challenges. YEP uses a five-month curriculum to help detained youth develop teamwork and leadership skills, reflect upon their past and make positive plans for their future while connecting with college student mentors. YEP provides an extensive leadership training program for volunteers by bringing in experts in the social work, psychology and legal fields with the purpose of building future leaders for social justice. YEP volunteers utilize their leadership immediately by working with detained unaccompanied immigrant children every other week and engaging in direct community outreach.

Organization.Name: Bay Area Scientists in Schools at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: GA Bay Area Scientists in Schools
Organization.Description:
Program Goals

Bay Area Scientists in Schools (BASIS) is a science role model volunteer program for public elementary schools in the East Bay.

The goals of BASIS are to connect a diverse range of scientist volunteers to elementary and middle school students and teachers, to inspire students with examples of real-world science careers and issues, to engage students in hands-on, inquiry based learning experiences, and to create effective teaching links between scientists and public elementary schools.

Program Mechanics

Community Resources for Science (CRS) works with BASIS volunteers to help develop hands-on activities that are age-appropriate and based in the California Science Standards. Scientists then select dates and times that they are available to visit classrooms to make lesson presentations, and teachers are invited to sign up for presentations as they become available. "Tremendous! More, please!" is the top comment CRS hears from teachers who've had a BASIS visit.

Scientists may work solo or in teams to develop a presentation to take to multiple classrooms over the course of a school year.

Organization.Description:
The Pantry Project is a program to build up a reserve of non-perishable food parcels for low-income UC students with dependent children. Food packages are available to such families in case of food shortfalls during the semester; each one with enough non-perishable food to feed a family of three for two weeks. Families eligible to receive an emergency package are full-time UC students with children,experiencing a shortage of food during the academic semester.

100 Cesar Chavez Student Center
Berkeley, CA, CA 94720-4260
Phone: (510) 776-8486

Organization.Name: Beyond Academia
Organization.Summary: Beyond Academia is a graduate student and postdoc-run career education conference that aims to expose PhDs to career options outside of academia.
Organization.Description:
The second annual Beyond Academia conference will take place on February 20 and 21, 2014 at the International House on the UC Berkeley campus.

Keynote speakers this year are Peter Fiske and Ellen Levy.

 

Focus areas

DAY 1: use your science

Focus on careers that require specific technical skills or knowledge that is directly related to your current research.

DAY 2: use your translatable skills

Focus on careers that value the critical thinking, management, and communication skills acquired during your training, independent of your area of research.

 

Who should attend?

The conference is targeted at both PhD students and postdocs. If you are considering a career outside of academia or are simply interested in hearing about many career options available to PhDs, we encourage you to attend.

 

For more information please visit: www.beyondacademia.org

For questions, contact us at info@beyondacademia.org

Organization.Description: Embrace is a social enterprise that aims to help the millions of vulnerable babies born every year in developing countries through a low cost infant warmer. Unlike traditional incubators that cost up to $20,000, the Embrace Infant Warmer costs less than 1% of this price. The device does not require constant electricity, is portable and is safe and intuitive to use. This spring, Embrace will be launching in the state of Karnataka, India. Embrace- the Berkeley Chapter seeks to promote and advance the efforts of Embrace via fundraising and awareness activities.

Organization.Summary: Get On The Bus is a program of The Center for Restorative Justice Works, a non profit organization that unites children, families and communities separated by crime and the criminal justice system throughout California.
Organization.Description:
Get On The Bus is a program of The Center for Restorative Justice Works, a non profit organization that unites children, families and communities separated by crime and the criminal justice system throughout California.

Get on the Bus - Berkeley is a part of this project, aiming to raise awareness of the situation of these children as well as raising money in order to help these children to get in contact, and to stay in contact with their parents.

By reuniting children with their parents, and by helping them stay in contact throughout their imprisonment, our hope is to lessen the probability of these children following in their parents footsteps, as well as increasing the possibility that their parents will not become repeated offenders.

Check out our inspiring information video at YouTube; http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3p7xiQAbTM&feature=youtu.be

Mission

To provide the highest quality services and programs that ease a student's transition through the University and in the greater community, and to provide all our customers-- students, faculty, staff and guests--with a quality customer experience.

Vision
To become the pre-eminent student services and residential program in the country.

Values
As part of a world-class university, we excel at creating quality living and service environments for students and guests. RSSP believes in creating a more socially just global community and role models this belief through our organizational behavior and practices. Our vision and mission will be realized by following these values:

Organization.Name: Stories from the Career Path
Organization.Summary: Hosts a speaker series to prepare students to transition from students to the career path
Organization.Description: The speaker series is called Stories from the Career Path.. The purpose of the speaker series is to give students valuable lessons to help them make career choices. Many students today need guidance in making decisions while transitioning between school and finding work they love. There seems to be a gap between the acquisition of knowledge in school and its application to students’ passions at a professional level. This educational lecture series is an attempt to bridge the knowledge gap that exists and give advice to students how to find that career that is right for them.

Organization.Name: STS Working Group
Organization.Summary: The STS* Working Group is a group of scholars brought together by shared interest in STS practices and approaches. Our research interests cover topics in environment, technology, development, food, agriculture, and health.

Organization.Name: Student Environmental Resource Center
Organization.Summary: established 10.17.12, SB 85 F12
Organization.Description:
established 10.17.12, SB 85 F12.
The mission of the Student Environmental Resource Center is to strengthen the collective effectiveness and durability of campus sustainability efforts by providing information, opportunities, and services to students and student groups with an interest in sustainability and environmental justice.

SERC was formed out of a need of creating a central location for several groups interested in sustainability and environmental justice issues. At UC Berkeley, more than 30 student organizations focus on environmental justice issues and sustainability on campus, however they lack collaboration among each other. Within just a single academic year, SERC has become institutionalized at the university and is now serving as the official umbrella group for 30+, diverse sustainable/environmental student groups.

Ultimately, SERC works with all sorts of organizations that are making an effort to improve sustainability on campus and counteract environmental injustice; from fraternities and sororities to our locally owned student food collective. Most importantly, we are in the process of building coalitions with other groups off campus that in the past have not felt the connection with students such as low income communities in the Richmond area (nearby refinery where explosion occurred a year ago).

Organization.Name: Student National Medical Association - Minority Association of Pre-Medical Students
Organization.Summary: established 10/10/12, SB 68 F12
Organization.Description:
established 10/10/12, SB 68 F12

Organization.Name: The Conscious Network
Organization.Summary: The Conscious Network unites local communities on a global scale to co-create a new, sustainable future through a culture of meaning and connection.
Organization.Description:
What is The Conscious Network?

The Conscious Network is an ever-evolving movement that unites local communities on a global scale to co-create a new, sustainable future.

The Conscious Network creates new kinds of real-world spaces, which serve as interactive, non-ideological platforms for connection, self-reflection and meaningful action.  

The Conscious Network can be thought of as collection of diverse, interconnected spaces that, at their core, are all dedicated to building a new, authentic way of life—one grounded in self-awareness, individual fulfillment, and human connection. 

What does The Conscious Network do?

The Conscious Network creates open, interactive spaces in local communities that allow community members to gather, connect with one another, and engage in meaningful action together.

Each space The Conscious Network creates has a unique purpose. For instance, a Community Space is designed to foster community connections, while an Action Space is designed to promote social action. However, at their core, each and every space is unified in its aim: to create a culture that promotes individual fulfillment and collective prosperity, while fostering human connection and self-awareness.

What else do The Conscious Network do?

The Conscious Network also connects each space it creates to a local network of other spaces. For instance, Berkeley’s Community Space is connected to its Action Space and its Gift Space.

The connected spaces in any given region form a local network. For instance, each space in Berkeley is part of The Berkeley Network.

Each local network functions independently and autonomously. However, all local networks are connected to one another. For instance, The Berkeley Network may chose to work with The San Francisco Network on a project that concerns both regions. Likewise, The Berkeley and San Francisco Networks may chose to connect and work with the L.A Network on an issue that affects all of California.

The Conscious Network is, then, a network of networks. Each local network is linked to a series of other networks, creating a global network: The Conscious Network.

 Why the world needs The Conscious Network:

The Conscious Network is guided by an enduring belief that real and lasting change is possible if we can connect on an authentic level, discover our shared values, and act together.  

Currently, our world is in need of public spaces that allow us to connect and and work together to create the new, sustainable future we all desire. The Conscious Network meets this need. It provides new, non-ideological spaces in which we can grow as individuals and communities, and together change the world.

The Conscious Network provides a model for the future. The spaces it creates foster a shared, sustainable culture of meaning and connection. Out of this culture, a new global narrative is emerging—one grounded in a healthy optimism, and a full appreciation of our individual and collective potential.

Hello UC Berkeley students! This group is dedicated towards supporting your entrepreneurial ideas and projects through a positive think-tank environment! If you would like more information. please email Chris at christroodat@gmail.com!

   

In 2012, TROO WEAR expanded its original Fremont branch to a student organization located in Berkeley. Members are encouraged to develop themselves creatively here!

Organization.Name: UC Haiti Initiative at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The UC Haiti Initiative (UCHI) is a group of faculty, students, alumni, and several members of the administration dedicated mobilizing resources of the UC system for assistance in Haiti reconstruction.
Organization.Description: The UC Haiti Initiative (UCHI) is a group of faculty, students, alumni, and several members of the administration dedicated mobilizing resources of the UC system for assistance in Haiti reconstruction. We aim to form partnerships with Haitian academic counterparts, civil society organizations, NGOs, and Haitian Government agencies in a defined municipality to enhance capacity building through education and research. We will focus on six core areas: (1) Agriculture, (2) Arts History & Culture, (3) Economics & Law, (4) Education & Psychosocial Assistance, (5) Engineering Architecture & Technology, and (6) Health Care. All projects will emphasize initiative and direction by our Haitian partnering institutions and organizations to establish self-sustaining, long term mechanisms for continued development. We hope to build a community of students, faculty, and administration at UC Berkeley dedicated to long-term sustained development in Haiti.

Organization.Name: Unbounded Representation
Organization.Summary: The purpose of our group is to promote dialogue about different kinds of diversity among those who do work in Mathematics. We are a group of Math graduate students and have a particular interest in the Math graduate student experience at Berkeley.
Organization.Description: The purpose of our group is to promote dialogue about different kinds of diversity among those who do work in Mathematics. We are a group of Math graduate students and have a particular interest in the Math graduate student experience at Berkeley. However, we would like to investigate how all people in math-related fields grapple with the issue of diversity. We will do so through a variety of panel presentations, round-table discussions, and surveys. Our events will be open to the wider community.

On one hand, as a consulting organization we strive to achieve client satisfaction and tangible results. On the other hand, as a student organization, our prime focus is to facilitate actual learning on a professional and personal level. This translates into a collaborative and academic oriented culture that encourages progress through collective decision-making.

Organization.Name: *The Green Initiative Fund*
Organization.Summary: TGIF is UC Berkeley's student-fee based campus sustainability fund. TGIF provides funding via grants for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu
Organization.Description:
Do you...

  • Need funding for your campus sustainability project?
  • Want to know what projects have been funded by TGIF?
  • Want to serve on a committee that awards sustainability grants?
  • Need a student internship that will provide you with green job skills?
  • Want to learn more about UC Berkeley's campus sustainability efforts?
  • Need information regarding starting a green fund at your institution?

If yes, then The Green Initiative Fund is for you!


The Green Initiative Fund (TGIF) provides funding for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. TGIF allocates funds to projects that promote sustainable modes of transportation, increase energy and water efficiency, restore habitat, promote environmental and food justice, and reduce the amount of waste created by UC Berkeley. Portions of the fund also support education & behavior change initiatives, student aid (via return to aid), and student internships. Students, faculty, and staff may submit project proposals, which will be selected for funding by an annually appointed grant-making committee (TGIF Committee), consisting of students, faculty, and staff, on which the students have the majority vote.

Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu.

Join the listserv: http://eepurl.com/xlX8v

Organization.Name: Berkeley Forum, The
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes panels, debates, and talks by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless.
Organization.Description:
The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes panels, debates, and talks by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless. Forum events are open to the public and will be broadcast online.

The Forum is run entirely by undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley, though it is advised by a committee of distinguished professors. Berkeley Forum members are motivated, intellectually curious students from a diverse range of academic and professional backgrounds. The Forum provides students valuable first-hand experience and a channel to explore and challenge the ideas that motivate them.

Our Organization

The guiding authority of the Forum rests in the president and an executive committee, composed of the president and two vice presidents. The president and executive committee of the Forum are responsible for the day-to-day operations, the long-term growth, and ultimate success of the Forum.

Forum operations are carried out by two standing committees, each of which is chaired by a vice president. Each standing committee plays a central role in the planning and realization of Forum events. A programming affairs committee recruits guest speakers, handles travel and accommodation arrangements, and creates the program for Forum events. A communications committee publicizes all Forum events and serves as curator of the organizationâ€™s brand and graphic standards. The president may from time-to-time, with the advice and consent of the executive committee, form special committees.

The Forum also houses a systems and technology division, in charge of web design and other technology-related tasks, a development division, in charge of fundraising, and an external affairs division, which oversees membership recruiting and outreach efforts. Each division is overseen by a director.

Our Mission

The mission of the Berkeley Forum is to provide the Berkeley community a non-partisan forum for the presentation and debate of a wide range of ideas; to reaffirm the value of a liberal arts education; and to regularly organize, promote, and broadcast debates, panels, and talks by distinguished persons, and any such events, activities, or conversations as shall engage and challenge the faculties of the mind.

Admission to Forum events

Admission to Forum Events is free for all members of the Forum and persons affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley. This includes students, professors, administrators, and other staff members.

A fee of $5 (as of March 2013) will be required of all other event attendees and will be collected at the event, unless otherwise noted.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Innovation
Organization.Summary: Berkeley Innovation is a human-centered design group at UC Berkeley. Our members come from a wide range of disciplines, but share a love of design thinking and innovation.
Organization.Description:
Berkeley Innovation is a human-centered design group at UC Berkeley. Our members come from a wide range of disciplines, but share a love of design thinking and innovation. Each semester, we work on design projects that give members hands-on experience with the entire design process, from conducting user research to building and marketing prototypes. We exist as a community for students who are interested in design to develop their design thinking skills and experience.

 

*Name approved by OMBO 3/17/09

Organization.Name: Berkeley Model United Nations
Organization.Summary: To sponsor and organize an Model UN conference for 1500+ high school students each March on the Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description: Berkeley Model United Nations is a student run organization on the UC Berkeley campus dedicated to planning and hosting the biggest Model United Nations conference on the West Coast. Every March, over 1,500 high school students from all over the world come to Berkeley to participate in Berkeley Model United Nations. Entering its 62nd session, BMUN’s mission is to spread awareness of international issues and the spirit of diplomacy through UN simulations. We also aim to create an educational experience for high school students, to help them realize their potential in public speaking as well as policy debate. We do this by serving as head chairs on a diverse group of committees in which we help to facilitate delegate education through substantive diplomatic debate.

Organization.Description: The Berkeley Water Group (BWG) provides a forum in which Berkeley students from different departments can meet, collaborate and discuss their interdisciplinary research on topics of water, sanitation and hygiene. The group meets every other week in the plaza level of the Blum Center. Most participants are actively engaged in projects and research implemented in less developed countries, although the group is open to engaging problems found in developed countries as well.
