Organization.Name: Body Peace
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this student group is to promote positive body image, raise awareness for body image issues and eating disorders, and provide a safe, supportive space of self love and acceptance.
Organization.Description: The purpose of this student group is to promote diversity and tolerance of all bodies regardless of race, sex, size, or ability status; to raise awareness about eating disorders and body image issues; to create a support network for students dealing with body image insecurities; promote positive body image on campus and discourage fat talk, diet talk, and body disparagement;and question cultural norms about acceptable body types.

Organization.Name: CA Bikes International at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ASUC Sponsored per SB 27 Sp 12 2/20/13
Organization.Description:
Who Are We?

CA Bikes International at Berkeley is a new student group working to support Chris Ategeka's non-profit organization, CA Bikes International. CA Bikes International is an established nonprofit which works on the ground in Uganda making bicycles, wheel chairs, and bicycle ambulances. It is a Green organization, in that all of these products are made from recycled materials. The goal of this non-profit is to aid the chronic poverty in Uganda by working to provide its citizens with mobility, in order to facilitate their access to education and healthcare. They also helps to create local employment and entrepreneurs by giving them the mobility to start businesses.

Some statistics about what they have already helped to achieve:

There are currently 10 bicycle ambulances in Uganda, which serve 1,000 people every month. One bicycle ambulance serves anywhere between 75 to 100 people in one month. CA Bikes has already been sponsored by Chevron, Zambikes, The United States Embassy- Uganda, Judith Lee Stronach and Big Ideas at Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Capital Investments at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Capital Investments at Berkeley is a student-run initiative that aims to educate UC Berkeley students on necessary skills for trading investment products.
Organization.Description:
Capital Investments at Berkeley Constitution and Bylaws

04/14/2012 Amended

 

Date Approved (Center for Student Leadership staff): 02/05/13

Approved by (Center for Student Leadership staff): Stephanie Chan

 

ARTICLE I – Name

 

Section 1. The name of the organization shall be “Capital Investments at Berkeley”, hereafter referred to as CIB.

 

Section 2. The Executive Board of CIB, hereafter referred as the ‘Executive Board,’ shall be made up of one President, the Vice President of Portfolio Management, the Vice President of Operations and the Vice President of Investment Research. Officer positions shall be created as deemed necessary by the Executive Board.

 

Section 3. The Alumni Advisor is a founder of CIB and serves as a consultant, and is only involved in the major decision-making and approval processes.

 

ARTICLE II –Purpose

 

Capital Investments at Berkeley is a student-run initiative that aims to educate UC Berkeley students on necessary skills for trading alternative investment products. Through our capital investments fund (CIB fund), students will gain first-hand experience in exploring and executing various trading strategies. Meanwhile, we also seek to deliver long term and consistent absolute returns.

 

The CIB fund is a student investment fund which pools money from investors at UC Berkeley and other universities. Officers and the Executive Board members are responsible for managing the portfolio and following the requirements strictly set by the investment mandate, liability waivers and prospectus of the CIB fund.

 

ARTICLE III – Membership

 

Section 1. Only currently registered students, faculty and staff may be active members in CIB. Members are allowed to participate in general meetings and events organized by the officers of CIB. CIB will take members’ advice into consideration. However, members do have not voting power in the decision making process of managing the CIB fund. Only active members may vote or hold office. SC

 

Section 2. CIB considers hazing to be a degrading and destructive activity, which is inconsistent with the standards of this student organization. We will strictly abide by relevant California State laws. CIB recognizes the dignity of every person and opposes all forms of hazing. We will not haze according to California State Law. SC

 

Section 3. We will not restrict membership based upon race, color, national origin, religion, sex, physical and mental disability, medical condition (cancer-related or genetic characteristics), ancestry, marital status, age, sexual orientation, citizenship or status as a covered veteran (special disabled veteran, Vietnam-era veteran or any other veteran who served on active duty during a war or in a campaign or expedition for which a campaign badge has been authorized). SC

 

ARTICLE IV - Analysts/Officers/Appointment

 

Section 1. Analyst

 

At the beginning of each semester, the Executive Board shall recruit analysts. The Executive Board will design a training program to equip analysts will the necessary skills to serve the purpose of CIB, which is to educate members on trading various financial products and to manage the CIB fund in a professional manner.

 

The Executive Board shall conduct at least a 20 minute interview with each potential candidate for the analyst program. The Executive Board will identify the most suitable candidate to become analysts. The appointment must be confirmed by the President and the Alumni Advisor will be notified.

 

Section 2. Officers

 

CIB shall have the following Executive Board members, which shall be nominated by the members of the current Executive Board and appointed by the President of Capital Investments at Berkeley:

 

The President shall preside over all meetings of CIB, shall be an ex-officio member of all committees established by the Board, and shall have the power to appoint members to such committees, as the Board shall establish. The President shall be responsible for the overall activities of CIB and shall represent CIB in all official matters, unless he or she chooses to delegate the above duties. Furthermore, in all meetings of the Board and of all other Committees created by the Board, the President, has the right to make final decisions regarding all matters of CIB with support from the Alumni Advisor.

 

The Alumni Advisor is the founder of CIB, and is an alumnus of UC Berkeley. He is not involved in the daily operations of CIB. He is also not involved in most of the decision making process of the CIB fund. He is only responsible for the final approvals after the Executive Board members and gives advice.

 

The Vice Presidents shall assume such duties delegated to them by the President. In the event of the President's absence, disability, or resignation, the Vice Presidents shall assume the duties of the President in the manner provided under Article IV section 5.

 

The Vice President of Operations shall have charge of internal functions, manage external contacts, establish and maintain good public relationships, mediate members’ concerns, and oversight of financial affairs of CIB.

 

The Vice President of Investment Research shall have charge of deriving innovative and practical investment strategies, as well as equity and securities research.

 

The Vice President of Portfolio Management is responsible for monitoring risks and returns of the portfolio, and makes trade decisions with the approval of the President and Alumni Advisor. The Vice Presidents and officers execute trades with the President’s approval.

 

The Vice President of Administrations shall have charge of the general records and correspondence of the CIB, shall take attendance, and shall prepare written minutes of all meetings of the Board and of all meetings of the general membership. Furthermore, the Vice President of Administrations shall have charge of the financial records and make them available for inspection to any member of the Board or general membership when requested.

 

All Officers shall be active members of CIB, and have joined the analyst program in the past.

 

To become an officer, he or she must join the analyst program organized by the Executive Board and current officers. The program consists of training that is essential to become the portfolio managers of the CIB fund.

 

Section 3. Appointment

The Executive Board members shall conduct an appointment meeting at least two weeks before the end of each academic semester.

 

Any analyst of CIB who joined the training program at the beginning of the semester is eligible to be nominated.

 

Discussion will be conducted between members of the Executive Board and final decision will be made by the President and approved by the Alumni Advisor and the President.

 

The President shall supervise all nomination and appointment procedures.

 

Section 4. Removal of Officers

 

Any officer may be removed according to the following procedure. Upon the submission to any officer of CIB of a written petition, the President shall call a special meeting of the Executive Board of CIB. An officer can be removed by the two third members of the Executive Board and final approval by the President and Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 5. Vacancies in Office

 

Upon the President's temporary absence or disability, the Vice President of Operations shall share the appropriate duties and responsibilities of the President's functions during such temporary period.

 

Upon the President's permanent absence through resignation or other cause, the Vice Presidents may decide between themselves who shall assume the functions of the President. In the event that there can be no agreement between them, the final decision will be made the Alumni Advisor.

 

Upon the permanent absence of any other Officer through any cause, the President shall decide to whether to appoint a new officer. All vacancies are to be filled within two weeks of the opening of the vacancy. Upon appointment, the replacement shall immediately assume the functions of such officer, subject to ratification by a majority of the members of CIB attending the next validly convened general meeting.

 

Any officer must present in writing a formal statement of his or her resignation at least two weeks prior to the date of his or her resignation.

 

Upon the permanent absence of any officer through any cause, the Executive Board should conduct an internal meeting and decide whether to include a new officer.

 

ARTICLE V - Meetings

 

Section 1. General Meetings of CIB shall be open to all members and be conducted at least twice per year. Any member may attend the General Meetings of CIB.

 

Section 2. Vice President of Operations should contact all members regarding the time and locations of the General Meetings, either through mail, phone calls or emails, unless he or she delegates this duty to an officer.

 

Section 3. An analyst meeting shall be conducted each week. The Executive Board and current officers will provide essential training for the analysts in order to them to be successful officers in the future.

 

Section 4. An officer meeting shall be conducted weekly. Officers and the Executive Board will discus the portfolio held by the CIB fund and make investment suggestions and handle other administrative issues.

 

ARTICLE VI - Constitutional Amendments

 

Section 1. A meeting to amend the provisions of this Constitution shall be convened by the officers and agreed by the Executive Board, and be finally approved by the President and Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 2. All amendments, additions or deletions must be filed with the Center for Student Leadership in 102 Hearst Gym within one week of adoption. SC

 

ARTICLE VII – Dissolution

 

Section 1. CIB may be dissolved at any time with the approval of all the Officers and the Alumni Advisor.

 

Section 2. All unspent ASUC funds shall remain the property of the ASUC, all Graduate Assembly funds shall remain the property of the Graduate Assembly. Remaining privately obtained funds may be donated to another nonprofit organization with prior approval of the ASUC Senate Finance Committee. Investment funds from investors must be returned to investors.

 

A Bill In Support of Capital Investments at Berkeley

4/3/2013

 Authored by Senator Daley Vertiz and Monica Ruiz

Sponsored by Senator Daley Vertiz


WHEREAS, Capital Investments at Berkeley (CIB) was founded in 2011 to allow UC Berkeley students to learn about the markets through real experience; and,


WHEREAS, there are a lack of campus organizations that teach students about the financial world in an in-depth manner; and,


WHEREAS,CIB aims to provide consistent returns with minimal risk exposure through utilizing equities, derivatives and alternative investment products; and,


WHEREAS, By managing an actual money fund comprised of investments from club members and external investors, club members make real decisions to achieve real growth; and,


WHEREAS, CIB’s mission is to increase financial awareness and knowledge in the student body through its analyst training program, a semester-long crash course in trading that exposes analysts to most of the financial instruments including securities, options, and bonds; and,


WHEREAS, CIB hosts weekly conference calls to discuss market trends and predictions; and,


WHEREAS, CIB also develops members professionally byhosting corporate sponsors to assist with recruitment and to educate students about careers/career planning in the finance industry; and,


THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, the ASUC recognizes Capital Investments at Berkeley (CIB) as a 1st year ASUC Sponsored Student Activity Group (SAG).

Organization.Name: Career Development Initiative for the Physical Sciences
Chemical Engineering Car
Organization.Summary: The Chemical Engineering Car team builds a shoebox-sized car powered and controlled by chemical reactions for the AIChe sponsored Chemical Engineering Car competition.
Organization.Description:
The Chemical Engineering Car team builds a shoebox-sized car powered and controlled by chemical reactions for the AIChe sponsored Chemical Engineering Car competition.

We took 2nd place in the poster competition and 3rd place in the performance competition at the most recent event at UCSD this April. With this result, we qualified for the national competition in San Francisco in November.

This fall we will work on improving [Au]ROAR-a, our Zn-MnO2 battery powered car while beginning development of next year's thermoelectric car.

Organization.Name: Climate Change and Health IdeaLab
Organization.Summary: We bring together individuals, groups, and projects to create a forum for creative thinking around the many intersections of climate change and health.
Organization.Description: We bring together individuals, groups, and projects to create a forum for creative thinking around the many intersections of climate change and health. Our work seeks to reshape the dialogue around climate change and health, and inspire new policies that may significantly mitigate climate change while protecting the health of the most vulnerable--through innovations in climate models, groundbreaking research on the health effects of pollutants, new designs for more energy efficient technologies, policy analysis on land use, and efforts to more effectively communicate the co-benefits of climate change mitigation.

Organization.Name: Code the Change at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We help computer scientists use their skills to make social change an integral part of computer science culture.

Organization.Name: Cognitive Science Organization for Graduate Students
Organization.Summary: COGS is an interdisciplinary student group whose purpose is to promote research and scholarship in cognitive science by providing a forum for discussion of research and supporting the community of cognitive scientists at Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Collegiate Association for the Research of Principles
Computer Science for the Future
Organization.Summary: To provide the essential tools to high school and lower income students in order to attain the essential skills required for basic computer science programing.
Organization.Description: The need for employees with knowledge in the science of computer programming is more important then ever before. Our mission is to educate high school students on how to access, download and learn coding programs, such as Python. Through workshops, which will take place at various high schools in the adjacent area surrounding Berkeley, and 24/7 communication and instruction with program participants, we plan to provide the necessary tools for eager students to gain an advantage in the field of computer science.

Organization.Name: Concrete Canoe
Organization.Summary: The Concrete Canoe team at UC Berkeley competes every year in the ASCE sponsored concrete canoe competition. Our team challenges students to apply their knowledge obtained in their courses to a hands-on project.
Organization.Description: We provide a welcoming community where students can learn, gain hands-on experience, and create something they can be proud of.  The concrete canoe team is unique from the other student organizations because we encompass many disciplines of civil engineering, and provide a unique opportunity for students to grow.  Participating in our team exposes students to many of the branches of civil engineering, such as construction, materials design, structural, and environmental.  In addition, as a competition team, we help individuals build leadership and teamwork skills.  Our team also has a long history of competition and success, which allows students to call upon a large knowledgeable alumni network.  Concrete Canoe here at UC Berkeley provides a great opportunity for students to grow outside of their courses.

Organization.Name: Conflict Free Campus Initiative at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: In partnership with the Raise Hope for Congo Campaign of the Enough Project, the Conflict Free Campus Initiative at Berkeley aims to harness the power of student leadership and activism to bring about peace in Congo.
Organization.Description: In partnership with the Raise Hope for Congo Campaign of the Enough Project, the Conflict Free Campus Initiative at Berkeley aims to harness the power of student leadership and activism to bring about peace in Congo. By encouraging university officials and stakeholders, both of whom are large purchasers of electronics and powerful spokespersons, to commit to measures that pressure electronics companies to responsibly invest in Congo's minerals sector, we can voice our demand for conflict-free products from Congo. Comprehensive reform is needed in Congo to bring about sustainable peace- now is the time is now for students to lead the conflict-free movement for peace in eastern Congo.

Organization.Name: Consult Your Community (CYC) at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ASUC Sponsored per SB 69 SP 12 3/6/13

Organization.Name: Creative Marketing Group
Organization.Summary: A UC Berkeley student-run professional marketing advisory group that provides creative solutions to local businesses’ marketing needs. For more inquiries, please email us at berkeleycmg@gmail.com
Organization.Description:
Creative Marketing Group is a professional marketing advisory group that provides creative solutions to local businesses’ marketing needs. The organization seeks to develop students’ marketing knowledge and skills, but most importantly, to allow them to execute those qualities in a real-world setting.

​As an official UC Berkeley student organization, we aim to recruit a talented and diverse group of students in offering excellent pro bono consulting services to the local community.

Upon our launch in Fall 2013, we position ourselves to not only be strategic in data analysis and business modeling. In building the competence of our consultants, we also position ourselves to be unique through our creative approach in design, online marketing, and social media strategies.

Edge Interns at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Edge Interns at Berkeley finds the most motivated, focused, and team-oriented students interested in the healthcare, business, or technology fields. We expand members’ professional and personal development through exclusive internships and mentoring.
Organization.Description: Edge Interns is unique in that it is not restricted to one industry, ethnic group, or major, but is focused on the exploration and expansion of its members' development through personalized mentoring, exclusive industry internships, and professional networking. The main objective is for its members to gain a stronger and clearer vision of who they are and the legacy they wish to leave behind.

Organization.Name: Energy, Civil Infrastructure, and Climate Group
Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley (EBSB) is a professional and scientific society whose purpose shall be helping student to explore the intersection of different fields of engineering and business.
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Organization shall be providing a knowledge platform at Berkeley that integrate scientific foundations of business and engineering; and a resource for engineering and business students to develop professional skills and learn about possible career opportunities that bridge different fields of business and engineering. 

An engineer needs to obtain the business skills and knowledge required to make his or her entrepreneurial vision a reality. Engineering graduates at UC Berkeley need to learn how to lead both the business aspect and the technological aspect of a successful enterprise. UC Berkeley provides two of the best academic program at the College of Engineering and the Haas School of Business. Engineering and Business Society of Berkeley (EBSB) will bridge the gap between these two parts of UC Berkeley and bring undergraduates from both schools together under one platform.

Organization.Name: Environmental Team
Organization.Summary: The Environmental Team strives to win first place at the annual ASCE Mid-Pacific conference. Students can hope to build close relationships with other team members, while learning about water quality and water filtration.
Organization.Description: Unlike other water filtration organizations on campus, the Environmental Team is competition-orientated. Our annual competition provides members with the opportunity to meet other students from other universities and engineers from the industry.

Organization.Description: The Household Energy IdeaLab brings together Bay Area academics, entrepreneurs, and advocates to explore advancements in the study of household energy use in developing nations. Through the exploration of cutting edge research and the communication and discussion of members’ own work, this IdeaLab aims to foster collaboration and creativity among Berkeley’s home energy and development scholars while simultaneously expanding the Bay Area household energy network.

Organization.Name: Human Rights of the Incarcerated Coalition
Organization.Summary: Our mission is to increase awareness in the U.C. Berkeley community regarding cycles of incarceration and the Prison Industrial Complex.
Organization.Description: Our mission is to increase awareness in the U.C. Berkeley community regarding cycles of incarceration and the Prison Industrial Complex. Additionally, the coalition would support a network of campus resources for student engagement on these issues.

Organization.Name: Incentive Awards Program
Organization.Summary: The IAP provides educational and financial access to high-achieving students who face socio-economic barriers from underserved communities. We commit to cultivate future leaders through civic engagement and provide services to succeed at Cal and beyond.
Organization.Description:
SERVICE OBJECTIVES

 

v Empower and develop leaders who will affect social transformation in their various communities.

 

v Cultivate long-lasting relationships within the IAP community of Scholars, Alumni, Staff, Donors, and High School Partners.

 

Committed to developing future leaders, IAP has established the service requirement to support the program’s mission and objectives, as well as, to provide their scholars with opportunities for personal growth, professional development, and service to their communities.

 

As an IAP scholarship recipient, you are required to perform certain types of service in order to keep your scholarship. The IAP staff has developed this packet to further explain the details in satisfying the service requirement, and to provide you with a list of options for completing your service activities. 

 

To fulfill the service requirement, you will be asked complete a total of four different services activities from four different service categories each academic year. The scholar will need to complete two service activities forms per semester and use the Service Requirement Form to verify their completion. The service categories consist of the following:

 

c     Service to Self

c     Service to IAP

c     Service to Community

c     Service to IAP Partner High School

 

Scholars can decide on the order in which the categories are completed each semester.

 

SAMPLE:

 

Fall Semester                                                            Spring Semester

10/22 Service to Community                                 2/5 Service to IAP

  (Campus Clean Up: Earth Day Club)                        (OHP: Host)

 

11/15 Service to IAP Partnered HS                   4/24 Service to Self

  (UC Applications Workshop-Alma Mater)            (Grad School Workshop)

Organization.Description:
Mariachi Luz de Oro de Berkeley is a musical student-run group that performs traditional and modern mariachi music. We aspire to promote musical and cultural diversity by increasing exposure to the Mexican art form of mariachi. We aim to establish and maintain a performing group to inspire the lives of the community and its members. 

We are looking for passionate and motivated students! Students interested can contact ucbmariachi@gmail.com with their name, year, instrument(s) they play, major, and any previous experience they have had either performing or playing mariachi music.

Email: ucbmariachi@gmail.com 
Phone: (510) 982-6087
Instagram: @ucbmlo

At the same time, MEND strives to educate communities in the Bay Area about the effects and impact of the War on Drugs in Mexico.

Organization.Description: The purpose of Patient Advocacy Student Group(PASG) is to gather students that have an interest in patient advocacy and/or a desire to develop and practice patient advocacy skills. Student Group activities may include public relations, outreach, communications, events, education, and development as well as peer support and networking. Additionally, PASG will recruit and support students actively serving in the Patient Support Corps.

Organization.Name: Personal Finance Club
Organization.Summary: PFC provides the tools and resources for any interested individual to learn and become self-sufficient in making personal financial decisions. We seek to help increase the financial literacy starting with the Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description:
The Personal Finance Club at Berkeley seeks to provide the tools and resources for any interested individual to learn and become self-sufficient in making personal financial decisions. We want to help as many people succeed in understanding the financial services industry, budgeting, saving for retirement, ways to invest, student loans, building credit, and provide development of financial skill sets through social interactions and networking experiences with financial professionals. In addition, we will provide opportunities for public speaking, community service, and social events. We hope to help increase the financial literacy starting with the Berkeley campus.

 

ASUC Sponsored per SB 40 SP 12 2/20/13

Organization.Name: Poker Club, The
Organization.Summary: Poker Club is a philanthropic group that holds monthly poker tournaments in which the proceeds are donated to charity

Organization.Name: Portraits of Kindness at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Portraits of Kindness at Berkeley is a club through which students create portraits of orphans from around the world to honor their heritage, help build a positive self-esteem, and commemorate their childhood. Contact info is under "read more"!
Organization.Description:
Mission:

Our mission is to encourage UC Berkeley students to turn their artistic skills into something greater than simply art. Through our projects, we nurture the lives of orphans worldwide and inspire the Berkeley community to share kindness with those in need

Process:

Participants receive photos of orphans waiting for portraits and then work from those photos to create portraits (drawings, paintings, digital art). Next, the portraits are delivered to the orphans as gifts. Finally, each artist receives a photo of the rpahn holding his/her portrait! 

Intrested for more information or would like to join: 

Shoot us a message on facebook.com/PortraitsofKindness or email us at PortraitsOfKindness@gmail.com!

Organization.Description: We will publish literary works as well as visual art. Our greater mission is to strengthen ties between high school and UC Berkeley students, and to promote high school students to pursue higher education.We publish literature and visual art by the Berkeley student community and report on recent artistic events and accomplishments at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to provide space for new writers and artists to have their work published. We want to form a community of creative people to share their ideas and gain exposure.

Organization.Description: The purpose of this organization shall be to promote and reward scholarship and service among students and practitioners of international studies, international affairs, and global studies and to foster integrity and creative performance in the conduct of world affairs.

Organization.Description: We are established group that is primarily support by Livingwater Church (Livingwater Fellowship & The Presence).

Organization.Name: VISION
Organization.Summary: VISION is a 4-day, 3-night mentorship program aimed at bringing awareness to historical, cultural and contemporary Vietnamese and Vietnamese American issues.
Organization.Description: VISION, a mentorship program under Vietnamese Student Association at the University of California, Berkeley, recognizes and understands the significance of the historical, cultural and contemporary issues the Vietnamese and Vietnamese American communities face. VISION aims to foster and encourage high school students to take away what they learn and gain from our program to become leaders of their own communities. Fundamentally, VISION empowers students to embrace their individual identities as well as the heritage of the Vietnamese culture.

Organization.Description: We are the Idea Lab for making data visualizations out of urban data.

Organization.Name: World Peace Buddhists
Organization.Summary: Cal's World Peace Buddhists is affiliated with the SGI, Soka Gakkai (Value-Creating Society) International, a world-wide Buddhist organization with 12 million members in 190 countries and territories.
Organization.Description: Cal's World Peace Buddhists is affiliated with the SGI, Soka Gakkai (Value-Creating Society) International, a world-wide Buddhist organization with 12 million members in 190 countries and territories. They often pride themselves on their diversity, and their ability to empower and unite individuals regardless of social standing, racial and ethnic differences. The club and organization is founded on Nichiren Daishonin's Buddhism that focuses on the individual's ability to become Buddha's, or enlightened individuals with the qualities of courage, compassion, wisdom, and life force. The motivating force of the club and organization is a desire that everyone carries the desire to be happy that serves as a driving source in transforming one's life and ultimately society and the world. Nam-myoho-renge-kyo

Organization.Name: Zoroastrian Student Organization
Organization.Summary: Promote unity among Zoroastrian students and other members of the campus community by examining the history, identity, and beliefs of the Zoroastrian religion through cultural, religious, and academic events.
Organization.Description: This organization will act to unite Zoroastrians of the greater Bay area through community outreach and activates. Members of the organization will work together to further understand the origins and teachings of the Zoroastrian religion, as well as help to bring this knowledge to fellow Zoroastrians in the area. Members will also strive to establish a stronger connection between Zoroastrians in the greater Bay Area, as well as work to establish more of a community among them. We will plan and hold events for Zoroastrians, which will hopefully form a more tight-knit Zoroastrian community. These events will also provide a way for more Zoroastrians to meet each other and hopefully also provide a large networking opportunity.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Student Journal of Asian Studies
Organization.Summary: The Berkeley Student Journal of Asian Studies (BSJAS) is an Institute of East Asian Studies sponsored journal that strives to both showcase the best undergraduate and graduate work at Berkeley in the field of Asian Studies.
Organization.Description: The publication gives students aspiring to a future in academia a chance to practice the process of submission to a journal. The goal of this student organization is to assist the journal by providing its committee members with the means to hold meetings on campus, access valuable campus resources, recruit new members, and reach out to a larger portion of the Berkeley student community.

Organization.Name: Cal Alumni Student Association
Organization.Summary: The Cal Alumni Student Association (CASA) is UC Berkeley's premier student organization for engagement between students and alumni.
Organization.Description:
Mission & Vision

The Cal Alumni Student Association (CASA) aims to be the flagship student group for engaging students and alumni and building student and alumni leaders. Furthermore, CASA strives to inspire Cal students to become engaged alumni through volunteerism, community building, and philanthropy. 

 

History

The formation of CASA was the result of the Leadership Award Scholars Association (LASA) and the Student Alumni Relations Council (SARC) joining forces to create a new student group supported by the Cal Alumni Association (CAA) and aimed at engaging students and alumni and building student and alumni leaders. 

 

Programming

Legacy Night: Legacy Night joins Cal's top student leaders with Cal alumni to celebrate the dedication and accomplishments of students and alumni alike. 

I Run 4 Cal: I Run 4 Cal: 5K Run/Walk is a charity race at UC Berkeley for campus departments, scholarships, programs, and student groups. 

Top Dogs with Top Dogs: Top Dogs with Top Dogs is an opportunity for students to engage with Cal alumni who share their extracurricular and career path goals -- accompanied by a Top Dog lunch!

Overnight Stay Program: CASA's flagship program, the Overnight Stay Program (OSP) provides approximately 800 high school seniors who have been accepted to UC Berkeley with the opportunity to experience life as a Cal student.

Tier 2 Programming (TTP): CASA offers additional programming, such as workshops and socials, aimed at engaging students and alumni and providing professional resources.

Organization.Description: Our organization has its home inside of the Center for Entrepreneurship and Technology and has unique access to all of the opportunities therein. Furthermore, we work hard to foster relationships between students looking for startup opportunities on and off of campus.

Organization.Name: OpenDialogues at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: OpenDialogues promotes personal growth by cultivating life stories through dialogue-centric mentorship.
Organization.Description:
We define OpenDialogues as mutually beneficial, uninhibited, non-prescriptive conversations built around various life themes. Through open dialogues, we can better develop our life story which propels us to attain greater personal growth and future achievements.

Our program is based on the notion that everyone is greatly impacted by our informal conversations -- we are enriched by actively engaging with each other. In OpenDialogues, each participant has a unique role to play, and each mentorship pair has unique stories to share. Our program is focused on facilitating this dynamic, through which we aim to shape life stories one open dialogue at a time.

Students and mentors are connected one-on-one to make a mentorship pair, with all pairs forming A Modern Mentorship Community.

Organization.Name: Society of Women Engineers
Organization.Summary: We are a multi-faceted organization, holding academic, professional, service, and social events. Everyone is welcome to attend, the only requirement is that you support women in engineering!
Organization.Description:
Society of Women Engineers is a national nonprofit organization. Its objective is to encourage and empower women to reach their full potential as engineers. SWE strives to highlight the achievements and contributions of women as leaders and engineers. Supporting both students and professionals, SWE consists of over 17,000 members in 90 sections and 300 student sections.

The UC Berkeley student chapter has been established for approximately 30 years and supports students through professional development, social events and outreach to young women interested in engineering and science.

For any additional questions on our chapter or how to get involved, please email swe.berkeley@gmail.com or visit our website swe.berkeley.edu. You can also find more information about Nationa SWE by visiting their website swe.org.

Organization.Name: Space Exploration Society at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Space Exploration Society at Berkeley is the Berkeley chapter for Students for the Exploration and Development of Space (SEDS) and The Planetary Society (TPS). Our goal is to stimulate interest in a space-related career for students of all majors.
Organization.Description:
By inspiring the next generation of space scientists, we hope to accelerate the development and exploration of space. We will accomplish our goals by forming a network of students interested in space, providing leadership opportunities, educating both students and non-students with scientific outreach, participating in space-related competitions (rocket-building, 3D printing, space policy), and interacting with professional organizations and companies. 

The Space Exploration Society at Berkeley is the only club at Berkeley to promote the exploration and development of space. We serve as the de facto astronomy club at Berkeley since it is directly related to space interests.  We are also the first interdisciplinary society for encouraging space interests and soliciting members from all majors including engineering, the physical sciences, humanities, and all others.

Organization.Name: Student Global Health Alliance at Berkeley
Thought Lounge, The
Organization.Summary: The purpose of The Thought Lounge is to provide a space for the students of Berkeley to capitalize on the opportunity to have their peers be their teachers.
Organization.Description: It seems that each student in Cal is often passionate and super-interested in certain topics that classroom discussions fail to address. Each Thought Lounge meeting will act as a mini-forum wherein members will be expected to present and engage in dialogues concerned with varying topics of personal interest. Connections and relations formed between these different ideas presented will be highlighted at the end of each meeting.

Organization.Name: Triathlon Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Triathlon Club at Berkeley is to bring the sport of triathlon to the student community at the University of California, Berkeley and its surrounding environs.
Organization.Description: Triathlon is a multi-sport event consisting of swimming, biking, and running that offers a potential for lifelong enjoyment and passion. It is this lifestyle that the Triathlon Club at Berkeley seeks to bring to its members. Finally, this club hopes to represent a standard in the organization, competition, and applicability for collegiate triathlon clubs around the nation. We will bring the sport of triathlon to the aforementioned groups and entities through a combination of detailed education about all stages of the sport, offering organized practices, as well as a sharing of our resources. These resources include access to our monetary resources for organized team events, access to our sponsorships to make the sport more affordable, and access to the array of experience and knowledge about the sport accumulated by the members.

Organization.Name: 4Corners Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: We are a diverse Christian fellowship that welcomes everyone from everywhere (hence the name, “4Corners”).
Organization.Description: Throughout the week, we meet together for bible studies and/or gather in smaller groups to hang out, eat together, play sports, or just enjoy each other's company in the hope that we may spur one another on to greater nearness and likeness to Christ. it is also our vision to bring the gospel to the 4 corners of the earth one day. So, whether you’re a Christian, or someone who’s just curious about finding out what Christians believe, we welcome you!

Organization.Name: ABA
Organization.Summary: ABA offers its members experiences, skills, and memories to last a lifetime, focusing on its three core values: professionalism, community, and service.
Organization.Description:
ABA was founded in 1975 by a group of students who set out to provide a bridge between the professional world and the students of the UC Berkeley campus. Over the course of its 35+ years of history, ABA has expanded its mission and now represents many diverse majors and cultures:

The mission of ABA is to advance the study of business and to develop well-rounded leaders at the University of California, Berkeley. ABA promotes scholarship and leadership at the Walter A. Haas School of Business; encourages career exploration; and cultivates community-building and networking within and beyond the University. ABA emphasizes social responsibility in contemporary business practices and encourages its members to serve the local community.

ABA has become a well-respected organization among the campus, the Haas community, and the business world. With over 500 members, it is the largest undergraduate organization sponsored by the Walter A. Haas School of Business.

Organization.Name: Alpha Epsilon Delta, Pre-medical Honor Society
Organization.Summary: To provide a forum where students, interested in the fields of medicine, dentistry, veterinary, and others, foster bonding between peers and faculty, with common interests of high moral character and brotherhood.
Organization.Description: To provide a forum where students, interested in the fields of medicine, dentistry, veterinary, and others, foster bonding between peers and faculty, with common interests of high moral character and brotherhood, who are not only dedicated to the encouragement and recognition of excellence in pre-professional health scholarship, but also devoted to education and philanthropy in order to serve and better health organizations, charities, and communities for a lifetime.

Organization.Name: American Chinese Culture and Education Foundation/Youth Care Club
Arab American Association of Engineers and Architects
Asian American and Pacific Islander Health Research Group
Asian American Donor Program (AADP) at Berkeley
Asian Pacific Islanders American Public Affairs - Collegiate Council Chapter
Asians On Stage By Any Means Necessary
Aspiring Vaishnava Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Aspiring Vaishnava Club at Berkeley�s purpose is to provide meeting, training, studying, service and fellowship opportunities for student, staff, faculty and community members of the UCB community who subscribe to Gaudiya Vaishnavism.

Organization.Name: Association of Undergraduate Women in Computer Science & Electrical Engineering
BERKE1337 Cyber Security Team
Organization.Summary: The purpose shall be to organize, hack, defend, educate, compete, and have fun. We provide the opportunity to compete in information security competitions and connect people interested in security focusing from both a theoretical & practical standpoint.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Art Museum/ Pacific Film Archive Student Committee
BERKELEY Bhagat Puran Singh Health Initiative
Black Engineering and Science Students Association
Cal AMSA
Organization.Summary: To further the message of the International Ahmadiyya Muslim Community, through activities and events, based on the motto, “Love for all, hatred for none”.

Organization.Name: Casa Joaquin
Organization.Summary: Casa Joaquin works to develop and empower student leaders of color to advocate for social justice & equity on campus and in their communities.
Organization.Description: Casa Joaquin provides a home away from home. We provide community building, academic support and leadership development through professional skill workshops and mentorship.

Organization.Name: Christian Medical and Dental Associations Chapter at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Christian Medical and Dental Associations Chapter exist to glorify God--by motivating, educating and equipping Christian pre-medical and pre-dental students.
Organization.Description:
Purpose:

To serve with professional excellence as witnesses of Christ's love and compassion, and by advancing biblical principles of healthcare within the Church and to our culture. Our goal is to offer guidance and role models as students consider pursuing careers in healthcare and then actively support them as they navigate through their professional training years and into a life of serving the Lord in a healthcare career by going on medical missions to underserved countries abroad and within the States

Organization.Name: College Micro Ventures
Organization.Summary: Investing in students’ business ideas in developing nations to provide them the opportunity to expand on business aspirations with the intent of impacting their local communities.
Organization.Description: Club founded on a student to student principle with the intent of changing the world. Members will invest money and/or their time into the club. As a club we focus on students' innovative business ideas in different countries each semester.

Organization.Name: Construction Team
Organization.Summary: We give students an opportunity to learn about the construction industry. Joining the Construction Team is a one of a kind experience and you will gain knowledge not available in classroom settings.

Organization.Name: Delta Kappa Alpha
Organization.Summary: The mission of Delta Kappa Alpha is to foster lifelong character, collaborative and creative storytelling, ethical and productive business practices, philanthropic action, and fraternal bonds by and between students of the cinematic arts.
Organization.Description: Established March 16, 1936, Delta Kappa Alpha is a National, Co-Educational, Professional Cinema Fraternity for cinematic arts students of character. As a National organization with over 75 years of history and alumni, our members are connected to the top cinema students from top cinema schools at universities such as USC, NYU, UCLA, Chapman, UT Austin, Columbia University, and many others.  DKA is grounded in timeless personal and professional values and principles, and as an organization, our vision is to be recognized as the premier institute of upstanding entertainment industry leaders. Not exclusive to film studies majors, DKA welcomes men and women, undergraduates and graduates, who are dedicated to fostering lifelong character, collaborative and creative storytelling, ethical and productive business practices, philanthropic action, and fraternal bonds by and between students of the cinematic arts.

Organization.Name: DUP - SPICMACAY at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Society for the Promotion of Indian Classical Music and Culture Amongst Youth, Berkeley Chapter

Organization.Name: Educational Alliance of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The primary purpose of the Educational Alliance program is to provide young people a means to engage in service that keeps students in school on track to graduate.
Organization.Description:
The secondary purpose of Educational Alliance of Berkeley is to provide students information and advice about the City Year program and the application process.

Educational Alliance of Berkeley is distinct from similar educational organizations, because it adopts a holistic approach to minimizing dropouts in K-12 US schools.  Educational Alliance pursues this goal within the tenants of the City Year organization and assists potential City Year applicants in lieu of educational service.

Organization.Name: Footprintz at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Footprintz is an organization that provides support and resources to underprivileged children locally and internationally who do not have access to basic necessities in an effort to allow them to better their life.
Organization.Description: Footprintz focuses on orphanages in domestic and international areas. We attempt to increase their access to resources such as better education or the tools for better learning by either providing monetary donations to buy such resources or the resources if they can be given directly, such as books. In addition, we aim to provide emotional support by organizing activities that will help entertain them as well as provide distractions from their much too stressful

Organization.Name: Free Racquet Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Our purpose is to provide tennis coaching and equipment to youth aged 5-17 in the Berkeley area.
Organization.Description: Our proposed organization is different from existing tennis clubs at UC Berkeley because it targets underprivileged youth (ages 5-17) and not college students in the Berkeley area. Youth that demonstrate financial need can sign up for access to weekly lessons and equipment. Our club will provide a unique volunteer experience for Berkeley students interested in sharing their tennis talent with youth who normally wouldn't have access to coaching. Berkeley students that don't play tennis but are still interested in our cause are also welcome to aid in facilitation of practices and purchasing drinks and snacks for the kids.

Organization.Name: GameCraft
Organization.Summary: GameCraft seeks to expose students to the processes and joy of game design, development, and art. We aim to give students the path and resources to create their own game through all disciplines.
Organization.Description: GameCraft is a club to help those interested in game design understand common tools and work environments that other indie and major industry developers work in. We encourage students from all backgrounds to come and join, as game design has many facets that people can be involved in; development, art, writing, and project management.

Organization.Name: Global Student Embassy at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Global Student Embassy at Berkeley looks to bring Cal students together with international communities in order to create positive, grassroots change on a local and multinational scale.
Organization.Description:
GSE promotes peace and equitable development by connecting young people from around the world through innovative workshops and service learning exchanges. We believe that students are young ambassadors who can practice grassroots international relations by identifying local issues, collaborating with their global peers, and implementing projects that create positive change within the community. We currently have projects in Northern California, Nicaragua, and Ecuador building school gardens with a focus in biointensive agriculture. Our goal is to send Cal students to GSE's sister gardens in order to learn, through experience, about social and environmental justice as well as sustainable farming techniques.

Global Student Embassy is unique in that it seeks to create a dialogue across international borders on a wide range of issues including grassroots organizing, social justice, public health, environmental crises, and more. We are a diverse group of students and organizers interested in banding together in order to address problems that affect as all.

Organization.Name: Golfers' Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The mission of Golfers' Association of Berkeley is to promote friendly competition amongst golfers at Cal, teach the game to aspiring golfers, and encourage a love for golf.
Organization.Description: This organization is unique from the one other existing golf related organization on campus because it is an outlet for both competitive golfers and a platform for aspiring golfers to receive coaching. The leaders of this club are advanced and passionate enough players to teach beginners the game of golf, and the tournaments we host will allow the numerous low-handicap golfers at Cal to compete on a level that they may not have the resources to engage in.

Organization.Name: International Human Rights Workshop
Organization.Summary: Started in 2012, the International Human Rights Workshop (IHRW) was developed as part of the SLPS program. The workshop was created to give 1L and LLM students hands-on experience in international human rights work.
Organization.Description:
IHRW currently partners with the Human Rights Center (HRC), under the supervision of the Director of the Sexual Violence Program, Kim Thuy Seelinger.

In 2013-14, IHRW will assist the three main projects at the HRC, the Forensic Program, Global Justice Program, and Sexual Violence Program.

Students will have the opportunity to hone their legal research and writing skills and develop knowledge of domestic and international laws. The Forensic Program will give students the opportunity to assist the Contra Costa District Attorney’s Office in gaining a more comprehensive understanding of victim behavior after an attack. Students assisting the Global Justice Program will work on war crimes research by conducting background research on victim participation in the International Criminal Court. Students assisting the Sexual Violence Program will respond directly to the needs of public defenders and judges in Liberia by researching the right to confront an accuser.

 

IHRW is unique because it serves the international, and local, human rights community. The community is served by UC Berkeley students who are able to interact with real projects within the human rights sphere. This year, because the forensics project is local, it also serves students who are interested in criminal justice and those who want to work directly with a district attorney. Additionally, students who are not directly part of the workshop can participate in large group trainings and learn about the research activities of the group.

IHRW has an impact on local and global communities. This year the Sexual Violence Project will be working directly with DA’s and judges in Liberia to answer questions about the right to face your accused. The research in this area will focus on ways accusers can safely participate in court proceedings in Liberia. The Global Justice Project is working to look at victim rights of participation in proceedings at the ICC. Finally, the Forensics Project will serve the Contra Costa District Attorney’s Office to assist with early injury detection in domestic violence cases.

Organization.Name: International Youth and Students for Social Equality Publications Group
Organization.Summary: The International Youth and Students for Social Equality is an organization dedicated to mobilizing young people in a fight against the capitalist system and for the socialist transformation of Society.

Organization.Name: Irish Dancers of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We aim to provide a time, place, and platform for Irish dancers of all experience levels to practice, perform, and explore all aspects of Irish dance, while bringing a bit of craic to Cal!
Organization.Description:
For many college-aged Irish dancers, it is difficult to continue participating in this cultural art form and sport for several reasons. When they move away from their dance company, they do not have space to practice, they do not have the same incentive of teamwork and camaraderie that is so central to the activity, and they do not have the chance to perform. 

The Irish Dancers of Berkeley does regular stamina and technique workouts, but we also choreograph traditional and contemporary performance routines. The group is actively seeking opportunities to perform in and around Berkeley, and could potentially compete in intercollegiat competitions. There are several collegiate Irish dance teams around the country. Seeing as UC Berkeley is one of the top universities in the world, we ought to have a group to represent the Bears when Irish dance groups meet up.

This art form is thriving in the Bay Area, and Cal should be connected to this Irish community. The Irish Dancers of Berkeley can and will serve as cultural ambassadors around campus, the Bay, and beyond.

Organization.Name: Korean Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Korean Christian Fellowship is to offer Bible studies, discipleship, and fellowship for Koreans at UC Berkeley where students can build friendships, train and learn.

Organization.Name: Latino Pre-Medical Student Association
Organization.Summary: The purpose of Latino Pre-Medical Student Association shall be to provide support and guidance to Latino pre-medical students and students interested in the medical field in becoming competitive medical school applicants.
Organization.Description: Our mission is to provide support and guidance to Latino pre-medical students and students interested in the medical field in becoming competitive medical school applicants. LPMSA abides by this mission by providing academic assistance, exposure to network, and extracurricular opportunities and resources.

Organization.Name: Materials Science and Engineering Association
Organization.Summary: MSEA is an activity & resource organization for all students majoring in or interested in the field of materials science and engineering. Our organization's main aim is to provide academic, industry, and social services to the overall MSE community.
Organization.Description:
While participation in events is open to everyone interested, our organization specifically caters to students in the department of MSE, with an emphasis towards the undergraduate community.
 
As for academics, we offer review sessions every semester for Engineering 45 students, which is the first intro to materials science class that most students take (regardless of their major). We hold review sessions for classes that only MSE majors are required to take and our infosessions are aimed at students with majors in MSE.  We also offer tele-bears and academic advising. 
 
Our organized faculty events also include MSE related faculty members.We facilitate relationships between faculty and students, such as by arranging monthly dinners with faculty. We also organize industry events, such as info-sessions and seminars.

Organization.Name: Middle Eastern Dance at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: This group aims to promote awareness of Middle Eastern culture and traditions with an emphasis on Middle Eastern Dance.
Organization.Description: We will focus on a variety of dance forms including but not limited to: Belly Dance, Persian Dance, and traditional Middle Eastern Folk Dance. Through workshops, performances, and social events this group hopes to convey the uniqueness of the Middle Eastern culture with UC Berkeley students and the community.

Organization.Name: OJOS
Organization.Summary: To teach and provide a space for optometry students to practice optometric exams in Spanish.

Organization.Name: Open Source Hardware Group of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We seek to develop and post open source hardware schematics and instructions to enable hobbyists and other interested persons to replicate simple devices, especially point of care diagnostic devices.
Organization.Description: We seek to make hardware solutions for common applications available to the public free of cost.

Organization.Name: Peace Talks
Organization.Summary: To actively communicate information about social conflicts in order to gain a more unbiased perspective that will help facilitate a peaceful ending to these conflicts through mediation and conflict resolution
Organization.Description: By engaging in collective negotiation through an unbiased perspective, we will attempt to resolve group conflicts by addressing why conflicts exist and by aiming to understand each side of the issue and bring students together to address these issues within our community and the surrounding community as well

Organization.Name: Phoenix Scholars
Organization.Summary: The Phoenix Scholars are dedicated to empowering underserved youth to pursue their dream of a college degree by guiding them through the college application process.
Organization.Description: 8% of kids growing up in low-income communities graduate from college by the age of 24. The Phoenix Scholars is looking to change that. This organization is a chapter of the non-profit organization The Phoenix Scholars, which is created and currently based at Stanford University. Furthermore, this organization is unique because we have a goal in our mentorship: to guide our mentees through the college application process and help them pursue their dreams of a 4-year degree. We work together with the team at Stanford to coordinate mentor-mentee relations. This is more than just a mentorship program; mentors and mentees find common ground even if they are from different backgrounds, and this program is more college-focused.

Organization.Name: Poetry for the People Student Allies
Simply Vegan
Organization.Summary: To provide a space for students of varying dietary habits and beliefs such as veganism or vegetarianism to meet and introduce these ideas to other students.

Organization.Name: Society of Physics Students at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Society of Physics Students is an organization dedicated to physics-related ideas and cutting-edge research.
Organization.Description: We encourage and assist students interested in physics to develop the knowledge, competence, enthusiasm, and social responsibility that are essential to the advancement of physics; stimulate interest in advanced study and research in physics; develop collegiality among physics students and faculty members; promote public interest in physics; and provide liaison between students and the member societies of the American Institute of Physics.

Organization.Name: Tribe
Organization.Summary: Tribe aims to be a community of faith devoted to following Jesus. At Tribe, students are encouraged to discover what it means to follow Christ through group interaction with scripture rather than passive adherence to doctrine.

Organization.Name: University Catholic Conference of California
Organization.Summary: The University Catholic Conference of California is a conference that seeks to unite university students in California through the universal Catholic faith.
Organization.Description: UCCC was originally a project under Senator Rosemary Hua. The first conference took place during her team on February 15th, 2013 and had over 200+ students from all over the state in attendance. There is no other Catholic Conference held in Berkeley ta this time.

Organization.Name: Women in Vision Science
Organization.Summary: Women in Vision science club encourages people who are doing vision related research to network with each other, foster mentor & mentee relationships between faculty and student members, discuss research & issues that impact women in academia.
Organization.Description: Women in Vision Science will address issues that affect women who are specifically involved in  vision research. The goal is to provide a supportive environment where people can discuss research, ways to increase representation of women in academia, different career paths, and  express concerns and issues that arise regarding gender. Faculty members will also be invited to meetings to discuss their experiences and also to provide mentorship to students.

Organization.Name: Zeta Tau Alpha
Organization.Summary: to be entered
Organization.Description: Mission Statement: To make a difference in the lives of our members by developing the potential of each individual through innovative programming, which emphasizes leadership development, service to others, academic achievement and continued personal growth for women, with a commitment to friendship and the future based on the sisterhood, values and traditions of the past. Purpose: The purpose of Zeta Tau Alpha is the intensifying of friendship, the fostering of a spirit of love, the creating of such sentiments, the performing of such deeds, and the moulding of such opinions as will be conducive to the building up of a purer and nobler womanhood in the world.

Organization.Name: Aletheia Collective
Organization.Summary: A Christian fellowship for women where students can find friends in a safe, drama-free environment interested in answering questions about truth, intellectually challenge one another, & learn through Bible studies, community service, fun outings and more

Organization.Name: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics
Berkeley Environmental Economics and Policy Students
Organization.Summary: A UC Berkeley student organization for students of the Environmental Economics and Policy major and minor to network, socialize and prepare for post graduation.
Organization.Description:
BEEPS (Berkeley Environmental Economics and Policy Students) seeks to bring students of the EEP major together through conceptualizing, collaborating, networking, learning and socializing.
 
As a group of friends in the EEP major, we thought it would be fun to have a place where other EEP students could come and meet each other. This idea grew to not only include community building and socializing, but to provide resources for EEP majors to be better prepared for the professional world. These resources will include talks from professionals, alumni, professors, and graduate students, as well as software workshops and peer tutoring.

The plan is to hold general meetings every other week, where the officers bring in speakers (e.g. EEP alumni) to discuss their career paths and to answer our questions. Occasionally, we will hold review sessions, software workshops, and fun social events. We want to prepare ourselves for the future and have fun doing it!
 
Contact officers at calbeeps@gmail.com to get on the list serve or ask general questions.

Organization.Name: Cal Seismic Design Team
Organization.Summary: The Cal Seismic Design Competition Team provides for UC Berkeley students to learn about earthquake engineering. The group must create a five foot balsa wood structure that has to undergo three different earthquakes of varying strength & length.
Organization.Description:
Starting with the design process all the way to the construction phase, members will be utilizing their engineering skills along with other outside resources to perform successfully. Throughout the year, the group will meet to brainstorm ideas for the design, proposals for the overall look, and actual construction of the structure.  

Since the college does not have specified classes for this emphasis, this group focuses on applying their knowledge and intuition into a competition based team. Competing in the Undergraduate Seismic Design Competition, held by the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (EERI), is the main focus of this group.

Organization.Name: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley (BCPA) is a student organization of University of California Berkeley. Our organization aims at building a network between all amateur and professional photographers at Berkeley.
Organization.Description: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley (BCPA) is a student organization of University of California Berkeley. Our organization aims at building a network between all amateur and professional photographers at Berkeley. We can provide a friendly environment for members to communicate, help them to enrich their experiences and enhance their skills for better photography. We will organize various kind of activities like studio shooting, portraits shooting, sports shooting, photography competition, photography workshops, lectures by professionals and etc. to create more chances for members to get involve in photography.

Organization.Name: Chinese Scholars by CSC at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: This group was established for communication of all CSC supported scholars at UC Berkeley in the name of Consulate General of the People's Republic of China in San Francisco, we hope all scholars join this group to share information.

Organization.Name: Coast and Bay Keepers of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: ..The Coast and Bay Keepers of Berkeley is an environmental organization dedicated to the protection, enhancement, and enjoyment of the San Francisco Bay and Coastal region.
Organization.Description: The Coast and Bay Keepers of Berkeley is an environmental organization dedicated to the protection, enhancement, and enjoyment of the San Francisco Bay and Coastal region. The purpose of this organization is educate students at Berkeley about environmental degradation and pollution of the San Francisco Bay and Coast, and to promote strategies to protect these areas. It is intended to be both an advocacy and volunteer organization dedicated to safeguarding and restoring our local watershed. Ultimately, its purpose is to enhance the water quality of the Bay and Coast for the benefit of its ecosystems and human communities through conservation, activism, and education... Hell Yeah!

Organization.Name: Datong Society of China Studies at Berkeley
Disney Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Official UC Berkeley club for all things Disney! Like our page on Facebook to stay updated!
Organization.Description: The Official UC Berkeley organization for all things Disney! We hold special events and take trips to iconic Disney locations. Learn and experience the joy and magic of Walt Disney and his legacy by joining the happiest club on campus!

Organization.Name: dup - Conservation & Resource Studies Student Organization
dup - Students of Applied Science & Technology
dupe - Latin American Social Welfare Caucus
dupe - One Love: Caribbean Student Association
dupe - Students for the Promotion of Research and Action on Africa
Dupe-East Asian Languages & Cultures Undergraduate Student Association
Environmental Sciences Student Association
Organization.Summary: ESSA's main goal is to bring students with interests in the environment together in a fun, academic, and social atmosphere. Membership is open to all UC Berkeley students.

Organization.Name: EOP Student Association
Organization.Summary: Student-run organization that serves to provide a space for students who identify as low-income, first generation, underrepresented, and/or undocumented college students
Organization.Description:
EOPSA is a student-run organization that serves to provide a space for students who identify as low-income, first generation college students. EOPSA is an opportunity to cater to the needs to the growing number of EOP students by providing a student-run space outside of professional staff. 

The purpose of this organization is help foster leadership and build community within the EOP community and outside the Berkeley community.

Organization.Name: ESAB
Organization.Summary: Also known as Egyptian Student Association at UC Berkeley (ESAB)

Organization.Name: Film & Literature Society, The
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this organization shall be to create a friendly and welcoming environment for film and literature lovers to watch, read, and discuss classic works of art, and in the process be a source of cultural edification for its members.

Organization.Name: Finance Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Finance Club at Berkeley is a student organization dedicated to professional development, trading, and building relationships. Our core mission is to help undergraduates who are interested in finance reach their individual potential.
Organization.Description: Club members will learn practical knowledge about the stock market and how to land a job in the financial industry. MBA’s, professionals, and other upperclassmen will help our members prepare through resume critique, networking, and mock interviews. Our club will also hold weekly trading competitions. Although we expect our members to be dedicated, we will not haze in any way or treat any member disrespectfully. Enjoy your time at Berkeley, invest in yourself, and apply for Finance Club at Berkeley today.

Organization.Name: Forerunner Chinese Student Ministry at Berkeley
Hindu YUVA-Youth for Unity, Virtues and Action
Home of Students Christian Fellowship
Organization.Description: The Purpose of this organization is :(1) To witness to the Lord Jesus Christ as God Incarnate and to seek to lead others to a personal faith in Him as Savior and Lord. (2) To deepen and strength the spiritual life of members by the study of the Bible and by prayer.(3) To present the call of the Lord to the world mission for the church; to help students and faculty to discover God�s vision for them.(4) To promote contacts and friendships with Chinese students.

Organization.Name: InterCP
Organization.Summary: InterCP is a multiethnic Christian mission organization that exists to mobilize, equip, and commission college students to unreached people groups in the 10/40 Window.

Organization.Name: Kazakhstani Student Association
Organization.Summary: Our aim is to unite students from Kazakhstan at UC Berkeley, and work together to create a well-respected society of Kazakhstani students.

Organization.Name: Kollab at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Kollab works to promote an accurate perception of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders through providing a stage for them to showcase their talents.

Organization.Name: Netherlandic Student Association
Organization.Summary: Netherlandic Student Association seeks to organize social events for the Dutch community at UC Berkeley, to allow students to interact with Dutch professionals in their relevant fields, & to encourage awareness of Dutch language and culture.

Organization.Name: Pre-Medical Asian Pacific American Medical Student Association at Berkeley
Queer Womyn at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Social group for anyone who ever has, will, or does identify as a wom(y)n

Organization.Name: Returning Veterans of America Berkeley, CA
SDC Blue Ribbon Foundation Berkeley District
Organization.Summary: Empowering children with disabilities through financial and non-financial means.
Organization.Description: SDC Blue Ribbon Foundation is originally based out of Canada. It was run for three years. During two of those three years, the organization designed, funded, and ran an after school program to help children with disabilities through music therapy. Over 100 children participated in this program. It is currently still running and in its fifth term. Our organization plans on reproducing the same program in the United States along with other initiatives to support children with disabilities.

Organization.Name: Serbian Student Organization at Berkeley - BOSS
Sri Lankan Students Association
Organization.Summary: The SLSA is a collection of students with cultural roots or affinity to Sri Lanka to socialize, promote friendship and understanding with Sri Lanka and the USA, and help Sri Lanka when possible.

Organization.Name: Turkish Student Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The members of Turkish Student Association of Berkeley wish to increase the campus’ awareness regarding Turkey and promote Turkish/Turkish-American community and culture.
Organization.Description: Our organization is unique in bringing together Turkish members of the Berkeley community and promoting an environment for dialog between graduate and undergraduate students within the Turkish community.  We also wish to provide a safe environment for Turkish people to socialize and discuss their problems.

Organization.Name: A Brighter Tomorrow
Organization.Summary: “A Brighter Tomorrow” provides a support group on campus for those who are struggling to cope with the daily stressors of their lives, whether they are suffering from suicide ideation, self-harm, loneliness, mental health issues, and more.
Organization.Description: It is our greatest hope that the club can act as a safety net for students who are considering suicide. Our club also works to spread awareness and education regarding suicide and issues of mental health to the campus through volunteer opportunities for our members, awareness campaigns, and fundraising for organizations dedicated to the prevention of suicide.

Organization.Summary: Our goal is to help current Berkeley students who are working on startups learn marketing skills to launch their product and to connect them with other students who can help.

Organization.Description: Brain|ed videos are informative without being simplistic, and inspire without intimidating, and will allow the general population to gain insight and knowledge into the up and coming field of cognitive and brainscience.
