Organization.Summary: FIT CLUB is a group health & fitness program designed for guaranteed weight loss, muscle definition & target toning while juggling the demands of college life. This club is designed to train “Ladies of Class” to love THYSELF: BODY, MIND, & SPIRIT!
Organization.Description: FIT CLUB is an health & fitness program designed for guaranteed weight loss, muscle definition & Target Toning while juggling the demands College Life. This club is designed to Train “Ladies of Class” to Love THYSELF: BODY, MIND, & SPIRIT!!!We believe fitness and health is about feeling good about yourself in all areas of your life...spiritual,emotional,mental,academic... When these areas of life are in tact a physical transformation takes place. As a Fit Club member you will recieve a TON of GROUP SUPPORT & MOTIVATION , but also.... massage/spa days ! yaayy! The opportunity to meet NEW FRIENDS from AROUND THE WORLD! & Instead of gaining the FRESHMAN 15 & SOPHMORE 30.... How about WE LOOSE IT and have fun being FIT & FEELING FABULOUS! we will also hold special events to help you unwind and feel at your best ready to take on the world...and those ...Finals. Our mission is to INSPIRE YOU, MOTIVATE YOU, & EMPOWER YOU to be the BEST YOU POSSIBLE!! & to have the CONFIDENCE & POWER to say YES! I AM AN EXTRAORDINARY & A PHENOMENAL FIT WOMAN!!!!!! JOIN US & GET FIT & FEEL FABULOUS TODAY! All sizes and fitness levels welcomed!

Organization.Summary: More Than Skin Deep at Berkeley is a student-led community division of the National Psoriasis Foundation of Northern California, whose purpose is to increase the NPF’s ability to improve care, drive better treatment & therapies, and find a cure.
Organization.Description: Our efforts will focus on awareness, education, advocacy, and the advancement of research towards a cure for psoriasis and related chronic skin conditions which are more than skin deep.

Organization.Summary: We are committed to creating good art through staged performances of great plays. We especially try to create opportunities for actors, directors, and others during times when TDPS does not.

Organization.Name: Open Access Initiative at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Open Access Initiative at Berkeley encourages the unrestricted electronic distribution of peer-reviewed scientific and scholarly literature.

Organization.Name: Optimir Consulting
Organization.Summary: Optimir Consulting is a non-profit consulting student group that aims to provide innovative, sustainable, and substantial improvements for various industry clients in the start-up world.
Organization.Description: Our student consultants come from a variety of academic disciplines and experiences and are dedicated to providing results-driven solutions. As a student start-up organization, we aim to develop and expand our consultants' skills. We aim to offer fast-paced and unique training for our student consultants in order to optimize our clients operations through implementation.

Organization.Name: OUTLAW at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose(s) of this organization shall be to provide educational support, professional development, mentoring, and networking opportunities for queer or ally undergraduate students interested in law and related fields.
Organization.Description: To provide a safe, supporting, and professional setting for queer, ally and any other student who are interested in law as a possible career and desire to develop networks, mentorship, or gain educational support.

Organization.Name: Phi Delta Theta
Organization.Summary: The oldest continuous chapter at Berkeley. A brotherhood with a rich tradition that emphasizes academics, honor, and fraternal bonds.
Organization.Description:
Phi Delta Theta was organized with three principle objectives: The cultivation of friendship among its members, the acquirement individually of a high degree of mental culture, and the attainment personally of a high standard of morality.

These objectives, referred to as the Cardinal Principles, have guided over 225,000 men since 1848 when the Fraternity was founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.

The Fraternity teaches men that these areas of commitment, outlined in The Bond of Phi Delta Theta, are not to be viewed as separate ideals, but as areas of discipline for daily life. Developments intellectually, in leadership, and human service (to name a few) are vital to the men of Phi Delta Theta. A member will support, and in turn have the support of, his brothers as these principles are lived out.

Organization.Name: Program for Eating Disorders and Outreach on Campus
Project Nutrition
Organization.Summary: Student -run organization that aims to combat obesity.
Organization.Description:
We are a UC Berkeley student organization founded in 2012 that is dedicated to combating obesity using innovative technology. Currently, we are working on developing a mobile application, Picknic, that incentivizes people to eat healthy. For more information on the app, visit picknicmobile.wordpress.com.

Members of Project Nutrition are actively involved with creating community awareness around healthy eating, connecting with other health organizations and partners, and designing the mobile platform and website.

Organization.Name: Sexual Health for Youth
Organization.Summary: needs a constitution

Organization.Name: Sigma Epsilon Omega Fraternity
Organization.Summary: Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO), UC Berkeley’s only queer and allies fraternity provides male students with a unique opportunity to be included in a safe space focused around respect, community, and respect.
Organization.Description:
Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO), UC Berkeley’s only queer and allies fraternity and one of the few recognized queer and allies fraternities in the nation, provides male students a unique opportunity to be included in a safe space focused around respect , community, and acceptance. Founded by 3 students at UC Berkeley, SEO has continued to break barriers and stereotypes of both the queer and Greek communities.

 

Even though SEO is one of the newer fraternities on campus, we already have incredible accomplishments under our belt. We have seen rapid growth of ourfFraternity starting with a class of 23 Brothers. We also already have a house to call our own! Being a housed chapter is a significant accomplishment for a new fraternity, and provides all of our Brothers with a unique and amazing housing opportunity. Feel free to check out our house at 2708 Channing Way.

 

As brothers, we aim to improve the school community by getting involved in various philanthropy and activism events by raising money, creating awareness, and participating in volunteer work. We seek to foster and maintain a brotherhood that is based on individual and collective strength, equality, and opportunity. We strive to provide an exciting and vibrant social space specifically, but not exclusively, for queer males.

 

Although Sigma Epsilon Omega is a predominatnly queer fraternity, our brotherhood is open to any individual that identifies as male and supports our mission statement. Every individual that rushes (straight, bi-sexual, gay, queer, etc.) will be treated equally and will be put through the same process.

Organization.Name: Sigma Phi Epsilon
Organization.Summary: SigEp is not your stereotypical social fraternity. SigEp practices a four year development program which provides each man with opportunities to further his own personal development. We build Balanced Men.
Organization.Description: SigEp is not your stereotypical social fraternity. We believe in the Balanced Man Program, which leaves no room for hazing, pledging, or discrimination by race or sexual orientation. Instead, SigEp practices a four year development program which provides each man with opportunities to further his own personal development. For over one hundred years at Berkeley, SigEp has surpassed the limits of what it means to be Greek.

Organization.Name: Student Abolitionist Movement
Organization.Summary: The Student Abolitionist Movement strives to bring about a student movement against human trafficking by building and preparing students to speak up and take action against modern-day slavery.
Organization.Description: The Student Abolitionist Movement's main objectives are to strengthen existing anti-human trafficking efforts, educate and inform others about human trafficking through adovocacy and awareness campaigns, and host the Bay Area Student Abolitionist Conference. Any person wanting to work towards ending modern-day slavery is welcome!

Organization.Name: Theta Delta Chi
Organization.Summary: Theta Delta Chi believes that its brotherhood intellectually, morally, and socially improves the beings of its members.
Organization.Description:
Theta Delta Chi reflects the diversity of Berkeley, as we have brothers from a wide variety of backgrounds who all have different interests and personalities.

At Theta Delt, we strive for excellence in school. We have many brothers with engineering and technical majors, and high GPAs. We also have brothers and alumni working at many amazing companies:
Investment Banking: Goldman Sachs, CODE Advisors
Tech: Zynga, Google, Amazon A2Z Development Center
Consulting: Triage
Corporate Development: CBS, Abbott
Research/Development: NASA-JPL, Walt Disney Imagineering

We even have a few brothers and alumni working on different start-up ideas of their own!

In addition to our academic and work achievements, we also know how to achieve victory outside of schoolwork. Theta Delt's IM Dodgeball team is currently a 4-peat championship team. We also have competitive IM basketball and soccer teams.

Only through the strong friendship among its members would all of these things be possible.

Organization.Name: Unite For Sight at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Unite for Sight Berkeley chapter aims to raise awareness for blindness and eye impairment prevention as well as fundraise for global eye clinics in developing countries.
Organization.Description: By supporting these clinics our chapter will be able to help provide thousands of uninsured patients eye exams and treatments and be able to help eliminate blindness around the world. Unite For Sight® is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that empowers communities worldwide to improve eye health and eliminate preventable blindness. Unite For Sight applies best practices in eye care, global health, and social entrepreneurship to achieve our goal of high quality eye care for all. In addition to being a leader in providing cost-effective care to the world's poorest people, our Global Health University develops and nurtures the next generation of global health leaders.

Organization.Name: Cal Students for Equal Rights and a Valid Education
caller
Organization.Summary: The main objective of this group is to organize social events in order to encourage strong relationship among members. We want members to create strong social network, which we hope to be continued after the graduation.

Organization.Name: Chinmaya Yuva Kendra
Organization.Summary: CHYK strives to unite young adults by providing a forum to explore, discuss, and practice Vedanta while strengthening their lives in every endeavor. Visit our website: http://chykbayarea.wix.com/chykbayarea
Organization.Description:
Want to learn more about Vedantic philosophy? Want to meet awesome people? Come check out Chinmaya Mission Yuva Kendra at Berkeley! Our mission is to provide individuals, from any background, the wisdom of Vedanta and the practical means for spiritual growth and happiness.

Relationships, academic pressures, job-related stress, fear of failure, worries about the future, regrets about the past, agitations in the present: “When will I be happy?”

Vedanta, or the Hindu logic of spirituality, answers this fundamental question by shifting our focus from the external world to the internal. By understanding the pathways we take to explore our inner freedom, the paths of action, devotion, meditation, and knowledge, Vedanta invites us to end our agitations using its practical methods to promote inner harmony and ultimately, spiritual awakening.

Every month we have weekly study groups, one seva/community service event, and one social.

As part of the larger Chinmaya and CHYK bay area community, we often have socials and seva events with students and young professionals from around the bay.

Visit our website:
http://chykbayarea.wix.com/chykbayarea


Join our facebook group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/chykbayarea/

We also organize all of events/discussions on the following google group: http://groups.google.com/group/chyk-west-berkeley

The bay area events are organized from the following google group: http://groups.google.com/group/chykbayarea

Organization.Name: Iota Phi Theta Fraternity, Inc.
Organization.Summary: The fraternity was founded by twelve men in the midst of the Civil Rights Movement. Influences included organizations such as the Black Panthers, SNCC, plus individuals like Malcolm X, and Stokely Carmichael.
Organization.Description: Iota Phi Theta Fraternity, Inc. was founded on Morgan State College in 1963 in Baltimore Maryland. We abide by five principles of Scholarship, Leadership, Brotherhood, Fidelity & Citizenship. Our mission is Building a Tradition, Not Resting Upon One. Iota brothers participated in various protests and sit-ins throughout the city of Baltimore. The founders were distinguished from their peers as they were all non-traditional students. Older than their peers, many had served in the military, working full-time while attending classes, and having families. On September 19, 1963, in the height of the Civil Rights' Movement, these twelve founders gathered together on the steps of Hurt Gymnasium on the campus of Morgan State College (now known as Morgan State University) and formed Iota Phi Theta Fraternity, Inc. The fraternity was formed as a support system for men of color during the turbulent U.S. social climate of the time

Organization.Name: Jam Sessions at Berkeley
Organization.Description: The purposes of this club are to provide a platform through which students may access alternative genres of music and learn alternative styles of music, to provide mentors to help expose musicians to the aforementioned genres, and to cultivate a culture based upon relaxing and playing music recreationally.

Organization.Summary: The Jazz Dance Company is a student organization at UC Berkeley that provides an opportunity for our company dancers to embrace various styles of dance, with emphasis on jazz, lyrical, and modern dance.

We hold auditions at the beginning of each semester so be on the look-out for announcements on our page or on Facebook, or you may email us via our listed conatct information.

Anamita Guha (anamita [at] gmail.com)

Organization.Name: Made In A Free World
Organization.Summary: Our goal is to educate students on the issue of modern-day slavery and empower them to educate their communities to work together and create a campus where one day everyone and everything will be free from slave labor.
Organization.Description: We are responsible for educating students, faculty, staff, and the surrounding community on modern-day slavery, advocating for the use of ethically-sourced products, and hosting educational events on campus throughout the academic year.

Organization.Name: New one - Caucus for International Awareness, The
Organization.Summary: CIA’s mission is to practice a multi-cultural, internationally-informed brand of Social Work, both domestically & abroad, in order to promote Social Justice, enhance international collaboration & utilize international insight to improve social welfare
Organization.Description:
In an age of increasing interdependence, and the advent of globalization, international social work is more relevant than ever. The C.I.A. has been formed in order to reflect this reality by: mobilizing internationally-minded undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students, consolidating resources, merging standing curricula, and designing or re-creating international symposiums and field learning opportunities. 

The CIA is unique amongst Berkeley student organizations as it is the only organization that bridges international and domestic social work modalities via a collaborative and multi-cultural approach.  The CIA seeks to work collaboratively with the School of Social Welfare’s administration to link currently disparate global social welfare programs under the auspice of an international field placement exchange program as set forth in the Report of the International Task Force. Furthermore, it is our goal to extend our reach beyond just the School of Social Welfare and to engage the campus at large in recreating the Berkeley International Symposium, with the goal of establishing the symposium as a recurring event.

Organization.Name: Open University
Organization.Summary: The Open University provides an opportunity for all to collectively re-imagine what public education means and what it looks like. This is a learning process for all of us, and the success of the Open University is contingent upon the inclusion and repre

Organization.Summary: To promote the use of persuasive communication for the greater good of society: Fighting health problems, social disparities, global warming, etc. The methodology we use is human-centered design.

Organization.Description: The main source of all creative production would be Korean and its culture. RAG (Ready Action Go) always put emphasis on unity and a convivial atmosphere. Therefore, RAG (Ready Action Go) tries to make a variety of social events in order to increase the level of closeness between club members.

Organization.Name: Sigma Omicron Pi
Organization.Summary: The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi, established in 1930, is the first nastional Asian American Interest sorority. SOPi remains dedicated to its four objectives of unity, friendship, leadership, and service.
Organization.Description:
The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi was established at San Francisco State University in 1930 by ten Asian American women: Elizabeth Hall, Frances Hall, Dorothy Lau, Gertrude Lee, Hannah Lee, Louise Lee, Fannie Lim, Nancy Lim, Emma Lum, and Beatrice Ng, pursuing the interest of teaching. They chose the Greek letters, Sigma, Omicron, and Pi to represent themselves as the "Sisters of Pedagogy." The Constitution was derived from an existing "Honorary Society of Education." 

     The sorority was active in the Asian Community for the next fifteen years. At the advent of World War II, the organization was forced to become inactive. In 1946, a group of women from the University of California, Berkeley re-established Sigma Omicron Pi on their campus. Since its inception, Sigma Omicron Pi has grown in membership with student chapters at: 

Beta Chapter
San Francisco State University, 1988

Gamma Chapter
San Jose State University, 1992

Delta Chapter
University of California, Davis, 1993

Epsilon Chapter
California State University, Sacramento, 1993

Zeta Chapter
University of California, Santa Cruz, 1995

Eta Chapter
University of Maryland, 1997, retired 2000

Theta Chapter
University of California, Irvine, 2001

Iota Chapter
Pennsylvania State University, 2001

Kappa Chapter
University of California, San Diego, 2002

Lambda Chapter
The Johns Hopkins University, 2002

Mu Chapter
University of California, Riverside, 2003

Nu Chapter
Binghamton University, 2008

     Though, the sorority, no longer centered around the interest of teaching, it still maintained its commitment to the Asian American community. All of the chapters became extremely involved in their respective communities, volunteering their time at community agencies and raising money to donate to favorable charities. Sigma Omicron Pi earned a respectable reputation as a benefactor to the Asian American cause.

     The purpose of Sigma Omicron Pi is to promote unity, lifelong friendships, leadership, and community service. This organization offers women a supportive network of sisters to achieve academic and social growth. The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi provides an environment where sisters may utilize and develop their organizational skills.

     Each one of our sisters has different interests and aspirations, yet we all share one common ground - SOPi. We have based our sisterhood on four objectives: UNITY, FRIENDSHIP, LEADERSHIP and SERVICE. In addition, Sigma Omicron Pi has a tradition of lifelong friendship that has prevailed for over eight decades.

Organization.Name: Sigma Phi Omega
Organization.Summary: "The reward is in the doing."
Organization.Description: Sigma Phi Omega is a nationwide Asian American interest sorority, founded in 1949 at USC. In 1997, the Zeta Chapter of Sigma Phi Omega was established at UC Berkeley and is recognized as an official Greek sorority by the Multi Cultrual Greek council here on the Cal campus. Berkeley Sigmas are seeking unique and motivated individuals who wish to expand their college experience by developing leadership skills, creating priceless memories, and establishing lifelong friendships.

Organization.Description:
The AGC chapter at UC Berkeley is dedicated to educating, promoting, connecting students with industry professionals in the AEC industry. Our goals are:

2. To cooperate with the university officials and the local AGC Chapter in sponsoring meetings, field trips and other events of interest to the student members. 

3. To promote both scholarship and fellowship among the members of the Chapter.

Organization.Name: Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Founded in early 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley.
Organization.Description:
Founded in early 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to connect entrepreneurial individuals, consolidate entrepreneurship network, and incubate future industry leaders. We provide valuable learning and networking opportunities for our members through a wide range of entrepreneurship events/programs and extensive collaboration with other communities in US universities and Silicon Valley.

成立于2012年初，伯克利华人创业协会 (ACE: Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs at Berkeley) 是加州大学伯克利分校最大的华人主题社团。我们的宗旨是聚集热衷创业的伯克利华人学生，建立紧密的校友创业网络，孕育未来杰出的华人企业家。为此，我们致力于开展形式丰富多样的创业主题活动，同时与美国诸多高校和硅谷地区众多华人组织和各业界伙伴密切合作，为ACE成员带来有价值的学习和交流资源。

Organization.Name: Leadership Committee, The
Organization.Summary: TLC’s mission is to provide scholars of The Achievement Award Program opportunities to further develop their leadership skills.
Organization.Description:
TLC’s mission is to provide scholars of The Achievement Award Program opportunities to

further develop their leadership skills by:

· Developing outreach opportunities

· Organizing community service events and social activities

· Planning and facilitating meetings.

 

TLC offers membership to any individuals that are current recipients of The Achievement Award Program by the Cal Alumni Association. Only currently registeredstudents, faculty, and staff may be active members in a registered student organization. Only active members may vote or hold office.

We will not haze according to California State Law. We will not restrict membership based upon race, color, national origin, religion, sex, physical and mental disability, medical condition (cancer-related or genetic characteristics), ancestry, marital status, age, sexual orientation,

citizenship or status as a covered veteran (special disabled veteran, Vietnam-era veteran or any other veteran who served on active duty during a war or in a campaign or expedition for which a

campaign badge has been authorized).

Organization.Name: MoneyThink
Organization.Summary: To teach students the skills necessary to efficiently and effective mentor high school students in a financial sense.
Organization.Description: Our goal is to mentor young adults and teach them about the financial deficit, debt solutions, leadership, and business skills. We will institute a 7-week financial curriculum to fully prepare each student for future financial problems, regardless if they attend college. Thus, we hope to contribute to the eradication of the US financial debt by teaching and preparing our next generation of citizens.

Organization.Name: National Eagle Scout Association
Organization.Summary: The PURPOSE of a NATIONAL EAGLE SCOUT ASSOCIATION AFFINITY GROUP is to help bring together Eagle Scouts, who share a common interest or affinity, for the betterment of the community, youth members of the Boy Scouts of America, and each other.
Organization.Description:
Have you ever participated in a sport or hobby and found that some of the people participating with you were Eagle Scouts?

Or took a class in college and realized that one of your study partners is an Eagle Scout?

Or perhaps, had a conversation with someone at a seminar or trade show and recognized an Eagle Scout lapel pin on their blazer.

Well, what happened???

After realizing the common ground of Scouting, most folks begin sharing with one another their similar camp experiences, the toughest merit badge they earned, how cool their Scoutmaster was, or maybe some of the details of their Eagle Scout project.

But what happened after that???

Well, if you are like most people that is where it ends and you get back to your hobby or studying for the next exam or move on to the next networking encounter.

The National Eagle Scout Association thinks it could be more!

NESA believes that the common ground of Scouting and a shared vocation or hobby (including college affiliation) between Scouting alumni could lead to some really great things.

The trick is getting organized. And that is where NESA Affinity groups come in…

Organization.Name: New Beginning Academics Student Association
Organization.Summary: New Beginning Academics Student Association (NBASA) is purposed to provide visiting students and scholars with opportunities to learn American slang language, social manners, American music, and other American culture aspects.
Organization.Description: Since visiting students and scholars might not be able to have chances for exploring American culture during their short-term visit in U.S., we will invite speakers to provide the presentations in different American culture fields. Our objectives include arranging student mixtures, info sessions about American education system, and guest lecturers.We also promote the interaction between our members and other universities' visiting students and scholars, so they will be able to gain a better feel of the local culture and share their perspectives. NBASA hopes to spread the customs of American culture to all.

Organization.Name: Ocean Society of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Ocean Society of Berkeley is an organization which promotes ocean awareness, environmentalism, and research while providing an opportunity for leadership and networking in the student community.

Organization.Name: One World Futbol at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: One World Futbol is an organization which provides sustainable soccer balls to children in impoverished areas, and is currently operating in 88 countries across the globe.
Organization.Description: These soccer balls are designed to last for years in all terrains, providing a sustainable alternative, and keeping hundreds of traditional balls out of landfills. Even after being run over by a truck, and stabbed with knives, the One World Futbols retain their shape and bounce. These Futbols, currently in countries such as Tanzania and, a symbol of hope for the impoverished children of these areas.

Organization.Name: Operation Smile
Organization.Summary: Operation Smile is an organization that mobilizes individuals to contribute to the generous cause of healing children's smiles and change their lives.
Organization.Description: Every three minutes a child is born with a cleft and one in ten of those children will die before their first birthday. Even if these children survive they are often unable to speak, eat, socialize, or smile. Each child deserves access to the proper surgical care that could alleviate these issues. This organization is set up to give students an opportunity for leadership and carry out service to help those in need. The organization is also important for educating members and the general public about these issues. Through fundraising the organization hopes to raise money to provide surgeries for these children in need.

Organization.Name: Pi Sigma Epsilon
Organization.Summary: PI SIGMA EPSILON The only marketing, management, retail professional business fraternity
Organization.Description:
Interested in sales, marketing, and management?

Then PI SIGMA EPSILON is The Brand You Need

The only marketing, sales and retail management fraternity

Organization.Name: Pre-Physician Assistant Society
Organization.Summary: The Pre-PA Society aims to provide support and resources for pre-physician assistant students at Berkeley, promote the advancement of the profession, and help prepare students in applying to Physician Assistant schools.

Organization.Name: Professional Development in Asia
Organization.Summary: Raise interest in professional development in Asia; Facilitate access to career opportunities in Asia; Provide networking opportunities for students and recruiters; Organize social events and professional workshops; Build and maintain relationships
Organization.Description:
PDA, or Professional Development in Asia, provides the Berkeley community a look into the field of career opportunities in Asia. We offer a greater understanding of professional development in Asia beyond job opportunities, such as career information on recruitment, and future of business in Asia.

We are the only Asia-oriented professional organization on campus, and we seriously believe in giving students the opportunity to experience the exciting field.

Organization.Name: Russian Speaking Business Club at Berkeley
Sketchicho!
Organization.Summary: Sketchico! provides UC Berkeley students an opportunity to write and perform comedic sketches similar to those seen on shows such as Saturday Night Live and MadTV

Organization.Name: Society of the Friends of the University
Society of Women In Science
Organization.Summary: ﻿The Society of Women in Science (SWIS) works to foster a community of women in STEM majors at UC Berkeley, providing a space for academic and personal support, networking, social events, outreach into the Bay Area and beyond.
Organization.Description:
The Society of Women in Science (SWIS) works to foster a community of women in STEM majors at UC Berkeley, providing a space for academic and personal support, networking, social events, outreach into the Bay Area and beyond, and a connection with trending developments in science.

 

Committees:

     *Funraising

     *Outreach

     *Academic

     *Activities

     *Women in Science Speaker Series

 

Officers:

     President: Sarah Tulga

     Vice President: Emilia Wakamatsu

     Secretary: Smriti Joneja

Organization.Name: Southwest Asian and North African Checkbox Campaign Committee
Square Up
Organization.Summary: Square Up is a modern Western square dance club, which provides the UC Berkeley community with the opportunity to participate in this fun, community-building, recreational dance form.

Organization.Name: Startup At Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Startup At Berkeley (ST@B) connects undergraduate, graduate, and faculty entrepreneurs from UC Berkeley to the greater entrepreneurial ecosystem through events, speakers, and job postings.

Organization.Name: Student ACTION ~ UNITE Greek ~ Apple ENGINEERING
Undergraduate Finance Association/ Undergraduate Management Consultants Group
United Nations Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The United Nations Association of Berkeley is dedicated to building understanding of and support for the ideals and vital work of the United Nations on the UC Berkeley campus.
Organization.Description: We plan on hosting numerous service events such as Nothing But Nets for people in countries with malaria risks, as well as, dinner forums and career panels for students to attend and to listen to past UN members or those deeply involved with the UN. We do not host a Model United Nations Competition, but will work in conjunction with the group to host service events.

Organization.Name: Wildlife Society at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Wildlife Society at Berkeley's mission is to educate students about wildlife-related careers and to promote wildlife conservation both locally and internationally.
Organization.Description: The Wildlife Society at Berkeley will be the first professional organization on campus that focuses completely on wildlife conservation. Through networking with wildlife biologists, policy makers, GIS specialists, and other wildlife professionals in the Bay Area, we will learn about local wildlife conservation issues and educate our fellow students about current events through regular work days and a monthly bulletin/flyer. We will be collaborating with the San Francisco Bay Area Chapter of the Wildlife Society to have joint volunteer and educational events, as well as having the wildlife professionals in the Society mentor students wishing to enter the field of Wildlife Conservation. Furthermore, regular camping, hiking and bird-watching trips will be organized for students to learn more about the wildlife in California.

Organization.Name: Writers' Ink: Center for Creative Delinquents
Organization.Summary: WICCD endeavors to bring together creative writers on campus to hone their craft in a supportive, social environment.
Organization.Description: We conduct workshops, socials, community events, and serve as a support group for aspiring student writers. We are currently forging new avenues in the local community to connect the students with local writers, poets, screenwriters and other professionals. Check out our website!

Organization.Name: Zahanat
Organization.Summary: Zahanat is an all-male fusion dance team at UC Berkeley that brings together the dancing techniques of Hindi film music and modern day American Music.
Organization.Description: Through dance, they seek to meld together an identity for Indian-Americans on campus.

Organization.Name: Academic and Recreational Enrichment for Children
Alexander Hamilton Society
Organization.Summary: To build a community for the discussion of important international relations issues and to provide a platform to connect students to policy professionals to get involved with policy issues they care about.
Organization.Description: We are the Alexander Hamilton Society, a national foreign policy society that includes students, policy professionals, and academics from universities across the country, at Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Alternative Breaks: Take It to the Streets
Bearwolves of Berkeley: a Boardgame and Werewolves Club
Big Brothers Big Sisters of Berkeley
Big C Track Club at Berkeley
Bridge Club
Organization.Summary: Come play bridge! We will have a casual game, but student members can also form a collegiate team and attend club meetings in order to prepare for the intercollegiate championship.

Organization.Name: California Archery
Organization.Summary: California Archery is a student-run club that provides an opportunity for the Berkeley community to experience archery as a recreational and competitive sport. People of all ages and skill levels are welcome.
Organization.Description:
California Archery is a student-run club that provides an opportunity for the Berkeley community to experience archery as a recreational and competitive sport. People of all ages and skill levels are welcome.

Practices are held on the Golden Bear Softball Field, located just off of Dwight Way at the north end of the Clark Kerr Campus.

Open practice hours for the academic year are:

Monday 6 – 8 PM
Wednesday 4 – 6 PM
Friday 6 – 8 PM

Organization.Name: Competitive Chess Club
Organization.Summary: Interested in playing chess/bughouse? Come to the UC Berkeley Chess Club! We meet in 225 Dwinelle Hall every Wednesday from 7-9 PM! Players of all skill levels are welcome.

Organization.Name: Crowdfunding at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The purpose of this organization is to encourage the spirit of crowdfunding and the circulation of innovative ideas by providing consulting services to campaign hosts in Berkeley.

Organization.Name: Curling Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Our club's mission is to introduce people to the sport of curling and field a collegiate curling team to compete weekly at a recreational level. We frequently offer opportunities to learn about curling and get involved in the community. Come join us!
Organization.Description:
Our mission: to (1) introduce people to the sport of curling and (2) compete in weekly recreational curling matches.

We are the first collegiate curling club in the state of California, and members have the opportunity to help other colleges and universities start clubs to foster intercollegiate competition. Our long-term goal is to field teams at the US National College Curling Championship.

We're partnered with the San Francisco Bay Area Curling Club, and we curl at the Oakland Ice Center, which is accessible by both BART and AC Transit bus. To access by BART, take the Fremont-bound line to 19th St. Oakland station and exit via Telegraph Ave. To access by AC Transit bus, take the 1 bus toward Bay Fair BART and alight at the 19th St. Oakland BART stop.

If you're interested in learning more about curling, get started here! Also, check out this introduction video from the US Curling Association!

Be sure to follow us on Facebook and Twitter! And for questions on events or curling in general, email us at calcurling@gmail.com!

Organization.Name: DUP - Journal of Ethics at Berkeley
dup - Karate Club
Organization.Summary: no signatories

Organization.Name: dup - Shorin Ryu Karate at Berkeley
GlutenX
Organization.Summary: We are dedicated to providing students with peer support and resources to lead a healthy gluten-free lifestyle while at college.
Organization.Description: Our primary goal is to create a supportive community for those who are limited by what they can eat, specifically students with Celiac Disease, Gluten Sensitivity, or any other food-related allergies. Additionally, we strive to unite all students who lead a gluten-free lifestyle by advocating for greater accommodations within the dining commons, creating a gluten-free student guide specific to the Cal campus, and spreading awareness to help those undiagnosed begin on the path of recovery.

Organization.Name: Graduates Reaching A Dream Deferred Northern California
Organization.Summary: Graduates Reaching A Dream Deferred Northern California envisions a system of higher education where ALL students aspiring toward a graduate education, regardless of immigration status, have the same opportunities as their peers across Northern Calif.
Organization.Description:
Graduates Reaching A Dream Deferred Northern’s California mission is to create a network of DREAM graduate students and allies centralized in Northern California in order to:
Facilitate peer support for current and prospective undocumented graduate students.
Advocate for systemic changes to increase financial, academic, and community support for undocumented graduate students
Collaborate with community organizations to maximize services for undocumented graduate students

Organization.Name: Investment Banking Student Association of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Investment Banking Student Association of Berkeley is one of the first clubs at Berkeley that focuses on all aspects of revenue-generating operations at a bulge bracket investment bank. We prepare members for summer analyst roles at investment banks.
Organization.Description: This organization consists of members having previously worked or planning to work at an investment bank. We have a focus on practical experience and training will consist of including financial modeling, valuation, and accounting courses taught by students and professionals having worked or who are currently working in the field. We also plan to partner with firms to hold externships at their offices, and hold investment banking case competitions on campus. Instead of being a club of purely interest in investment banking and focusing on following industry news, we differentiate ourselves by providing members significant practical case, modeling, and work experience. We only accept members who are serious about investment banking as a career path, as we will utilize our resources to help them secure a job in the field to the very best of our ability.

Organization.Name: Judo Appreciation Club of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: To analyze and practice the goals and philosophy of the Japanese martial art, Judo, as intended by its founder, Kano Jigoro, and his many disciples.

Organization.Name: La Raza Caucus of the School of Social Welfare
Organization.Summary: The La Raza Caucus of Social Welfare supports Raza students (Latino/a, Chicano/a) and faculty, advocate for the retention and recruitment of Raza students and faculty, and to become politically involved in issues that affect our community.
Organization.Description:
The purpose of the Caucus is to unite the efforts of social welfare students who desire and are committed to working towards the improvement of the quality of life of Raza/Latino people and their communities.

Our goals include:
1.To help students make optimum use of the University and its facilities;
2.To enrich Latino students’ Social Work education;
3.To provide the student body with alternative means for learning about social work with Latino populations; and
4.To create a liaison between faculty, students and the social work profession to further the attainment of mutual goals for a high quality professional education in Social Welfare.

The Raza gains its uniqueness by being embedded in the united efforts of the School of Social Welfare at UC Berkeley, which further strives to improve the quality of life for Raza/Latino people and their community.

Our desire to utilize the university and its various resources to enrich our education of Latino students, as well as our commitment to providing students with alternative means for learning about social work, further sets our group apart.

Lastly, we are unique in our approach to creating liaisons between faculty, students and the social work profession to further the attainment of mutual goals for a high quality professional education in Social Welfare.

Organization.Name: Magic Club, The
Organization.Summary: The purpose of the Magic Club is to draw together individuals sharing a passion for magic. The goal isn’t necessarily to teach tricks of the trade, but more to cultivate a love for the wonderment that comes with magic.
Organization.Description: Moreover, this club is also focused on using magic as a tool to integrate fellow magicians in the society through philanthropic efforts. Ultimately this club is meant to view magic as a way of life that can help broaden an individuals horizons.

Organization.Name: Photowalk Club
Organization.Summary: Photowalking is simply the act of walking while taking pictures, and that's exactly what we do. This club is for anyone who enjoys photograph, exploring, or just taking breaks. Join us on monthly excursions around the Bay Area.

Organization.Name: Poetry for the People Publishing Committee
Pokemon Club at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Pokémon Club at Cal connects all Pokémon enthusiasts interested in battling, trading, or just meeting fellow Pokémon lovers.
Organization.Description:
Interested in Pokémon? The Pokémon Club at Cal strives to unite Pokémon fans in and around Berkeley.

Activities:

  • Trades and Battles
  • Tournaments, both among other club members and possibly at regional video game championships
  • Discussion of the metagame
  • And more!

Sound good? Email pokemonclubatcal@gmail.com to be added to a mailing list for further information on meetings and events!

Organization.Name: Policy Wonks in Training
Organization.Summary: Policy Wonks in Training (Policy WIT) is a campus-based student group created to support the professional training, academic achievement and quality of life of doctoral students of the Goldman School of Public Policy (GSPP).
Organization.Description: We leverage available resources to fulfill the current needs of the GSPP community and motivate our students to organize projects that will lead to future improvements. Our priorities include career development and research resources, meetings and events that facilitate faculty involvement in student work and improve the quality of education, and professional development activities such as conference and external trainings.

Organization.Name: Practical Modern Chinese Martial Arts Association
Project Nur
Organization.Summary: Project Nur intends to implement meaningful civic, direct services, and cultural initiatives on campus centered on human rights, civil rights, social justice, understanding, and co-existence in an attempt to help diminish stereotypes and misunderstanding
Organization.Description:
Project Nur was founded in August 2007 as a response to tensions on college campuses across the U.S. Project Nur intends to implement meaningful civic, direct services, and cultural initiatives on campus centered on human rights, civil rights, social justice, understanding, and co-existence in an attempt to help diminish stereotypes and misunderstandings.
Project Nur will be dedicated to creating a space that allows all students to learn from, and about, each other in order to build an inter-ethnic and multi-faith student community promoting human rights and civil rights; this would ultimately result in emphasizing the positive values and expectations of all identities, while promoting co-existence, tolerance and understanding. Furthermore, Project Nur aims to emphasize positive relationships by building bridges between Muslim and non-Muslim students in order to diminish generalizations and stereotypes.
Nur, defined in Arabic as enlightenment, will position itself as a Muslim-led forum for students from various backgrounds, cultures, and faith to come together to celebrate their differences, solidify their commonalities, and bring light or knowledge to their respective communities.
Nationally, Project Nur is recognized as a student-led initiative of the American Islamic Congress.
The goals of Project Nur relate to the name and mission which reach out to students to promote understanding of each other in the spirit of enlightenment.
1. Project Nur aims to form a social arena for students to represent a strong identity of eclectic backgrounds and opinions, while opening the doors for people of other cultures to come, share, discuss, and ask questions in a multicultural setting.

2. Project Nur's goal is to a build a student led initiative for human rights and civil rights led by students in order to denounce hate speech and violence, by being committed to co-existence, understanding and individual human and civil rights.

3. Project Nur aims to create the ground for voices of eclectic Muslim-Americans and non-Muslim Americans by working with students who are progressive, reformist, liberal, secular, moderate or conservative and without proselytizing and judging Muslims of different thought.

We do not make religious rulings, and the chapter will not provide a religious agenda. The role of Project Nur is to promote human rights, promote positive social change in the pursuit of civil rights, and celebrate cultural and social identities students whether the individuals are religious or not.

 

It is the minimum requirement of the PN Board and its committees
(mentioned hereinafter) to organize at least three events per academic year of the
following:
• Social events.
• Cultural events.
• Academic events.
• Community service engagements in the wider Ann Arbor area.
In addition, the PN website must be kept up-to-date, serving current and
prospective members as well as sponsors.

Organization.Name: Psychology at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: A scientific publication specializing in undergraduate research conducted in psychology and related fields.
Organization.Description: The Undergraduate Journal of Psychology at Berkeley (UJPB) is a student-run publication which features exciting research from undergraduates in the areas of psychology, neuroscience, cognitive science, and other related fields. We feature articles by authors from all over the country, providing a great way for undergrads to get a sense of what their peers are up to and bring the community of undergraduate research a little closer together.

Organization.Name: Reading, Writing, and Realizing the Berkeley Environment
Save Our Sisters
Organization.Summary: Save Our Sisters advocates to end violence against women & aims to raise awareness on local and global issues surrounding women's rights and human rights violations, with a focus on (but not limited to) the South Asian community.
Organization.Description: Save Our Sisters is unique from other organizations at UC Berkeley in that we aim to work with survivors of domestic violence, sexual asault, sex trafficking, and child abuse through providing community service to various organizations such as local women's shelters, helplines, etc. We also aim to raise awareness through organizing teach-ins and engaging in peaceful protests on local and global women's rights issues, as well as collaborating with other organizations to  celebrate female empowerment through social and cultural events.  Save Our Sisters promotes female empowerment, justice, and equality.

Organization.Name: SBERK: Homestucks at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: SBERK will provide a local means for fans of Andrew Hussie’s webcomics, particularly his webcomic Homestuck, to gather and share their enthusiasm together. In this way, we hope to provide an outlet by which camaraderie, social gatherings, public services
Organization.Description: We hope to provide an outlet by which camaraderie, social gatherings, public services, and other such benefits may be met through the united enjoyment of such aforementioned works

Organization.Name: Science Fiction and Fantasy Short Story Workshop
Organization.Summary: Science Fiction and Fantasy Writing Workshop We write and workshop stories. New members always welcome. For more information, go to facebook.com/groups/sffww

Organization.Name: Ski and Snowboard Team at Berkeley
Social Ballroom Dance Club at Berkeley
Stock Trading Crew of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: The Stock Trading Crew of Berkeley brings anyone who is interested in trading stocks on a short term time frame together. We do NOT “invest” in stocks. We “trade” stocks that have great technicals and positive future catalysts.
Organization.Description: We plan to work together, sharing and debating about ideas, using technical, fundamental, and derivatives analysis to generate the greatest return possible in a short period of time with minimal risk. We do NOT “invest” in stocks. We simply “trade” stocks that have great technicals and positive future catalysts that will propel the stock forward in only a couple weeks or months. Members will learn and trade (paper trade or trade with their own real accounts if experienced) alongside with other members during the day, utilizing the three types of analyses described above. Members will meet either in person or online in a proposed chatroom between the hours of 6:30am-1pm from Monday thru Friday - whenever members have the time to do so.

Organization.Name: Strawberry Creek Collective
Organization.Summary: The Strawberry Creek Collective (SCC) aims to encourage the widespread participation of members of the Strawberry Creek watershed in the diverse and numerous activities involved in the ongoing ecological restoration of Strawberry Creek.
Organization.Description: The Strawberry Creek Collective (SCC) supports the cultural, democratic, educational, ethical, and scientific processes important to fostering a wholesome and inclusive restoration effort.

Organization.Name: Swipes for the Homeless at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Swipes for the Homeless aims to tangibly and tactically partner with college campuses to alleviate hunger while raising college students’ awareness of homelessness and hunger, which is prevalent in their community, through education and outreach.
Organization.Description: Swipes for the Homeless is an international, 501(c)3 non-profit organization consisting of a coalition of university and college chapters located throughout the world. Their dual mission is to tangibly and tactically partner with college campuses to alleviate hunger while raising college students’ awareness of homelessness and hunger, which is prevalent in their community, through education and outreach. Swipes for the Homeless was established as a student organization in the Fall of 2009 at the University of California, Los Angeles.  The organization has now established successful chapters at University of Southern California, University of Paris in France, University of California, Santa Barbara, University of California at Irvine, and University of California at San Diego. Ultimately, Swipes for the Homeless is a broad-based collaborative initiative among university students who are assisting in alleviating the neighboring homeless populations through programs and events among university communities, in hopes of eventually impeding hunger and homelessness.

Organization.Name: Team F.I.T. at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Team F.I.T. is a coalition whose purpose is to forge stronger spirits by promoting healthy living of both body and mind, achieved through the application of three core values: Fitness, Integrity, and Teamwork.

Organization.Name: Urban Culture Society
Organization.Summary: Urban Culture Society hopes to explore the surrounding urban city area of Berkeley and the general San Francisco Bay area; increase the general public’s awareness of the hidden treasures of the urban city such as cafes, museums, and other fine arts.

Organization.Name: Voces Cinemáticas: Latin American/Iberian Film Club
Organization.Summary: Our club seeks to promote cultural awareness through a Latin American lens/perspective in an open environment. We explore the historical and cultural perspective through film and discussion of the way film preserves & develops understanding

Organization.Name: [make]new christian fellowship
Organization.Summary: Our vision is to use creative arts to engage the campus about Christianity. We offer training in film, Photoshop, photography, cooking, and music and use these skills to express the gospel. We have weekly Bible studies and have fun activities all year.
Organization.Description:
Web: http://makenewfellowship.org/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/makenewfellowship

Organization.Name: Aero Design SAE
Organization.Summary: This student competition team is organized to design, build and race UAV and R/C air crafts at international competitions
Organization.Description: It is the first international aero design competition team on campus. It is sponsored through SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers) and goes beyond simple model air crafts. The air crafts must compete internationally in various challenges.

Organization.Name: Berkeley Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: Find out more by visiting www.tjc.us!

Organization.Name: Boalt Immigration Group
Organization.Summary: BIG aims to unite a community of students excited about immigration law.
Organization.Description:
To that end, we hope to connect students with immigration experts, advocate for advanced immigration courses, organize career-related as well as substantive speaker panels, and support local efforts to help students and low-wage workers regularize their immigration status.

BIG’s goals include:

Providing a mechanism for law students to network with professors, alums working in immigration, Bay Area immigration activists, and undergraduate students.
Building upon our growing immigration program by advocating for more classes, such as a Crimmigration class or an upper-level Immigration class.
Co-hosting speaker events with other immigration-minded student groups like CARC and La Raza, among others. These events will give students the chance to learn about different areas of immigration law and see how it intersects with other legal studies.
Connecting students with local volunteer efforts to help identify undocumented immigrants who are eligible for various forms of legal relief.

Organization.Name: Cal Christian Fellowship - IVCF
Organization.Summary: We are a multiethnic Christian fellowship and one of the six sister fellowships (CCF, Kapwa, ISM, Greek IV, BCM and La Fe) — Together we seek to discover God's heart in an authentic community.
Organization.Description:
Cal Christian Fellowship (IVCCF) is a multi-ethnic community of students seeking to learn more about Jesus and how He's relevant to our lives. We are part of the InterVarsity Christian Fellowship at Cal. We meet regularly for weekly small group bible studies and large group fellowship meetings to grow deeper in our faith, stronger as a community, and wider in our impact.

Our Vision: To be a community of students transformed by the whole Gospel to love God, the campus, and the world. 

Cal Christian Fellowship (IVCCF) is part of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, which consists of 6 sister fellowships:
Black Campus Ministries (BCM), Cal Christian Fellowship (CCF), Greek IV, International Student Ministries (ISM), Kapwa, and LaFe. Together we seek to discover God's heart in an authentic community.

IV's Vision:
To see students and faculty transformed,
campuses renewed,
and world changers developed.

Organization.Name: Campus Crusade for Christ
Organization.Summary: To build a movement of people who are transformed by Jesus Christ

Organization.Name: Campus Lions Club of Berkeley
Organization.Summary: Campus Lions Clubs help provide opportunity for the campus community to address the unique needs on their college campus and reach out to the local community and communities around the world.
Organization.Description: Campus Lions Club is the collegiate version of Lions International which is an organization that focuses on a variety of different causes, but the bay area clubs focus on helping the blind and visually impaired.

Organization.Name: Caring Hand For Children at Berkeley
Chi Alpha Christian Fellowship
Organization.Summary: We are a diverse group that loves God.

Organization.Name: Christian Science Organization at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: We meet every Thursday at 7:30 at 2601 Durant Avenue.
Organization.Description:
Hour-long meetings include readings from the Bible and other spiritual writings, prayer, singing, and sharing.  They are generally followed by an unstructured "hangout" time for whomever wants to join.  Keep an eye out for special events!

Any and all CSO activities are open to all, and catered with the Cal community in mind.

Organization.Name: Christians at Boalt
Organization.Summary: Christians at Boalt provides a safe community for students to come together for bi-monthly fellowship to talk about the Christian faith and deepen our commitment to God and one another. We also hold occasional social activities, including dinners and ne
Organization.Description: We are the only Christian group that is open to people of all faiths based at the law school.  We provide bi-monthly Bibles studies during the lunch hour.  One leader chooses a passage from scripture and guides the group discussion for each meeting.  We also provide a community within the law school for those seeking spiritual support.  We offer a time for those who self-identify as Christians, and those interested in learning more about the Christian faith, to encourage one another though the ups and downs of law school.  We also provide networking opportunities to connect people to churches, other bible studies, and other faith groups at Berkeley. We also hold occasional social activities, including dinners and networking events with other graduate student groups.

Organization.Name: Christians on Campus
Organization.Summary: We are a student group composed of believers in Christ from various backgrounds, and we stand absolutely for the faith common to all Christians. We love the Lord Jesus Christ, endeavor to give Him “the first place in all things" (Col. 1:18), and have ...
Organization.Description:
We love the Lord Jesus Christ, endeavor to give Him “the first place in all things” (Col. 1:18), and have the utmost respect for His Word. We meet simply as Christians without any denominational affiliation because we treasure the testimony of the oneness of the Body of Christ, and our desire is to cooperate with Him for the accomplishment of God’s eternal purpose (Eph. 3:11) by ministering the unsearchable riches of Christ (Eph. 3:18) for the building up of the Body of Christ (Eph. 4:12).

We warmly receive all believers as our brothers and sisters in Christ and seek to maintain the oneness of the Spirit by keeping our focus on Christ. In addition to pursuing fellowship, we also desire to strengthen and spread the Lord’s testimony on the UC Berkeley campus.

Organization.Name: CoachArt at Berkeley
Organization.Summary: CoachArt@Berkeley aims to advocate CoachArt’s mission and the importance of art and athletics to improve the lives of children with chronic and/or life-threatening illnesses by hosting campus-wide art drives and community events.

Organization.Name: Coaching Corps at Berkeley
Organization.Summary:
We improve the health, educational and social outcomes for kids living in struggling communities through the power of service and sports.
If you would like to coach check out: http://www.coachingcorps.org/coach/
Organization.Description:
We are a Corps of motivated college students and community members who serve as volunteer coaches, mentors and role models in afterschool sports programs serving girls and boys who live in some of our most under-resourced communities.

We exist to ensure that for all kids, the opportunity to run, play, learn, be coached and work with a team is a given – not a luxury. We are Coaching Corps and we are changing the game for the kids who need us most.

On the surface, what we do may look easy – we offer a full-season of sports programs for kids who normally wouldn’t get them.  We pair up with another Coaching Corps coach and we create teams, design drills, give high-fives and coach our kids through wins and losses on and off the field.

If you look deeper, we are more than just coaches.  We promote positive peer relationships, inspire leadership in kids and ensure the emotional and physical safety of all our athletes.  We know there is no life lesson that sports can’t teach … and we teach those lessons.

To date, 3,000 of us have changed the game for more than 30,000 kids.

Additionally, we offer our afterschool partners a range of crucial support, including training and consulting.

We are a community of advocates. Through our research and special initiatives, we raise awareness of the disparity in opportunity for populations most in need such as girls in low-income communities. And we educate policymakers and opinion leaders on the importance of ensuring that all kids have a chance to play – and experience the life-changing benefits of sports.

We have embarked on an ambitious goal to change the game for 300,000 kids across the nation over the next five years.

Engineering for Kids
Organization.Summary: E4K is an annual one-day outreach event hosted on the campus of UC Berkeley.
Organization.Description: We invite roughly 400 local elementary students here for an exciting day of science activities, demonstrations, and lab tours. The goal is to expose under-priveleged and under-represented children to science and engineering at a young age in order to persuade them to pursue a technical degree in the future.
